Bottle. Nice smoky aroma - ham, sausage, smoked cheese. Pours dark brown with strong medium head. Taste of smoked meat, malty, earthy. A bit of iron in the background. Medium body, average carbonation. Classic Urbock.

500 ml bottle. Pours a flaky deep amber brown with a resilient, thick, creamy beige head. Aroma is smoky, woody, salty and meaty. Flavor is fruits, meat, salt, berries, caramel, brown sugar. Finish is smoky, woody, salty. Medium body, velvety mouthfeel, average carbonation.

Dark reddish brown color, small beige head. Aroma with roasted malts, smoked bacon and oak. Taste is similar plus some fruity notes - dry sweet with medium bitter finish and smoky aftertaste. Medium body and average carbonation. Nice smoked beer, quite enjoyable.
Amberish in colour with a nice thick white head. Deliciously smoky in taste.

50cl bottle at Haasche Bluf.
smokey aroma. Thick creamy off white head. Clear amber pour. Smokey aftertaste but well balanced. Very good.

Butelka; barwa brÄ…zowa z rubinowymi refleksami. Piana beÅ¼owa, bujna, zostaje do koÅ„ca. Intensywny aromat wÄ™dzony, palony, dymu, ogniska, szynki, oscypka, suszonych owocÃ³w, Å›liwek, spalonych kabli, sÅ‚odu, karmelu. Smak wÄ™dzony, dymny, suszonych owocÃ³w, kompotu z suszek, sÅ‚odowy, karmelowy, ciemnego chleba, ciasta, oscypka.

Keg @ CK. deep reddish brown with a small head. Nose is deep rich smoked ham. Slightly medicinal herbs. Toffee. Flavor is the same. Very smoky with a clean slightly bready finish. Some grain. Light body, soft carb. Eminently drinkable. Nice.
UPDATED: DEC 22, 2014 500ml bottle. Pours deep, dark brown with white head that quickly disappeared. Sweet smoky aroma, taste is toffee with hints of bacon and smoke. Tart, bitter aftertaste

Bottle at Bierstube in Philly. Clear dark chestnut pour with a weak off-white head. Bottle is likely towards a year old. Dark woody caramel malts. Good amount of smoke in the mix. Both well burnt and strangely juicy. Coffee, cocoa and roasted nuts. Dark rye bread. This bottle started out way too cold and took a lot of warming to bring out the deeper flavors. Ends up being richly complex. Ultimately (to me) feels like a milder version of the Mikkeler Weasel which (again to me) is one of the greatest dark beers in existence!
UPDATED: NOV 4, 2015 Tap. Brownish head, some lace. Red black. Smoky, roasted malts, sweetness and bitterness in good balance. Strong and smooth.-- rated with beerbasher/winphone

Aroma: roasted notes, intensive smoked notes.
Appearance: clear brown color, nice beige head.
Taste: low bitterness, intensive smoked notes, some sweetness, roasted malts, roasted caramel.
Palate: medium body and medium carbonation, roasted finish.
Overall: An icon in this style, recommended.

Bonfire night beer. Bottle from beersofeurope. Ruby brown beer with medium foam head and good lacing. Aroma of smoked sausage and bavarian cheese. Taste is smoked sausage, dry malts, smoked oak and bacon. Medium bodied. Excellent beer.
user_location: West Bromwich (Yorkshire Expat), West Midlands, ENGLAND

text: Pours a lovely dark amber with a distinct dark ruby cast that is slightly darker than their Marzen variant . Good head, lacing and retention. Outstanding nose of meaty bacon like smoke against an underlying dark fruit (plum, fig) note over a slightly sweet base. Medium body with a creamy slick texture. Normal carbonation with a bit of effervescence on the finish. Compared to their Marzen variant, Urbock has slightly less head characteristics, slightly more carbonation and more body and texture. The superb flavor profile is even more outstanding in that it obtains a higher degree of balance by being slightly sweeter and coats the tongue with a slick layer of bacon like smoke. The flavor profile is a masterpiece of intensity, balance and complexity. The delicious smoke character is always present, but never overpowering. It begins with a campfire bacon like smoke over a moderately sweet background that has dark fruit characteristics. The middle allows the hops to impart a low level bitterness that has a citric note as it effervesces. The finish is less dry than the Marzen, somewhat crisp, slightly sweet and leaves you with a touch of dark fruit and a lingering smokiness as if youÂ’ve sitting around a campfire. World Class and ever so slightly better than the Marzen variant.

Pours amber/brownish with a thick beige head. Aroma is very smoky. Bacon, caramel, honey, sugar... Particular smell. Reminds me of the better breakfasts. Gets me hungry. Taste is much in line with the aroma. Strong smoky taste, bit like the smoked sausages or the Â’palingÂ’ we have here in The Netherlands. However, the smoke indeed gets less in your face after a while, which creates room for the other flavors that this beer encompasses... Clear taste of the caramel as well, sugars, some dark chocolate, bit of wood, some fruits as well... Bit bitterish in the end. Astonishingly good actually. Really tasty. I like this. Smooth mouthfeel, creamy, soft carbonation... DidnÂ’t know what to expect after hearing about this smoked beer. But IÂ’m glad that I haven given it a shot. Wonderful rich beer. Meaty, sweetish, full beer, that would do fine with some nice pork chops. Great, great, great brew.

500 ml bottle. Lovely ruby red color topped by a thick rocky beige head with clinging lace. Wonderful smoky malt aroma reminiscent of a woodsy campfire. Upfront their are notes of bittersweet chocolate, charred wood and burnt raisins. Mid taste brings dark sweet caramel and smoked malt. This is a complex brew that drinks smoothly. Bitter hoppy finish complements the smokiness nicely. Wow, this is a classic and certainly the best smoked beer I have ever had. A must have.

Think lagers are boring? Try this one. Aecht specializes in smoked beers. This Urbock has a nice creamy white head with some lacing. Color is very dark ruby/brown. The aroma is one of smoked bacon, some maple, caramel. The taste is smoked malts, very little hop profile is very slight, but present.This is Urbock and has some of those tastes to it, caramel, little toffee, but the smoked flavor just amps it up about 3 notches.Drinking this makes me feel like I am Germany. I could drink a ton of this stuff. Experience it, even if you donÂ’t like Oktoberfest beers.

Smells of wood smoke and banana and light tobacco. Pours a dark translucent Brown with fine tan head. Tastes of smoke, molasses, savory licorice, banana, and more smoke. All this with a short sharp bitter finish. Surprisingly syrupy in the mouth feels rich and smooth. Really delicious.

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2014 500ml bottle poured in a dimpled pint mug.
A: Pours a deep dark amber to brown color forming a medium beige head. Medium to low retention and lots of lacings left
S: Very particular. Very smoky as expected. Bacon. Roasted malts, honey, brown sugar
T: As the nose, very roasted and smoky. Bacon, honey, roasted malts, smoked wood. Sweet candy/brown sugar upfront. Sweeter than the Marzen version. End is roasted bitterness
M: Medium and molasses body. Medium carbonation. Roasted bitter aftertaste
O: Excellent beer, excellent drinkability. The best Rauchbier ever! :)
[ BA Review @ 4/21/2012 ]

Bottle from MuckeyÂ’s. Poured into a tall lager glass. A very good looking dark ruby brown with a thick tan head. Aroma is very smoky with layers of malt too.. Flavor is smooth and malty with layers of smoke. Good balance. Lingering dark sweetness.

Endlich waren wir also vor Ort in diesem Rauchbier-Mysterium und leider Gottes hat es sich wie erwartet in etwa so entwickelt wie befuerchtet. Ein Bier, das zuvorderst natuerlich nach Rauchschinken oder Rauchlachs zieht, doch daran gewoehnt man sich recht fix. Schlimmer ist jedoch das laffe Innenleben, das dazu irgendwie abrupt und unerwartet bitter abschliesst. Mit mildem Ausgang waere auch ich milde gestimmt gewesen, doch so ist das hier nix.

On tap at their brewpub in Bamberg. The beer pours out in a deep black colour with steady head and medium body. Aroma of campfire and woods. Taste of campfire, woods, smoked ham, smoke, peat and torf. Earthy finish. Drinkable.
Bottle. Brown, rocky head, tan foam, medium bitterness, light sweetness, medium body, medium body, average carbonation, oily feel, & bitter finish.

Dark brown color. Aroma is, well, smoke...duh...a wood smokiness. Taste is strong smoke at first, but after a few sips the smoke becomes less in your face. Sweet, malty, thin-to-medium mouthfeel. Very enjoyable beer, though not the kind I want to drink often.
"thanks John - this was an exquisite beer. the smoke is anything but subtle, more aggressive than i was expecting, but not overpowering. rich malty tones and a super smooth finish. love it!"

Enjoyed fresh on [emailÂ protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */, 12/2013, bottled 2014 and aged (1yr, bb10/2014). Gorgeous ruby-edged jet black with thick, pillowy beige crown. Delicately sweet and peated aroma of vaporised, smoke-charred BBQ ribs on a fir bonfire: the perfume version. On draught the nose is rich, dense, dry yet caramalty, bottled some oak shines through, whereas aged it is all oak, branches, earth. Taste draught: harmoniously rich and creamy, a meaty, caramelised marshmellow. Bottled slightly slimmer in body, with more tannins and twig-like wood components shining through over a bockish sugarbelly. Stellar when fresh and on tap in season, impressive and still sessionable bottled.

Aroma of beef jerky, bacon, roasted cereal grains. Appears clear reddish dark brown, minimal pale caramel foam. Tastes of roasted malted barley, some caramel, sweet and mostly bitter. Overall, great aroma, good.
Bottle. Dark black purple. Thin. Strong woodsmoke/bonfire nose. Tastes of smoke blended with a sweet malt character--almost sugary.
Idealne piwo dla kogoÅ› kto chciaÅ‚by sprÃ³bowaÄ‡ piwa wÄ™dzonego. Wyznacznik stylu. DuÅ¼o kieÅ‚basy.

500 ml bottle. Super gusher - minus one point. Pours a red mahogany with light head and lots of suspended sediment. Strong aromas of smoked bacon. Strong flavors of hickory smoke, sweet malts, liquorice and sweet dark fruit. Balanced for a smoky but overly smoked for something sensible.

Transfer from BA review on 5-25-13-

 Poured from bottle into a pint glass

 Appearance Â– The beer pours a color brownish copper color with some light ruby highlights seen shinning through. Upon pouring there is a two finger tan colored head that has a about a 3 min retention time before fading and leaving some light lacing on the sides of the glass.

 Smell Â– Big on the smoke and the char with some undertones of brown bread and caramel. There are also aromas of char and some meaty smells mixed within giving it a nice campfire like aroma.

 Taste Â– The taste of some darker malts as well as a nice strong smokiness are initially present upfront. Some lighter dark fruit flavors mix with these giving it a moderately taste. The sweetness intensifies a bit as some flavors of caramel come to the tongue. A salty flavor joins the mix more toward the end while the beadier and malty flavors begin to fade. IN the end with the smokiness increasing slightly, a cured but moderately sweet smoked taste is left on the tongue.

 Mouthfeel Â– The body of the beer is on the average to just above average side in terms of its thickness with a carbonation level that is overall rather average, both suiting well the blend of smoky and sweet.

 Overall Â– Lightly sweetened BBQ taste in a glass here. Roasted, smoked with a bit of char, sweet and delicious.

Aroma is very smokey like a campfire. Hints of hickory, peperoni, light spiciness and rich malts. The taste is rich caramel and almost chewy malts. A well balanced bitterness is found here finishes smoothly. The smokiness definitely lasts to finish but that is a good thing.
WOW!!! The best way of describing this beer for me would be when you are near a bonfire and you smell your cloths when you get home. Amazing smokey smell and flavor with hints of bacon

Clear copper, tan head. Nose is woody, malty, clean, not too heavily smoked. Flavour is more wood, slightly charred but not into rubber territory. I often get toothpaste flavours when drinking these rauchbiers I really should stop brushing my teeth with spent kindling. Yeah the malt and smoke is complimentary. Nice experience.
Bottle. Cola color with a 1 finger khaki head. Aroma is campfire, bacon and burnt sugar. Taste follows but has an underlying banana note. Rich creamy mouthfeel with relatively strong carb. Awesome.

From a bottle at 28 Springs. Pours a rush dark brown with one finger of tan head. Aroma is smokey burnt slight malt. Flavor has caramel and smokey peaty malt. I'm not a fan of the style but this was still nice. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2014 Bouteille. Une robe brune acajou avec une Ã©paisse couche de mousse. Un nez rappelant les moules fumÃ©es en conserve mais rien de dÃ©sagrÃ©able. Une bouche soyeuse de fumÃ©e noble. Facile Ã  boire. (dec 2014 aussi)

Cette biÃ¨re est brune acajou. La mousse a deux pouces dÂ’Ã©paisseur. Elle est rÃ©sistante et laisse quelques traces derriÃ¨re son passage. Son nez est bien fumÃ© et complexe. Les malts doux sÂ’y intÃ¨grent parfaitement. Outre le caramel, je peux sentir du cuir et des fruits foncÃ©s. Une touche de noix grillÃ©es semble sÂ’avancer vers mes narines. En bouche, lÂ’expÃ©rience Schlenkerla est toujours aussi ravissante. Beaucoup de bois qui fume et une reprÃ©sentation cÃ©rÃ©aliÃ¨re profonde. En bouche, un corps bien menÃ© avec un pÃ©tillement intelligent et une texture crÃ©meuse. En finale, lÂ’amertume, les malts et la fumÃ©e jouent des notes harmonieuses et franchement plaisantes. Chic.

Pour dark amber with large off-white head. Aroma is rich wood smoke and a bit of sugar. Mouth-feel is light and creamy. Taste is blast of smoky sweet malt and bitter chocolate. Very different but it grew on me with each sip. At the finish, the smoke cleared and left a pleasant roasty sweetness. Marvelous!

Bottle. Purple cola. Campfire smoky aroma. The taste follows suit and really emphasizes the smoke, adding bacon. This is a big huge brew. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Taster at Aces and Ales. Pours mahoghany with an off white head. Smells like a forest fire, very smoky, charred. Taste starts with watery caramel that is quickly overrun by tons of smoke. Liquid bbq.

2011 backlog. Pours clear dark brown with a2 finger off white head that left nice lacing. The nose is roasted malt, ham, caramel and bacon. The taste is not as smoky as the nose surprisingly. Dark fruits, light roast, smoked meat. Medium mouth feel. Tasty. 3.8

Couleur cuivrÃ©e sombre , trÃ¨s belle mousse blanche. Super nez fumÃ© boisÃ© , et malt grillÃ©. Gout malt grillÃ© avec super fin de fumÃ© boisÃ©, notes douces sucrÃ©es. Super balancÃ©e. Bien douce en bouche. Super! top smoked!

Bottle sample at a tasting at Beer Market Jaffa. Thanks Vova. Very dark brown and a little clear. nutty, fully hickory smoke aroma, smooth, smoky, sweetish taste. Smooth, hardly any carbonation, full body and hints of bitterness in the finish.

Apparently the winter version in this fascinating series, again with the Bamberg smoked malt. Pale beige, creamy, sticky foam, colour an opaque brown with a copper hue, only visible under bright light; nose gets the same wave of smoked meat and charcoal as in the better-known MÃ¤rzen version, but this time it gets more, as hints of bitter chocolate, liquorice and caramel shine through. The taste is even more surprising, as the caramel- and chocolate-like malty sweetishness dominates the first sip, only to be abruptly broken by the salty, bone-dry smokiness which lingers on till deep in the finish, which also reveals some spicy hops. Actually quite complex, especially for a lager, and in that respect perhaps even more rewarding than the classic MÃ¤rzen version.

500mL bottle, pours a dark amber brown with a small beige head. Nose is malty and smoky, with lots of dry caramel malt, lots of smoke but no ashtray. Flavour is exactly the same, with everything acting in total harmony. One of the most complex smoked beers IÂ’ve had. Excellent.

Poured from a 500 mL bottle. Clear dark brown with persistent toffee head. Good lacing. Aroma is smoked barbecue jerky and dark malts. Flavour is smoked hickory and burnt malts. Interesting smoked beer.

Bottle (500 ml). Dark brown with reddish reflects, medium beige head and good lacing. Aroma is quite smokey but as always with Schlenkerla itÂ’s deep and well intagrated. In this one, itÂ’s similar to Gouda cheese. ThereÂ’s also caramel, malt sweetness and dark fruits notes. Taste is also of smoke but it leaves enough place for the malt, caramel and dark fruits to express. Light wooden notes too. Medium body. Moderate carbonation. Slightly oily mouthfeel, somewhat creamy too. Gentle medium lasting smokey aftertaste. One of the best Smoked beer IÂ’ve tried so far. Impressive balance and drinkability. This isnÂ’t just plain smoke, itÂ’s quite complex and really tasty. I love Schlenkerla!

pours medium dark brown mahogany with a reviving and slightly creamy light beige head, nice lacing. rich beech-smoked and browned caramel and specialty malts, very woody and fairly tannic, red fruitiness, but also dried lightly sweetened dates, figs and prunes, caramelized nuts, some sweetness - brown sugar, few phenolic esters - much welcomed here; grassy, peppery, minerals. moderate carbonation, light to medium body - oily, bittersweet very grassy-peppery and assertively tannic woody finish. woody more than woodsy. tasty. good.

Bottle at home from backlog notes 07. Pours a clear reddish amber brown color with a medium sized beige head. The aroma and flavor have smoked meats, campfire, charred wood, just plenty of smoked character. One of my earliest smoked beer experiences and still one of the standards.

Pours a medium brown with a small offwhite head that leaves pretty lacing. Nose is of intense smoke, like at the fish smokers, over a caramel syrup background. There is also a light fruity character to it. Taste is sweet but way less than its doppel sibling, moderately bitter. Flavors of smoke once again and some sweet syrup. Finish is just smoky, completing the experience. Body is medium, carbonation more than sufficient (once again an improvement from the doppelbock to me) and lightly sticky. Pretty authentic and fun, I need to go down there some day to sample it from the cask!

Smells of pine and campfires. Color is a deep red with an off white head. Good retention. Taste is much like the smell, pine, ash, campfires. Lingers for a few moments on the palate. A good representation of the smoked style.
Clear brown, small offwhite head. Strong, meaty and smoky aroma. Flavour has malt, smoke, a little sour towards the finish.

A darkbrown / dark red beer with quite a firm layer of somewhat brown foam. A nice smoked aroma which reminds me of smoked salmon. This goes on into the taste, accompanied by something which resembles some sort of licorice or other sweetness. The aftertaste is subtile bitter, and hangs around for a while. 

Een donkerbruin, donkerrrood bier met een vrij stevige kraag, lichtbruin van kleur. Een lekker rokerig aroma dat doen denken aan gerookte zalm. Dit gaat zeker in de smaak mee, maar samen met iets dat lijkt op drop. Subtiele bittere nasmaak die even blijft hangen.

Bottle: Served in a Stein:
Medium sized thick, slowly changing, creamy beige head on top of a dark ruby colored beer.
Aromas of smoke, leather, fireplace, malts, dried leaves, a hint of something coal alike.
Flavours of light smoke, bitters, malts, some flowers, some herbs, smoked herbs, some wood, grains, some toast, nuts and a leather sprinkle...
Aftertaste is bitter, light smokey, some malts and some sweet leaves.
Low carbo, creamy mouthfeel and texture and a body between medium and fuller.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Sample at Julios (from bottle). Pours a reddish brown. Very complex flavors with the most obvious being smoke and oak but there is alot more going on with this. Truly one of the great smoked beers out there.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Beer Market Jaffa. Thanks Vova. Pours brown to red clear with a beige head, aroma of wood smokiness, smoked fish, smoke and roasted tones, flavor is smoked with smoked fish, sweet and tasty, medium bodied.

Pours a glowing ruby brown with a fair khaki head that settles to a thicker film and leaves touches of spotty lace. Nose is super cool: dry hickory wood smoke, underlying molasses and dark fruit sweetness, some hay, but mostly just campfire bold smoke and savory qualities. Fairly sweet, decently bitter. Fuller side of medium bodied, fair carb action, a bit oily and slippery, with a lingering smoky exit. Fabulous brew, canÂ’t wait to see how my pulled pork turns out with it.

At a tasting, thanks Vova, smallish head, quite clear, darkish brown colour, aroma of smoke, barbecue sauce, grilled flavour snack a,d a hint of caramel, flavour of smoked meat, charred wood and some dried fruits, mellow bitterness. Really nice and highly enjoyable.
Bottle. Aroma is intensely smoky, but showing honeyish, caramel maltiness. Clear deep ruby-brown colour. Taste is nicely malty in addition to the smoke. Caramel. Very good.

Flasa. Extremne tmavo bordova farba, kremova hneda farba velmi dlho drzala. Vona velmi pekna, sladova, prazeny slad. V chuti opat sladovost, travnatost, udene tony. Pivo so strednym telom a nasytenostou. Velmi pekne vyvazene pivo, ktore ma prekvapuje kazdym duskom napitia.

Rouge trÃ¨s foncer avec une mousse moyenne marron. LÂ’arÃ´me du fumÃ© (comme un feu du camp, mais dans un sens positive!) et de la viande fumÃ©. Le goÃ»t est dÂ’abord du malt un peu sucrÃ©, puis du fumÃ© terreux, comme du bois, avec une finition trÃ¨s peu amer. TrÃ¨s bonne et assez facile Ã  boire.

Poured from bottle into snifter: Pours dark brown with a foamy tan head, no lacing. Aroma of smoked, roasted malts, maybe a little nutty but the smoke definitely dominates. Taste is mildly sweet malt flavor, a little earthy, and lots of smoke. I mean lots, but it somehow isnÂ’t overwhelming. Medium body, nice carbonation, really peaks when it warms up a bit. This is one of the best rauchbiers IÂ’ve ever had.
From a bottle. Quite smoky, with a strange fishy metallic note. Tasty, though.

500ml bottle - pours a medium/dark brown ,light tan head . Great lacing . Big smokey bacon aromas . Smooth palate . Sweet smoke flavors . Possibly my favorite rauch .

BOTTLE 50CL.

Look: clear dark red-brown, beige frothy head.
Aroma: very intense, smoked, smoked prunes, black olives, rich. 
Taste: smoked, light sweet rich taste. Intense brew, smokiness is nicely balanced by rich malty body, unlike in their basic Marzen.

Of all of the SchlenkerlaÂ’s, this is my favorite, closest to the "bacon" experience. Smoked malts rule in this beer, dark and nutty, lots of the cured meat, smoky taste of hickory bacon. An acquired taste for sure, but a must try.
Pure smooth smoke and bacon. This was So tasty and interesting. There was no roughness to this beer like already stated pure silky smooth smoke and bacon from start to Finnish.

Clear brick red with a massive head. Good carbonation.

Aroma is bacon and wood smoke. Followed by a surprisingly crisp, light malt. ItÂ’s biscuity and bready after a heavy dose of campfire. Agitating it lets the sweetness really break out.

The aroma has the same familiar elements: first the smoke, then a sweet, lagery malt, and then more smoke on the back of the tongue. Just great.

The feel is smooth but not slick, substantial but not thick, dry but not ashy. I would say drink about half a bottle, or have it as a shot with my bacon and eggs.

.5L bottle into wrong glassware because youÂ’re not doing the dishes. Nose is, "ew, this smells like a fire" per my wife. I understand how the finish may be a turn off, but over all this is pretty darn good. ItÂ’s as though a lager is screaming in desperation to get help behind locked doors. Drink only if you like smoke.
Ins Glas ergieÃŸt sich ein dunkel rÃ¶tlichbraunes Bier mit schÃ¶ner Schaumkrone. Geruch intensiv rauchig, Schinken, leicht rÃ¶stmalzig. Geschmack rauchig, wÃ¼rzig, gerÃ¤ucherter Schinken, klasse!

50cl bottle @home. Pours dark brown with an off-white, creamy head. Overwhelming smoked aroma, bit like bacon. Taste is bacon, caramel, bit sweet, smoked but not as dominating as the aroma would suspect. Actually an interesting beer, not bad at all.

UPDATED: JUL 19, 2014 500cl bottle poured into a Delirium Tremens glass. Pours an almost black liquid with a foamy off white head. Taste is malt and sweetness. The smoke is not too evident to start but once swallowed there is little else coming through other than smoke. Very much an acquired taste but one that I havenÂ’t got. Very good for its style but just a little too heavy going but glad I tried it.

Aroma and flavours of good quality English bacon and a dram of Laphroaig. Poor appearance, with not much of a decent head. I thought the Maerzen one was a bit thicker on the palate. Still, a great beer.
Bottle, 500 ml at Pivkan, Zagreb. Pours brown with brownish head. Smoke aroma and flavor. Malty caramel.

500ml bottle from Berlin Bier Shop. Probably the smokiest Schlenkerla with the biggest flavours, but even so itÂ’s blended so well with such a smooth mouthfeel that itÂ’s so easily drinkable. Smoky bacon dominates with a meaty juiciness, moderate bitterness and some ash and charcoal wafting about. Tastes like a meal in a glass. Great stuff!

Bottle. Creamy off-white good mostly lasting head. Dark red amber colour. Moderate malty and hoppy smoked aroma. Moderate bitter flavor. Some bacon notes. Average moderate bitter finish. OK balanced smoked. Oily palate.

Dark red/brown pour. Smells like roasted meat and campfire. Taste is all about the smoke with some nice malty goodness in the background. This is probably the smokiest beer IÂ’ve had to date. Delicious!
holy crap! smell is of smoked lox!! amazing!! smooth and smoky....malty more than anything...smooth like liquid smoked lox!! great! like no other beer!
From bottle. Dark red, almost black. Smokey, sweet smell. Taste is chalk, ash and roasted malt. Well balanced.

Bottle to tulip
Aroma of wood smoke, oak, malt, and something sweet, similar to but not exactly, syrup or caramel. Dark red, nearly brown, with a long lasting creamy off white head. Taste is smoke, oak, lots of sweet malt balanced with a little bitterness. ItÂ’s very thick and creamy with maybe a bit of chalkiness. Wonderful beer...very refreshing and quite rich.

Bottle from craft beer store Hamburg. Tamara carica, limpida con schiuma beige fine. Affumicato, caramello, cenere, malto e luppolo resinoso all aroma. Gusto dolce abboccato poco acida abbastanza amara da luppolo. Affumicatura intensa. Abbastanza calda, mediamente corposa appiccicosa e poco carbonata.equilibrata ed armonica
Bottle thnx to benzai. Dark brown color with a white head. Smells malts and smoked. Tastes smokey, sweet and dry. Mwa.

On tap at London Drinker festival 2014, Kings Cross, London. A dark brown coloured pour with a thin off white head on top. Smokey, soy sauce aroma. Tastes similar smoked bacon, malty, soy sauce, hint of dark fruit.

Bottle shared with Dutchdrebus, Joes and Martinus @ weekly tasting. Dark brown color with a deep dark red glare coming through when held into the light, average sized tan head. Aroma is malts and heavily smoked. Taste malts, smoke, some bitterness. Average to medium body and carbonation. Quite nice imo, and I usually donÂ’t like smoked beers at all.

Bottle @ benzai. Dark copper colour with a small to medium sized off-white head. Smells smoked, malts, hint of liquorice, ash. Tastes smoked, malts, some liquorice, ash, slightly tar. Thin to medium body, soft carbo.

Absolutely great! Dark brown and clear appearance, little tick foam. Aroma of dozens of notes: smoked cheese, bread, cooked bacon and grass. Mouth of bread, roasted malts, smoked cheese with a great bitterness cutting the previous notes in the final. Complex and very drinkable in the same time!

Great beer. It completely tastes like bacon, and smells like bbq sauce. Love it. Maybe has a too strong flavour to drink it with some food.

Smells like smoked pork -- brings back good memories of home. Only a hint of meat in the aftertaste; smoky flavors dominate, with a touch of hops. Pleasantly effervescent. Very good.
Heavy smoke flavors dominate this beer, tastes almost like bacon. Incredible beer, not quite as good as the Eiche but certainly close.

IÂ’ve had this take on a Â“smoke beerÂ” before. I donÂ’t remember much in the way of the nuances but I do remember enjoying it. I had it while defiling a womanÂ’s kitchen in Fairlawn, NJ. I was attempting to rewrite the physics books and fit 20oz of tomato bits and thick cream into a pot that had no business holding half that amount. I digressÂ… I found this beer again at the West Over Market in Arlington VA where every beer is gratuitously inflated. This didnÂ’t stop me. When I opened it the beers froth erupted from the top and only stopped when I poured it into my glass. The initial head is impressive albeit short lived. Aroma itself is a feast, a cornucopia of rich and malty aromas. This beer is robust. Bacon, campfire smoke laced with oak and maple make this a righteous beer to sip on. It reminds me of crisp winter nights sitting next to the fire pit till 4am. Versatile beer when it comes to food pairings. Optimal pairing would be with a glazed Cornish game hen and a significant other. Thoroughly impressed with this one.

UPDATED: APR 7, 2016 Reddish brown with a thin bubbly off white head. Very strong aroma of smoky maple bacon. Pure smoke up front, rich sweet malt, nuts and maple. Very little bitterness, almost no hop flavor. Medium body, heavier than I expected.
Extremely smokey. Pour is pitch black with no head. Aroma is smoke and burnt grains.

Great beer. Aroma is smoke, ham, sausages, youÂ’ll get hungry from it :) Pours clear amber with medium head. The beer is medium bodied, with low carbonation, so it is easy to drink. In taste you get great smoke combined with some malts and delicate hoppy bitterness.

Aroma - full bodied beechwood smoke
Appearance - body is cola colored, clean liquid, light white head that eventually settles to a thin covering of diffused bubbles
Taste - only can be described as a ham-like ~ ham-smoked and roast flavored brew
Palate - body is medium; texture is thick and sticky; carbonation is average; the finish is rich and full with what can only be described as a neatly BBQ-like smoke

If you like smoke, waste not anytime and get right to this. ItÂ’s really what you hope smoke can be. ItÂ’s like BBQ fire in a bottle.
(bottle) clear dark reddish amber colour with a small tan head; aroma of smoked fruit; smoke, jam; smooth well balanced flavour; slightly creamy palate
Bottle from Watson. Pours dark amber brown with almost no head. Aroma of delicious smoked meats. Taste of slightly sweet, mostly smokey.

Brune legerement claire a la lumiere, carbo moyenne, petit col fuyant.
Aromes tres marquÃ©s de malt fumÃ© et dans une moindre mesure de cafÃ©.
CÂ’est en bouche que le cafÃ© ressort plus meme sÂ’il est toujours moins presenet que le gout de fumÃ©. Corps moyen mais belle presence en bouche.
Aroma is caramel and smoke. Brown, clear, tan foam. Taste-light sweetness, lightly bitter. Medium body, soft carbonation, short finish.
Smoked malt and sweet character; Subtle caramel. A little medicinal aroma.  Thanks, Dallas...

Tap @ Mongoose vs Cobra. Dark brown with little head but I didnÂ’t see how it was drawn. Great depth in the smoky aroma, like meat roasting over a campfire. Taste adds malty sweetness. Bet this would make a wicked bbq sauce.

Very dark brown colour, medium beige and stable head. Very intensive aroma of smoked meat (bacon), caramely and roasty note. Taste is fully dominated by smokiness. I felt like being on barbecue party. Full body. Medium carbonation. Despite of strong smoky note, itÂ’s very taste and drinkable. Must to try!

Huge head, lasting long, almost black color, hints of ember. Aromas of smoked ham, campfire, malt, bread with hints of salt.
Taste is defined by its huge, warm smokiness. This goes along with burned malts, also toffee and pine. Even more intensive and sweeter than the "Schlenkerla MÃ¤rzen", but all in all quite similar, which is, in this case, not a bad thing. Smoked maltiness lingers on the tongue for a while, but not too intensive. Carbonation is well in balance with the overall medium-body, not too notable, adding up to a slightly too sweet and otherwise smooth mouthfeel.

Poured from bottle into glass stein. Pours a deep brown with just a slight cloud. Nice head, cream color to it. Nice lace. Many people say this has a pork aroma, and it does have a South Carolina pork place aroma I get something else. As a tea drinker I find it to smell exactly like Lapsang Souchong tea. Smoky taste, Lapsang Souchong tea, malt and yeast. Mouth feel was lighter than I expected, a little oily. I truly bought this to get a notch under smoked beer and ended up enjoying it.

From 0.5l bottle to the Teku glass . BBD: 14.2016 APP: Pours clear dark brown to black liquid. Medium beige head. AR: Very rich aroma. Smoked cheese, meat, sausages, alcohol. T: Very rich, beautiful taste. Medium sweet, medium to heavy bitter, light sour, bit salty. Meat, sausages, smoked cheese, roasted malts, dark chocolate, coffee, woody, pleasant bitterness with smoked tones in the aftertaste. PAL: full body, creamy texture, lively carbonation, long bitter finish. OV: Very good rich rauchbier, well combined tastes.

Keg at Earl of Essex, Islington. Pours dark with an off white head. Sweet, smoky, slightly soy sauce aroma, BBQ. Medium to full body, medium carbonation. Rich, meaty, a bit if teriyaki, smoky as can be. Still smooth and well balanced. Good.

Poured into a ceramic stein. Poured dark brown with a thin white lacing. The lid serves to lock in the smokey aroma and let it out in bursts. Oak? Taste reminds me of smoked bacon. Yum.

Bottle pour at Gourmet Haus Staudt in Redwood City, CA.
This is a campfire in a bottle and I love it immensely.

Deep brown with a red tint, with a white, thin, lacy lasting frothy head. Smells of pork bellies, malt, caramel and ash. Medium to bull body. Tastes of nice roast with with caramel, and finishes, malty fruity and a bit ashy,. Nice

Bottle courtesy of Zer0. Poured a clear dark brown with a thin whispy off white head. The aroma is super smoky malt leather and yeast. The flavour is medium to strong bitter with a smooth watery smoked hop bitter palate. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.

Bottle shared thanks to Zer0. Pours clear dark brown wig a small beige head. Aroma of smokey malts, bacon, leather, overripe dark fruits and soy. Flavor is moderate sweet and light moderate bitter. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.
Bottle shared. Pours hazy brown. Aroma is cigars, meaty, malys, leather, caramel and beef jerky. Taste is smooth. Less smokey than the nose. Moderate sweet. Medium to full bodied. Good stuff.
One of the best beers I have tasted. The smokeness is well applied, and there is a resemblance of a meaty taste. Appearance is OK, and palate is a bit mild.

500ml bottle, one very similar to the MÃ¤rzen, except of course now with the Urbock designation. A picky 6.5% ABV on this offering, at that. This beer pours a clear, dark caramel-tinted brown hue, with two fingers of lazily puffy, mildly creamy, and mostly bubbly true beige head, which leaves a bit of streaky remote islet lace around the glass as things slowly sink away. It smells of gamey smoked meat, bready smoked caramel malt, gritty smoked Gouda, generic campfire ash, and more isolated, well, smoke (the thesaurus having duly failed me here). The taste is still big and over the top smoky, sure, but now at least one can discern the caramel malt backbone and singed leafy hops amongst the still heady simmering bacon and infused cheese acridity. My mouth silently cries out for an ashtray. The carbonation is agreeably involved, but just enough to keep things lively and on the go, the body a somewhat tacky medium weight, and much more smooth than I might have proffered had I been asked at the onset of this affair. It finishes strangely off-dry, the now biscuity caramelized (and smoked, don't ever be forgettin' the smoke!) malt hanging tough, as does the lingering assaulted noble hops, all still under the yoke of the moderately overbearing smoky notes. Uber alles, this does seem to have a bit of a lighter, booze-lifted essence, that is at once reminiscent of Bocks and actively burning beechwood fires. Still, one hell of a sturdy, gritty, and of course eye and palate-watering smoky deal. Veritable truth in advertising, that cannot be denied, and if there was any homeland beer that Rammstein should hold close to heart, it would be this.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle - Rich dark malts, dark fruit and nice balanced smoke. Jet black with a creamy light brown head. Heavy dark malts, well balanced smoke and a nice thick mouthfeel. These guys can do no wrong in my book.

Bottle 50 cc, thank you Jeppe. Nice gesture and much apriciated. And hereÂ’s for something different. Lovely smoked meat smell. Reminds me off the Dutch Hema rookworst (a smoked sausage). Pours a dark redbrown with a small off-white/light brown head. Taste is a robust sweet smoky with just a hint of bitterness in the finish. Just a little carbonation.
Bottle. Brown with small tan head. Aroma of smoked malt and hints of caramel. Medium body with malt body upfront and a smokey finish.

Oh glorious beer! Blessed by the smoke that was a given - will it be enough to get me past my dislike for bocks? Thick sweet smoke reminiscent of a smoker filled with meat, zero wood hints, pan roasted carrots and yams hides. Great aroma that lacks complexity. Tasty smoke that cannot hide enough bock to make me love this. Odd roasted bitter over sweetness that I will never like (but like it here more than usual), I donÂ’t mind the harsh quality - still a really smooth soothing brew. A bolder brew than than the marzen but IÂ’d much rather put back a couple of litres of that instead.

Bottle. Dark brown with a medium sized diminishing beige head. Meaty salami smoke, light chalk, bark, wood, rye bread. Medium body, soft creamy texture, soft carbonation. Medium malty sweetness, light bitterness. Lingering smoke. Very soft and pleasant.

Bottle. Pours clear dark brown with a small to medium off white head. Aroma has lots of smoke, mostly like smoked fish I guess with some bacon as well. Taste also has bacon and smoked fish with some malts. Medium body and carbo. Nice stuff.

Bottle 0.5l from P&M Bonn. Pours mahagony with off white head. Taste is smoked ham, roasted malt, burnt wood. Intense. Taste is light bitter, medium sweet, smoked ham, roasted malt, wood. Long lasting smokey aftertaste. Oily, full bodied beer. Perfect smoked beer.

500ml brown bottle. A deep red brown pour, creamy beige cap. Nose has smoky ham/meat. Taste has smoky and ham/meaty notes. Light bitterness at the end, then fairly dry. Medium bodied with prickly carbonation. Overall a smooth smoked bock, very pleased to have finally tried the Urbock after years of admiring the Marzen.

Sorry beer peeps, I just donÂ’t get the smoke beer-thing. Looked nice, a dark brown with a small head. Aroma was a sweet and potent smokiness. I gave it the benefit of the doubt as I really like smoked meats in general. Unfortunately, the smoke flavor was just too much for me. I definitely donÂ’t want it as part of my beer. I get that a lot of people might enjoy these, not me. Looked like a decent beer, mouthfeel was pleasant but that overpowering smokiness was just a killer.

Ruby red colour with minimal head on top. Lots of smoked goodness, sweet caramel and salty tar. Sweet caramel and toffee, then some oak and woody notes and then lots and lots of smoke. Medium body and smallish carbonation. Great smoked beer as always from Schlenkerla.
Tap @ konttori. Pours dark ruby red with a creamy beige head. Smoke malts bead in the aroma. Smith mouth feel. Smoky malty dark flavour.
Like the MÃ¤rzen, this is a fantastic beer. Slightly more complex and balanced perhaps, the smokiness less in your-face. Full bodied. Like the MÃ¤rzen: excellent.
Black with a reddish tint, almost no head. Smoked ham, tar, chocolate, caramel. Medium sweetness, very light bitterness. Nice and strong, prefer this to the MÃ¤rzen.
UPDATED: FEB 20, 2014 Nulla da eccepire Ã¨ davvero un grandissimo bere, fantastica ne berrei a cariolate, non mi stanca mai...
This one is smoked from Beech Tree wood hence the world famous taste. The Oak smoked version ( green label ) is even more smooth and an absolute wonder in the world of smoked beers.

0,5 l bottle BB 05/14 
red-brown color, clear, stable tan foam
alcohol, smoke, woody, roasty, toast, herbs, earthy, leather, light sweetness, salty, full body, thick feel, sticky, oily feel, soft carbonation, very long finish,

Deep brown colour with a small beige head. Smokey aroma/taste. Dark malts, caramel, hops, wood, chocolate, some spice. Nice smooth mouthfeel. Great beer.
UPDATED: FEB 28, 2017 Evergreen classic from the Teutonic brothers. Great smoky aroma of home-roasted ham. Medium body with a hint of caramel and melanoidin. Smoke, smoke everywhere. Great.

500ml bottle. Clear, ruby red glowing, dark brown colour with average to huge, firm, frothy, fairly lasting, moderately lacing, beige head. Intense smoke aroma, notes of ham, smoked eel etc., ashes, campfire. Taste is dry, smoky, moderate subtle sweetness, wood notes, hints of tar. Excellent, as we all know.

UPDATED: APR 7, 2016 Really intense smokiness. This one is very similar to the Marzen classic, but I prefer it because it has a more complex taste. Underneath a sweet, slightly chocolate flavored brew. Thin and not a big bodied beer at all, but huge on taste. Not bitter, with a long lingering finish like the smoky smell on clothes the day after hanging around a campfire.  While it is still extra smokey I can taste a bit more of the oakwood and it was a bit more smooth. A little less sticky than the Marzen. She?s a big one and not for the Rauchbier faint of heart, but well worth a try. Good stuff.

Great smokey taste. Appearance is good as well as the nose. There is a good amount of smoke on the nose. Great beer overall.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours a deep brown with garnet highlights and a large-grained, cream/cinnamon head. Nose is smoked meat/charcuterie, spice, brown sugar, and molasses notes; smells exactly like KlemmÂ’s, a German smokehaus I used to frequent (and love) when I lived in Indianapolis. I miss smoked braunschweiger, with a little hot mustard...anyway. Back to the beer. And rye bread. Real rye bread, not this boring stuff you get...right. Beer. Um. Smoky, smooth, round, substantial -- it would go amazingly with a smoked braunschweiger sandwich. I wonder if KlemmÂ’s delivers? Ships? I wonder if anyone I know back in Indy would ship me some? This is a damned good beer. WhereÂ’s the mustard?
16.9 oz bottle to snifter (shared with the Mrs.). Looks solid; cola with thin very light beige lacing. Smells and tastes of dark malt and smoke with an average mouthfeel. Solid beer.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2014 500 ml bottle
Reddish brown clear beer with some blonde head disappearing quite fast leaving a thin layer on the beer. Aroma and flavor have sweet malts, tar and some smoked ham. Thicker than medium, soft and slick, quite carbonated. Aftertaste adds some herbal bitterness. Not as mind-blowing as many people say, but still enjoyable.

Reddish black colour, beige head. Aroma of bacon, wood fire, lots of smoky Bacon. Light sweet flavour, smoke, Schwarzwalder Schinken. Thick, almost oily body. Finish bacon and smoky malts. Nice!(from 50cL bottle, courtesy of RM, thanks!)
Malty, smokey, rich and smooth. Brownish amber with a thin tannish brown head. Woody, earthy, with hints of spice, all wrapped in the smokey malt. Interesting.

On tap at Fermentoren, October 2013.

Dark brown with a medium head, A lot of malt and smoke both in the aroma and taste. Also sausage, salt and ham. The finish was long. Really a great Smoked beer, a big one!
Nice clody dark color... Amazing aroma of smoke and bacon... Tastes like real ham, perfect... Even better than the standard smoke beer...

On tap@Â’In de WildemanÂ’, Amsterdam. Head: beige foam. Colour: clear, ruby brown. Aroma: smoked ham. Taste: bitter-sweet, smoked ham. Palate: smooth, full body, long bitter-sweet finish, low CO2. Overall: very good

Followed up this beer with the Dopplebock (8%) and loved this almost as much. (See my review for the Dopplebock). IÂ’ll add that after a second smoke beer it is overwhelming on the palate because it is so rich but I love the Rauchbiers since trying my first Schlenkerla Marzen twenty or so years ago.
Poured reddish brown with a huge off white head. Aroma of huge roast malt. Medium body, flavour is sweetly rauched malt, underlying berries. Dry, refreshing finish.

Sweet malts, caramel, slight hops, charcoal, smokey, woody, dark chocolate. Very good.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2014 Bottle: deep brown with some dark ruby outlines; slightly gray & tan head mellows out quickly as leaves a little bit of lacing behind. Aroma is wonderful... Smoked malts, wall to wall. Smokey wood chips, burnt barley, campfire, and mild meat & sausage notes. Light malty sweetness underneath. Taste is very similar - mellow sweet smoke, wood chips, campfire charcoal, smoked sausage... Wonderfully balance with some malt showing underneath. Light caramel & yest flavors lie beneath. Smokey, semi-sweet finish with a thick & creamy body. This is a delicious smoked beer, simple as that. Great, all around.

Bottle given from my boss (nice guy) and poured into a snifter. Clear dark ruby body with soft, tan head that laces well. Upon opening the cap, there is a unique, smoked cheese aroma with a note of rhubarb. This earthy beer is malt-driven with notes of anise, licorice and minerals. Excellent.

Pours dark brown with a hint of amber and a rapidly fading off-white head. Aroma is smoked meats and malt. Taste is smoky campfire wood, tar, cured meats and a touch of darkfruit with a bitter hop finish. Very smooth. Low carbonation. I prefer a few of the other rauchs.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

500 ml bottle. Pours dark brown with a big frothy head that fades very slowly and leaves nice lacing. Aromas are smoked ham, bacon, burnt wood, and light fruitiness. Taste is obviously smokey but not overpowering. Reminds me of a campfire. ThereÂ’s a nice light sweetness and cured meat flavor that bring it all together. Very smooth, creamy finish. Medium body. Very nice smoked beer.
March 2010. 500 ml. bottle. Pours red brown with a tan head. Probably the best of the line-up. Caramel, malt, fruit and smoke aromas. This is liquid gold.

Just listening to the beer guru down on the corner going on about how unique German smoked beers are. There is true wood smoke coming off here, not the barbeque or cask scents found in some strong American ales. The urbock here compliments that with an earthy, peaty background. Brown cola like appearance, fizzy for last yearÂ’s bock. Bittersweet taste with smokey notes playing intermittently. Not horrifically smoked, maybe rates 6 of 10 on this scale. Silky smooth body, not so filling as expected.
Deep chestnut brown, thin off-white head, minimal lacing. Smoke, earth, caramel. Medium bodied, gentle carbonation, lingering smokey finish.
This is best described as the bock version of the traditional rauchbier. ThatÂ’s what it is, a German bock beer with an intense taste of smoke.

This is near perfection! Aroma and taste is smoke, tar, smoked ham, some sweetness, sausage and more tar. 
Full bodied with almost perfect mouthfeel.
This is THE BEER for me. 
Urbock was also my gateway to Islay single malts. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A: dark brown, brown head
S: smoky, bacon, malts
T: light smoke, malts
M: medium-full body, creamy

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On draught at saraveza fire and brimstone - pours cloudy amber color with small off white head. Nose of molasses, smoke, and malt. Taste is of sweet malt and yeast balanced out by smoke. Pretty smooth beverage.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Deep brown with red hues. Aroma of campfire, smoked meat, and light, fruity Munich malt. Flavor is light Munich malt that gives way to moderate, gentle, salty smoke and BBQ. Mild ash. Low on the plastic flavors you can get with smoked beers. Residual smoke, ash, and fruity malt. Full lager mouthfeel. Nice.

Bottle to goblet. Initial aroma of sweet malt follow by campfire and smoked salmon. Deep, deep copper almost porter colored pour. A bit light on the palate, taste follow suit with the nose. There are definitely some sweet malt notes up front, followed by a mellow smoky goodness. Nothing overpowering, just a classic Rauch!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours dark brown almost black with a lasting tan head. Aroma of smoke of which you would expect. Very complex taste of malt and smoke with an almost velvety feel. The aging is evident by the rich malty taste. Nice smokey finish. I love how this brewery only has a few offerings that have survived the test of time. Unlike most American Breweries that seem to have to "create" something new every few months to survive. I waited 25 years for this beer to come to Texas and drove 128 miles round trip to purchase it. Too bad only 2 were left on the shelf or I would have cleaned out the house.

Appropriately strong smoky aroma. Oak, like a burnt wood, burnt amber. I was thinking of a pig.. campfire.
tastes very smoky but smooth. burnt wood, a little ham/sausage. a little sweet, very smooth, complex, drinkable.

Beautiful rubyish mahogany. Medium tan head, partially lasting. Aroma is pleasantly but quite strongly smoked balanced by some sweeter malt, smoldering old wet wood, almost slightly sausage like, campfire. Flavor is much the same. Complex. Smokey, some sweet, some sausageyness. Medium to light body. Soft. Finish is a very smooth balanced blend of everything.

Bottle from trade to glass. Aroma has slight smoke and caramel. Taste is very well balanced sweet malt and caramel up front balanced by hops and the smoke is at the end very unique and good beer
Draft sample at Flying Saucer Fort Worth. Big aroma and flavor of spicy, smokey barbecue and campfires. Classic.

1 pint 0.9 oz. bottle poured into a shaker- poured a heavily darkened brown with shades of mahogany when held to a light source, mildly foamy sunfaded tan head formed with several frog eyes upon the surface- and did lace upon the vessel to a degree. Aroma of smoke, smoked fish, smoked birch, black forest ham, and charcoal- you know, the good things in life. Hits the mouth with a medium body, the smoke just comes ROLLING in and doesnÂ’t let up from start to finish, malt is light but can still be detected, finish is mildly drying, lingering, and just a pinch of sweetness and nuts. JA!!!!
Dark brown-amber, clear, with a sudsy beige head. Aroma of smoked meat, wood, and caramel malt. It tastes like sweet caramel and barbecue. Medium bodied kind of oily.
Bottle. Pours very dark brown with off white head. Nose and taste of bacon fat, smoked malt, smoked cherry oak, smoked caramel and smoked chocolate malt. Medium body.

Defumada, amargor leve (malte torrado) inicial que persiste, aroma peculiar. CombinaÃ§Ã£o com speck.

Clear dark brown pour with red highlights when held to the light. Nice cream colored head. Aroma is smoky meat and char. Smoke is more tame in the flavor but still there. Has some sweetness and wood in the flavor as well. Soft on the palate.

Aroma is very smokey like bacon and a little peppery. It pours a very dark brown color with thin beige head. The taste is dominated by the smoke it starts sweet and gives way to some nice bitterness, the smokiness lingers on the palate for awhile. Probably one of the best smoked beers IÂ’ve ever had.

Delicious smoked beef jerky aroma. Flavor is peppery and sweet like good beef. Medium body. Only on the finish does a slight maltiness come in and then a strong bitterness letting you know this is beer. Very good smoked beer. Very good.

Pours dark ruby mahogany with a small beige head. Smells smoky and of sweet malts. Taste is smoky and amazing. Medium-bodied with a smooth, slick texture and soft mouth-carbonation, Aecht Schlenkerla Rauchbier Urbock finishes with a lingering smoke.
This is rauchbier. Smokey aroma and good color. Wonderful balance between first rate smokiness and subdued hopiness. Smoky finish with light hop nip. Excellent beer.

Aroma of smoked sauage or bacon. A translucent black pour with a small and short lived tan head with no lacing. The taste is much like the nose. Strong smoky flavor with notes of bandaid and some meatiness. Somewhat of a crisp hop-like finish with a bit of a grain noted in the smoke fill aftertaste. Medium body with medium carbonation. Overall, a great example of a smoked beer!
Deep brown, cream head. Smoke, BBQ, beef. Great palate, huge beefy smoke notes, tasty.
Aroma is very good, you can tell this is a rauchbier. Very good representative of the style. You can smell and taste the smokiness of this beer. A good finish. A wonderful beer.

Flaska frÃ¥n beernavigator. BB juni 2013 dvs nu. MahognyfÃ¤rgad, klar vÃ¤tska med cm-hÃ¶gt beige skum. Stor doft av frÃ¤mst charkuterier, men ocksÃ¥ toffee och sÃ¶t brÃ¶d. Bottle. Pours clear mahogany with a small creamy tan head and food lacing. Aroma is smoky, roasty, caramel. Flavor is quite smoky, plant, light sweet, a bit of astringence, no real bitterness. Nice flavor

Dark brown pour.  Tan moderate head that stays.  Smells like a sweet  smoked roast hot dog.  Tastes like smoked hot dogs.  Watery mouthfeel a little sweetness thickening it, but it finishes quite dry.  Wet hops flavor refreshing yet very hearty at the same time.  Impressive.

Pours dark reddish brown with off-white frothy head. Good lacing once settled. Aroma is oaky, smoked sausage, dark malt. Taste is nice and smokey, woody and meaty too, but a little sweet also. Finish is dry and the smoke really stays. Lovely smokebeer, quite a heavyweight too.

Red/dark brown beer with an offwhite head. Aroma is smoke, malts and wood. Taste is lots of smoke, sugar, bacon/porc, wood and a bit bbq/ashy.
Heavyheavy stuff...lots and lots of smoke.
Dark pour, tan head.  Nose is smoked meat and blackened malt.  Sweet.  Middle is burnt wood, roasted chocolate malt, and piney hops.  Finish is mellow but persistent wood smoke.  Really nice beer.
Sample at Hopfest 2013.  Comes reddish brown with a decent tan head.  Aroma of smoke, wood, and malt.  Taste is smoke, malt, smoked meat, and wood.  Great smoked beer!!
Red copper with an off white head.  Aroma smoky with a hint of smoked country ham. Taste is smoked malt. Has a littl saltiness. Dry mouthfeel.

Bottle at Sybarite Pig. Tulip. Pours dark brown, nearly opaque. Medium off-white head. Great lacing. Aroma of a campfire grilling hot dogs. The taste is the smokiest rauchbier IÂ’ve ever had. Wow! Serious smoked meat (cured sausages) is very dominant.

50cl bottle. Easy drinkable beer despite the smokeyness and the dark brown color. Body is thin and mauthfeel is dry. Lightly hoppy and smoky nose. Palate is pleasant with a strong smoked finish. Great beer for a summer BBQ!

If smoke is what you want this is where to get it. Very assertive smoked bacon/ham flavor. Smells like a BBQ, tastes the same. You either like Rachbiers or you don't. However the Marzen is much more balanced and enjoyable. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: JUN 15, 2013 Rating: 4/5 = Sex in my mouth - need I say more!!!. -This is an amazing beer!  Instant aroma of wood smoke upon pour.  Reminds me of a campfire just as the last embers are still ablaze.  Fluffy ivory head, almost creamy like raw milk.  Jet black liquid.  Tons of lacing.  Not quite smoked meat, but very strong and unique smoke quality.  Amazing sensations.  Slightly saltly upon kissing the tounge, but quickly faded.  Reminds me of a porter.  Zero smoke taste in my mouth.  Also zero hop bitter.  Creamy on the palate, just amazing.  Very clean taste.  Oddly - the finish reminds me of bacon (just a tad).  Again, this is an amazing beer, what an experience.  Wouldja - Hell Yes!!
Bottle->shaker.  Murky brown with tall offwhite head.  Aroma: smoke, bacon, wood, malt.  Taste: smoke, wood, bacon.  The quintessential rauchbier.

Jeg har lige smagt den pÃ¥ Die Kleiene Bierstube. Den var overraskende rÃ¸get af en urbock at vÃ¦re.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma: Smoked ham.
Appearance: Dark brown with ruby highlights. and a thin tan head.
Flavor: Medium sweetness, smoke and (I hate to say it) touch of hotdog.
Palate: Medium to full bodied, low carbonation.
Overall: A classic rauchbier dressed with bock parameters.

Half-litre bottle opened on its BBD (late Apr 2013) and poured (twice) into my Westmalle chalice.

You know what you are going to get from these guys, or at least you should.

This was everything I expected anyway: smokey and malty, with enough body and alcohol to sit back and enjoy, which I did.

Plenty of others have already pontificated long and hard about this fine brew, I agree with most of them (that scored it high and liked it).

Pours reddish brown with a moderate tan head that dissipates quickly.
The nose is liquid smoke and that is weird to me. IÂ’m not a fan of smoked beers, although I recognize that it would probably pair nicely with sausage or  other meats.
Flavor is reasonably balanced malty sweetness and hoppy bitterness.
Medium body, soft to average carbonation.
Overall, a little disappointing for me, given the high ratings, but I wouldnÂ’t turn one down.
A pleasantly malty sweetness that pours a ruby red color. This brew sports a rich smoke aroma and smokey flavor.  A good special occasion brew.

some real deal smoke beer. Color is a rusty red. Aroma is campfire with lots of dry wood. Taste takes on extra crispy bacon, even to the savory fatty part. Really a beer that any beer lover must try to understnad this special style.

16.9 oz. bottle- Pours very dark red with a one finger tan head that reduces  to a blanket and some lace. Aroma is smoke, ham, sweet sticky malt. The taste is more intense than the aroma, smoky campfire and roasted pig are on the menu, very tasty. Body is medium and carbonation is medium high. Overall I really liked it, the smokiness that I crave, and love.

16.9 oz bottle. Pours a deep mahogany with a collapsing beige head. Aroma is campfire smoky, bready malt, faint dark fruit. Taste is smoky and a little sweet (cotton candy); finishes a little bitter. Mouthfeel is creamy, body and carbonation medium. Delicious. Give me more!

Pours amberish, more brown; with a small white head which quickly dissipated.  Aroma is smoke, earthy, dark chocolate and woody.  Taste is roast bitters with some sweetness, lots of smokiness that is perfect and not overwhelming.  Drinks medium bodied with a dry finish.  Delicious.

Draught at Qbrick during Strong Beer Week. From notes. The characteristic Schlenkerla smokey aroma, unlike any other. Dark smoke and somewhat rude flavors. More stable feeling and serious than the regular smoked marzen. Great!

Bottle at home (March 9, 2013). Dark mahogany colour with red shades with a small creamy white head. Aroma has a lot of lovely smoked meat, like bacon.  Campfire notes coming through. There is also some soft caramel and nutty aroma on it.  In the beginning slightly bitter smoked malts. Milky caramel and smoked sausage. Later on some sweet coffee notes as well. Finishes bitter with a hint of peat and burned wood. Thick mouthfeel, a bit sticky and not much carbonation. Very well balanced rauch bier, quite refreshing dispite the rich and sweet taste.
As it says on the description, simply bigger than the classic MÃ¤rzen style. Smoky. Urbock. Simple. Great.
Oct 2012 - dark beer.  Initial flavours very good - rich smokiness.  No real bitterness.  Very drinkable and enjoyable.

Pours dark amber with half finger cream head- dissipates quickly.
Aroma- plum (slight tart- raspberry?) and smoked steak
Starts tart and slightly carbonated hops-like bite, beginning is only the slightest bit lacking. 
Body falls into deep smoke, then relaxes into plum and raspberry light tart finish. Gentle tart aftertaste with smoke undertone. 
Absolutely wonderful, paired with ribeye stake.

Pours a deep copper brown, in the nose lots of smoke, bacon & a bit of cheese. In the mouth the smokiness is still there, but its balanced by caramel malts and a bit of chocolate, also some berries and dried fruit, Very smooth.

Sampled at the W&C Ballas open house.  It poured a brown color with a  light tan head. The aroma was of smoke, some caramel and pale malts  and floral hops. The taste was similar, with lots of smoky bacon. Very decent.

Aecht Schlenkerla Rauchbier Urbock has a thin, off-white head and minimal lacing. The appearance is reddish-brown, and it would be clear, but for all of the pretty big gray chunks floating throughout. The aroma is of wood smoke, but maybe some underneath sweetness can be picked up. Taste is of smokey sweetness, maybe some dark fruit, and just a shade of alcohol. Mouthfeel is light and watery, and Aecht Schlenkerla Rauchbier Urbock finishes not too dry and smokey. If you like smoke youÂ’ll love it, but if you donÂ’t like smoke, youÂ’ll hate it. RJT

pours deep red wine-ish with (hmm?) browny beige top, medium, middle lacing. On nose it comes of course mild smoky, rye bread- roasty baked, nice, but simple. 
Taste is rye bread sweet and roasted bitter plus hopped bite, nice one. More reminds me of double bock.  A bit berries in flavour, malty profile overall, mild hops presence. Above medium body, bready-creamy texture. Nice brew but after "Eiche Doppelbock" this really seems like younger bro. So could be much "bettered" by conditioning for longer time ? No, its good enough :)

Bottled. Pours dark brown with a medium sized, creamy off-white head, leaving a fair lacing. Lovely aroma of smoke, wood and caramel notes. Sweet flavor that ends up quite dry and again with smoke and slightly bitter. Medium bodied, oily texture and soft CO2. A nice and markedly smoked. â˜…â˜…â˜…

Overwhelming aroma of wood fireplace at first, then a smoked sausage aroma. No visible head, and no lacing. Taste is very smoky. Cant really discern any other flavor. Lingers on the palate. Might work with the proper food pairing. Certainly not a drinkable beer in my opinion. Reviews please  bear in mind that smoked beer probably is not my favorite.

Bottle. Pours a dark but relatively clear brown with two fingers of tan head. Settles relatively quickly to thin cap. Moderate amounts of thin lacing. Aroma is smoky, beechwood, slight bacon. Flavor is smoky and sweet up front. Finishes with beechwood and malt tones. Smoky aftertaste that lingers. Soft carbonation and medium body. A smoky, tasty beer.

Pours a clear brown with good head and lacing.  Aromas of smoke and maple cured bacon with sweet malt also.   Smoke taste is more subdued in taste but still dominate.  Some roasted malt taste but not much else.  Light/ medium mouthfeel that finishes dry.  Not a fan of smoked beers but unlike the aroma, the smoke taste isn't too heavy. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dirty brown color no head. Huge smokey bacon smell with a very faint sweet malt in the distance. Taste is a surprisingly sweet malty with the smokey bacon after. Almost like a maple bacon. Can't say I care for smoke beers but I don't mind this one as much. Would be interesting to cook with. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

16.9oz bottle. Dark brown / red but clear color. Thin khaki head, with good lace. Smooth, crisp carbonation. Dry finish. Medium body. Great smokey nose, and even more smokey flavor. Toasty, smokey malt. Some light earthy hop. Very light hints of dark fruit and chocolate. Little bitter taste, savory with the smoke. Awesome, tasty, and (for me) drinkable stuff. IÂ’ve always loved AechtÂ’s doppelbock. This bock is probably my new second favorite from the brewery.

Red/brown colour, thick beige head. Aroma: dominant smoke (charred meat, bacon, camp-fire) notes, caramel, tar. Taste: a perfect balance of sweet, smoky and woody notes with roasted malts and toasted bread. Thick, creamy mouthfeel. Low carbonation. Dry, slightly astringent, finish. Complex and full of character. Marvellous.

I like this beer.  IÂ’ve had smokey beers IÂ’ve loved and those IÂ’ve hated.  Usually it depends on the intensity of the smokiness.  This is light, most of the smoke being in the nose and the finish.  Very nice dopplebock-like malt flavor, slight hop bitterness, but barely noticeable.  Nose is sweet malt and, of course smoke.  Medium-bodied mouth-feel.

(Tap) Bevuta al Deutsche Bierfest. Nel bicchiere bruna con riflessi rubino. Aroma subito caratterizzato da un affumicatura ben definita ma mai stucchevole. Arriva poi il sentore potente dellÂ’alcol, supportato dalle note di caramello e un leggera presenza tannica. In bocca subito corposa e abbastanza carbonata con una perfetta e superbilanciata affumicatura. Quest ultima lascia poi spazio alle note di caramello e alla potenza dellÂ’alcol. Birra incredibile, potente ma anche buonissima.
UPDATED: MAY 12, 2013 Mappazza affumicata, con troppo corpo, sbilanciata, non mi Ã¨ piaciuta per nulla.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2017 28/01/2013 Brasserie 4:20 (tap). Bevuta al Deutsche Beer Festival. Bruna, color miele di castagno, intensa, limpida, schiuma biancastra leggera, non molto persistente. Al naso Ã¨ straordinaria, malto, caramello, con note affumicate caratterizzanti ma per nulla invadenti. In bocca Ã¨ incredibile, caramello e affumicato si fondono insieme in maniera mirabile, un esercizio di stile, eleganza ed equilibrio incomparabile. Il corpo Ã¨ medio, la carbonazione leggera, molto scorrevole al palato. Birra magnifica, da bere e ribere senza sosta.

500ml bottle. Dark caramel color, tiny off-white head. Juicy smoked bacon dominates in aroma. Malt and hops are slightly detectable as well. Woody, smoked, malty, watery flavor. Taste is very nice but it feels thin and not deep enough. Maybe itÂ’s me, maybe itÂ’s beer? Have to find out next time when I drink it.

Bottle. Clear deep brown liquid with medium off-white/light brown head. Aroma of burning wood, sausage, bready malt, biscuits, dark fruit, wood and light lagerish yeast. Taste is light sweet and light bitter with notes of bread, nuts, dark chocolate, sausage and smoke. Medium bodied with medium carbonation. Very nicely balanced without too much smoke. Awesome!
Dark brown with light brown head. Low carbonation. Very smokey aroma of smoked meat. Also sweet malts and nice bitter, earthy finish.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2013 Bottle. Dark brown, clear. Smoked beef, beef jerky, bbq on nose with a good deal of sweetish malts. Body is malty, medium. This is a lot more sweet malty than the mÃ¤rzen version. IÂ’m liking this less than it. On the other hand, this is not as extreme as the mÃ¤rzen, has some other flavours than smoke. Excellent brew, once again. But I would rather have the mÃ¤rzen.-- bb/h

Pours dark mahogany with a deep tan head thatÂ’s pretty sturdy.  Lots of smokiness with peat and meat.  The malt is quite toasted and on the sweet side with deep caramel. Medium body that is pretty smooth and a subdued amount of carbonation.  Starts with a lots of bready malt, lager smoothness, caramel, toffee and peat smoke.  The finish has more of the meaty smoke aspects, earthiness, tobacco and leather.  Good if you like a ton of smoke in your beers, but I prefer smoked beers that arenÂ’t quite as smoky.
UPDATED: OCT 2, 2016 coffee-dark brown colour, medium brownish head; aroma and taste of smoked ham/cheese with some malty sweetness and bitter/sourish aftertaste; perfect beer

PeÅ‚ny i wyrazisty wÄ™dzony sÅ‚Ã³d wyczuwam, piana nie ustÄ™puje na krok, alkochol nie wyczuwalny. W kuflu wyglÄ…da rubinowo czerwono z kremowÄ… pianÄ…. Finisz dÅ‚Ã³gi, wytrawny i trochÄ™ sÅ‚onawy. Klasyka wÄ™dzonek, polecam

Reviewed 11/07/2012. 16.9 fl oz bottle poured into a straight glass.

A: Pours a dark burgundy color with nice clarity. It looks a little thin pouring down into the glass. The head is a two finger mocha color with moderate retention. ThereÂ’s a lot of spiderweb lacing left down the glass.

S: Very strong smokiness - not just in a woody motif, but reminiscent of ham when taking its mild sweetness into consideration. There is a caramel backbone behind it all, but it takes a bit of hard work to discern it through the smoke. ItÂ’s a damn good aroma - one that permutes into something slightly more chocolaty as further whiffs are taken - with the only real detractor being a slight note of plastic.

T: As expected, smoky meat opens the flavor profile, before turning into vaguely sweet caramel maltiness after the midtaste. The plastic in the aroma is nearly nonexistent in the taste, thankfully. I kind of expected this to be a little more heavy handed than the marzen version, but itÂ’s actually just as subtly flavored, if not more so. The main difference here is a slightly chocolaty finish. ItÂ’s not too sweet nor too bitter, just balanced to near-perfection. Like their marzen, itÂ’s one of the most complex lagers IÂ’ve ever savored, with multiple layers of flavor - like dried fruit and grassy hops - revealing themselves behind the main show of smoked malts.

M: Smooth and a little syrupy, but easy to drink. Very creamy up until the wet, almost decadent finish. Actually, it isnÂ’t that easy to drink, if only because itÂ’s something that should be savored rather than chugged.

O: I am convinced that Schlenkerla is starting to spoil me with their rauchbiers. Take it from a man who normally dislikes bacon - this is excellent.

500ml bottle, 2012 version. Dark reddish brown pour with a bubbly khaki head. Aroma is full of smoke, smoked ham, a little wood, slight caramelly and chocolaty sweet malty notes. As expected. Taste is surprisingly subtly smoked, itÂ’s not overpowering or coating in any sense. First up thereÂ’s caramelly dark malt, then some slight, balancing bitter hoppy notes in the middle, finishing with a campfire smokiness that lingers in the mouth for quite a while. Very nice. Mouthfeel is creamy and smooth with medium carbonation.

Bottle. Black with almost white head. Smoky aroma. Smoky, burned taste. Bitter, bit watery.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2014 Pours dark brown with a little white head; some lacing stays on the sides. The aroma is heavily influenced by smoked maltiness with a noticeable note of ham in it. The taste is much the same: smoky, ham-flavoured maltiness dominates. No hoppiness and interestingly not much typical roasty flavours either. The palate is medium to full bodied with a fairly smooth and slick texture. Maltiness is rich but a bit one-dimensional. The palate is very full for a bottom fermented beer. An interesting speciality all in all.

Poured out of a bottle
Big smoke filled nose
Small off white head that lingers leaving lacing on the glass
Moderate to high carbonation
Dark brown with ruby tints
Taste is smokey malt sweetness that is smooth on the finish with just enough smoke that lingers in the after taste

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma of smoke, honey-glazed ham, maple bacon, beechwood, honey-roasted nuts, and caramel malts. Wonderfully balanced. The taste is smokey, sweet, and finishes dry. Mouthfeel is medium, with a medium body and low carbonation. IÂ’m not a huge smoked-anything guy, but this was artfully crafted.

Pours a very dark ruby red with a beige head, quite thin, plenty of lacing. Smell is overwhelmingly of smoke and burnt wood, amazing smell. Taste is very smokey again, a certain type of smoke though, almost like a smoked cheese or meat. After the smoke, the malts come in, like a dark larger or porter, quite roasty. Also a tiny bit of chocolate on the back of the tongue. Lovely and smooth despite the carbonation, long smokey aftertaste. There are two words to describe this beer: Â’SmokeÂ’ and Â’amazingÂ’.

Bottle, courtesy of MiP. Pours hazy, very dark brown with thick, unstable light tan head. Dark aroma of smoked malt. Delicious taste of malt, rasted nuts and caramel. Pleasant, dryish aftertaste. A very good brew, indeed.
Bottle at home. Dark reddish brown color, medium white head, disappears quickly. Nice aroma of roasted malts, smoke, wood. Smooth taste, smoke, medium malty body, wood, smoky aftertaste. low co2.
On tap. Dark brown body, minimal off-white head. Aroma of smoked ham with some woodyness. Lots of smoke and a little dark fruityness in the flavor. Nice beer.

12/XI/12 - 50cl bottle from Geers (Oostakker) @ home - BB: X/13 (2012-1268) Thanks to Dieter A. for sharing the bottle!
Clear dark purple brown beer, big aery beige head, unstable, pretty adhesive. Aroma: smoky, a bit woody, quite some mocha, sweet, more smoke. MF: ok carbon, medium to full body, smooth creamy texture. Taste: smoky start, sweet, some caramel, bit of mocha, little bitter, fudge, smoky. Aftertaste: caramel, bit sweet, smoky, bitter hops, some mocha. Very interesting and nice smoke beer.
Bottle. Pours a very dark brown with a moderate off-white head. Nose is extremely smoked - one of the smokiest IÂ’ve ever had. Taste is extremely smoky, too. Interesting.

Bottled the day before. The typycal Schlenkerla aroma to smoke and bacon. Excellent retention, head and lace. In mouth, wood, smoked meat and a little trace of sweetness of a plum kind. Delicious, as usual.

Pretty dark brown with a nice foamy tan head. Powerful smoke/wood and meaty scents, taste is similar with a little bit and finishes super smokey, but smooth.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Cola black beer with a brief white head. Smells like smoked ham. Literally. The taste is also heavily smoked. Some roastiness, sweetness, roundness, softness. Slightly oily slick. A little crispiness from the carbonation which isnÂ’t too heavy. This beer is absolutely brilliant to have on its own but it can be served with food as well. This is pure goodness. I love it.
Dark brown color.  Aroma of smoked meat . Taste is like the aroma  - smoke meat with some sweetness, nicely balanced. I like it.
Deep mahogany body, white head. Aroma of smoke, tart, rich maltiness, bit concentrated malty aroma. No hops at all. None missed. Flavour is deep with smoke, nuts, cola and tar.
