500ml bottle pours a clear brown/copper color with medium khaki head and some lacing.  Aroma is full of meaty smoke but enough caramel malts to remind you that this is a bock beer underneath.  Body is medium to full with only slight carbonation.  Finish is slightly bitter.  This made a great dessert after a dinner of barbecued ribs.  As good as any rauchbier IÂ’ve tried from this brewery - the master of this style.
500 ml bottle. Great smokey taste. One of the best beers IÂ’ve tried. But the aftertaste is a bit too bitter.
Medium brownish head, clear and dark red brown colour. Nice smoked aroma. Spicy taste with a caramel note. Bitter and smokey palate.
A smoked beer that is more than just liquid smoke. It still has the niceties of a good bock. Roasted malts, some sweetness. Great smocked bock. On tap at In De Wildeman.

Bottle. Deep meaty smoke aroma with caramel in the background. Clear cola-colored with a thin head. Flavor is deep with caramel flavors that complement the smoke. More depth than most rauchbiers. Thick palate. Very enjoyable.
Draught at Black Door, Helsinki. Colour is dark brown with some brownish white head. Aromas and flavours are smoke, malts, caramel and some oak. Great beer.
2012.11.08 - bottle 50cl - dark brown - nose : smoke, charcuterie/bacon - mouth : smooth, smoked malts, bacon

Pours a thin caramel brown, big bubbles in the thin head which dissipates quickly. Aroma is straight up smoke, not too pleasant, a bit sour even. Taste is surprisingly good given the smell, sweet cream with smoke from start to finish, not subtle but not overpowering. Smooth, thick going down. Would be better without the overpowering smell, but tastes good if you like the smoke.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Obviously rauch especially in the aroma. Had it iota clay mug and it looked good! Sweet like a bock, not as fresh as the mÃ¤rzen

Pours cola colored with almost no head, just a few white bubbles on top. Aroma is caramel, oak, and smoke (like a campfire). Taste is nice and smooth smoked meat flavor with a tinge of sweetness. Feels watery and slick in your mouth. I love this stuff and always look forward to the fall so I can drink it appropriately.
Bottle. Pours dark brown color with nice tan head. Aroma is smoke, malt, honey. Flavor is smoke, malt, honey. Excellent combination of bock and smoked beer.

Pour out of 500 mL bottle, thanks Aaron! Dark brownish red pour with thin white head, aroma brought notes of big bacon, ham, slight ash, smoke, hints of earth, chocolate, and oak.  Nice.  Taste is a mix of earth, nice smoke, some chocolate, roast, hints of bacon and ham, finishing nice and smoky, dry, slightly thin.

Location/Date:Bottle on October 5th, 2012. Dual rating with Aecht Schlenkerla Eiche Doppelbock.
Appearance: Pours a dark brown - maroon with light white head. 
Aroma: Aroma of smoked wood(oak), bacon, pork.
Taste: Smoke, faint malt, not as much meaty taste as the aroma, faint bitterness, slightly sweet/boozy.
Palate:Medium body, slick, creamy, lingering finish.
Summary: I really think I could smell this beer all day. I liked the taste, but not as much as the marzen.

500ml bottle poured into Schlenkerla pint!  Pours a nice deep almost opaque brown with a finger-thick head.  Aroma is...oh my sweet fÂ’in lord...candied-bacon!  The sweet caramel malts blended with that delightful smoky aromas...this is incredible.  This is liquid sweet BBQ in your mouth.  Taste is medium sweet and only very slightly bitter in the far background.  Palate is incredible as well, better than the MarzenÂ’s.  Body is medium-full, texture is slick and creamy perfection, carbonation is somewhat light but itÂ’s just perfect for this beer.  Finish is medium in length and the woody/smokey aspect is whats left on your tongue.  I wonÂ’t hide that IÂ’m a HUGE rauchbier fan so I might be a bit biased but seriously this is one of the best beers IÂ’ve ever had.  I donÂ’t think I will ever be deceived by Schlenkerla.  The only thing which is deceiving and I wonÂ’t ever say it enough is that locally we only get the Marzen because in Quebec, Canada, alcoholic beverages are controlled by our provinceÂ’s liquor board.  And theyÂ’re retarded.

Strong aroma has lots of smoke, tar, roasted caramel, licorice. Dark red/brown to black. Beige head leaves lacing. Full bodied, soft and full feel, smoky tar, caramel, long roasted flavors, good balance. Hits the core, tasty and easy to drink and enjoy. Excellent.

Out of a bottle, review is from notes previously taken.  Pours a rich brown color with a nice sized white head.  Smell is real smokey, nice campfire scent also roasted malt and coffee.  Taste is sweet and malty with a big smokey flavor....very nice. Nice rauchbier, would have this one again.

Pours a dull chestnut color with an inch or so of khaki head. Oh, the aroma. Holy smokes! Pun intended, of course. Very smokey and sweet aroma tickles the nostrils in a way that makes say "Oh, thatÂ’s nice." Woody, campfire smoke mixed with caramel and brown sugar wafts so gracefully from my mug I can practically see it. If campfires smelled so good IÂ’d find myself sleeping on dirt in a tent thrice a week. The flavor is much more subtle than the nose. Slightly dry, nutty, and smokey with no more than a wisp of noble hops to say Auf Wiedersehen! as the sip embarks on a perilous journey down your throat. The palate is robust yet quaffable, rating a perfect 10 on the Goldilocks scale of alcohol content vs. drinkability. Without resigning myself to hyperbole, I must unequivocally state that this is the most perfect beer ever crafted by humans or outer space aliens.

Ruby tinted brown with a nearly non-existent head. Smoke pervades the nose to be sure. Medium to full bodied, the smoke goes out front, but swirling underneath one finds amazing complexity with caramel malts and some oaky notes. Soft mouthfeel.

I could smell the smoke as soon as I popped the cap. Reminded me of a campfire. Very intense. This beer pours a deep, clear reddish brown. It has a strong smoke flavor with a medium amount of bitterness. It is so intense that it overwhelmed my taste buds, requiring me to take a break before continuing tasting. Perhaps a cracker or two to cleanse the palate would be appropriate.
The beer has average carbonation with a long mellow finish that is very refreshing. Definitely a keeper!
A real big smokey bock beer, not to thick and suprisingly refreshing and crisp. I really like this beer and its aged in 700 year old cellars underneath Germany, wow.

Pours medium brown amber with light beige head. Smells lightly sweet and grainy with the natural smokey scent reminiscent of bbq ham and smoked cheeses. The taste is smooth a more sweet and grainy over the smoke compared to several if the other aecht brews, carrying some light toasted toffee and a hint of chocolatyness. It is nice that way as the smoke is secondary to a smooth highly drinkable beer. The darker malt changes the character of the smoke making it more like bbq pork or brisket in the finish than a bacon or cheese flavor. Lighter carbonation adds to the smooth satiny smooth drink and it finishes slightly dry. Very nice overall maybe my favorite of theirs as it stands distinctly on it?s own.

A very unique beer. Extremely smoky. Pours a very dark maroon brown color with a tan head. Smells smoky, like BBQ. Taste is smoky and creamy. Very nice.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

500ml bottle. Pours a clear, deep ruby brown, with a large off-white head, which lasts well and leaves good lacing. Savoury smoke aromas dominate, with some sweeter brown sugar and caramel notes to balance them. Spicy hops lead into a delightful smoked meat flavour, blending with it nicely. This smokiness is again balanced by some sweeter malt notes, yet lingers into a dry finish, which leaves a pleasantly smoky aftertaste. This is a little sweeter than AechtÂ’s marzen, and correspondingly a little less smoky. It is very nice indeed, but on the whole I prefer the marzen.

500ml bottle in a lager glass.  Pours brown with a lacy, light tan head.  Aroma of barbecue, some caramel and pale malts, and floral hops.  Flavor the same, with lots of barbecue.  Average texture.  A pretty good beer of the style.
Pours brown colour. Aroma is of smoke and light cheese funk. Taste is sweet and smokey.

From bottle at home (Dec Â’11) into a half litre German glass with a handle.

Mid brown in colour to dark chestnut (late in the season) with a head on the small side.

Big smokey smell to this beer - thinking frazzles (UK bacon flavoured crisps!).

In addition to the obvious smoked flavour of this beer I also get a malty bitterness particularly in the aftertaste.

A similar smoked taste to the other Schlenkerla beers (but not noticeably greater than the Weizen or Maerzen), but being from the bock family has a stronger alochol taste to it.

Just smelt the empty glass 15 minutes after drinking - smells like a BBQ pit !
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Pours a dark dark brown, lighter red-brown highlights and a tan head. Smells wonderfully smoky. Robust smoke/gouda/bacon flavor that rolls back just a tad on the finish. Perhaps a little one dimensional, but what a dimension!
delicious smokyness. not too intense, fairly sweet and caramely. malty and crisp finish.
500ml bottle. Dark brown with some head. Smokey aroma and taste. Overall very good in my books.

Splitting a bottle with my wife this afternoon. One of her favorite beers enjoyed on a beautiful autumn-like day.

A: Dark walnut hue. When held to the light, the beer becomes more transparent and I notice the slow ascension of bubbles throughout the glass. There is an off white head that recedes to a quarter inch and holds steady, leaving a healthy amount of lacing on the glass.

S: This aroma defines rauchbier, in my opinion. Smoke, campfire, burning meats, summer sausage, roasted malts. The scents are absolutely fantastic.

T: The taste does not disappoint. Fabulous smoky taste, with a salami or sausage flavor in there, as well. This is to beer what Lagavulin is to single malt scotch. Everything is balanced so well - this is a pleasure to drink. This beer is perhaps the perfect pairing with a meat and cheese spread.

M: Very smooth, thin to medium bodied. The smoky aftertaste is delightful. Alcohol hidden very well.

D: Very drinkable, though I find one glass to be sufficient. This brewery sets the standard for German rauchbiers. Highly recommended.

Pours a very dark brown with plenty of light sneaking through, similar in color to a thin-bodied black coffee. Light tan head. The nose is delicious, like smoked bacon blended with the sweet malts and mild hoppiness of an American brown ale. The flavors are along the same lines, with the nice sweet maltiness of the base beer perfectly mixing with the smoke and leather characteristics. ItÂ’s also surprisingly clean and easy to drink.
Bottle pour. Big time smoked wood, bacon, very roasty. Bigger malt characteristic than its counterparts. Wonderful beer. Awesome with breakfast for dinner.

10/12 0.5 l bottle at Pivkan fest, Zagreb. It poured clear dark brown body with smaller head. Straightforward smoked aroma of tasty ham and cheese. Strong flavor, besides already mentioned smoked stuff there was fruitiness, some distinct wood and touch of tobacco. Full bodied with very long cloying finish, maybe even too much over the top. Excellent hardcore smoked by any means.

Light brown, clear, thin white head. Aroma: bready Munich malt, a little toffee, pronounced rauch malt smokiness. Flavor:  bread-crusts, toffee, toasty notes, light chocolate, smoked malts are pronounced and blend in nicely. Medium-full body.  Very well done and balanced. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
I rate this a little high but this is my all time personal favorite beer. Not many people like this but I LOVE it.

Poured deep dark brown, creamy tight little head and some very decent lacing much nicer than what I usually get from the bottle. aroma of smokey BBQ, meaty, bacon, smoke, delicious. Taste is just as it smells. nice balance between sweet meaty BBQ and a slight bitter aftertaste that leaves the palate clean and ready for food or the next sip. Lighter on the tongue than youÂ’d expect and smooth as can be. Overall this is a beer experience, one that helped to change my own attitude as to what beer could be. It is one of my all time favourites.

Bottle at home. Dark muddy brown, thin white head fades to nothing. Rich bacon woodsmoke on the nose, with a solid backbone of chocolate and dark fruits. Palate is slightly sweet and malty up front, before being matched by a big charcoal smokiness. Syrupy notes, very well-balanced. Bacon fat, definitely. Soft dry finish, hint of cocoa. This is nice. Growing on me.

Bottle. Aromas of really smoky bacon, hints of dark fruit and chocolate as well, nice and subtle. Tastes, obviously, unbelievably smoky, but it is balanced as well, really nicely, with some dark fruit and almost liquoricey. Really tasty, top rauchbier.

Bottle. Hardwood smoked ham aroma initially, and then caramel malt became apparent as it warmed.  Dark brown with a small beige head, light lacing. Fruity smoked ham, roasty malt, and light bitter hop flavor. Medium body with light carbonation.

500ml bottle listed at 5.1%ABV pours a dark brown color with a small off-white head that leaves only thin spotty lacing behind.  Aroma is smoky with some light caramel and chocolate and some oak and light hops.  Taste is malty sweet with and oakiness and smokiness that are dominant over the light hop bitterness.  Light to medium body with mild carbonation.  A very well done rauchbier which is quite tasty and enjoyable.

Purchased at West Lakeview Liquors in Chicago, IL; enjoyed after a grueling visit to the dentist, prior to watching game 2 of the NBA Finals.  Appearance is a dark brown/ruby hue with a thin slightly off white head.  Aroma of bacon/ham, smoked wood, burnt ash, also a light bit of sweetness, smells fantastic.  Taste is really freaking good.  The smoke is nice and balanced between the mixture of smoke and sweet.  ItÂ’s surprisingly smooth for the style, also a very faint bit of dark fruit/plum taste.  This doesnÂ’t beat out the fresh marzen that I enjoyed straight from the brewery, but this is a pretty damn close second.  Awesome awesome stuff, happy to have tried the majority of the beers from this historic brewery.

[bottle]
Sweet smoky aroma with some faint dark malt bread crust accent. Almost opaque reddish-dark brown with almost white ring and floating wispy patch. Sweet, malty flavour with loads of wood smoke and notes of grain and bread. Medium bitterness balances the  Medium to full body, moderate carbonation, faint lasting bitterness.

A perfect smoked beer. Nice smokey aroma without being overpowering; you can still smell fruit and sweet malts as well. Nice red-brown colour with off white head and lacing. Taste is lovely sweet malt with smokiness of course. Overall, a great beer.

Amazing smokey aroma. Reminds me of smoked edam cheese. Appearance is nice, but the head didnÂ’t last. Taste is very good, easy drinking, beautiful smokiness. Palate isnÂ’t very lively, but because of the delicious taste and aroma this is a great beer.
The head is robust, the body brown. It smells malty and like ham and smokey. The taste is intensive smokey, smokey-malty. Nice! 12/12/11/12/11/12

Bottle that some anonymous guest left in my fridge. Clear reddish brown pour with a medium beige head. Hammy aroma with sweet malt and caramel. Malty and smoky flavor with sweet malt and caramel in the finish.

Pours deep brown with a frothy oatmeal coloured head about 2 inches tall.
Scent is smoked meats, slightly sweet accent.
Taste is salted ham/back-bacon......sweet malt.....very mild.
Very nice smokiness throughout...pleasantly light body.
Wonderful.

Pours a very deep rich amber with a nice two finger sudsy tan head. Aroma is smoked malt, cured meats, baked bread and hints of sweeter roasted maltiness. A more rich rounded out, sweeter body with complexity of smokiness and salty bacon. Finishes dry and refreshing. Delicious beer.

Pours a dark brown from the bottle with a thick tan head and little lacing. Aroma is of cured sausage with a sweet malty note that comes in late. Taste is of smoked, meaty malts that last in your mouth, but it is clean and decently balanced. Interesting, but not for me.
Well, IÂ’m not particularly a fan, but I can see the appeal. Big smoke aroma, meaty. ItÂ’s impressive.
Tap at Hopmonk Sonoma. Amber pour with a white head. Huge smoky nose and taste, with some smoked meat in the flavor. Very good.

Bottle from Utobeer. Colour is very dark brown ale, off white head. Nose is smoky. Deep wood smoke, sweet malty notes, smoked meat. Taste is wood smoky, smoked meats, but light in character and delicate. On the finish thereÂ’s some nice sweet maltiness. Balance is very good, touch sweeter than other Schlenkerla smoked beers.

500 ml. bottle. Pours a medium, lasting, beige head, with some lacing, over a clear light brown (SRM 20) body....nose is smoke, light toffee/caramel....taste is toffee/caramel, light smoke, hints of molasses, finishing with a lingering slightly sweet smokiness....mouth feel medium and slightly sticky, carbonation adds creaminess. This meets the style perfectly, with the balance between the malts and smoke deftly done, but then after several hundred years, they should have it down. BJCP 7/3/16/4/7

500ml bottle. Pours a brown black tea like colour with a beige head of smallish foam. Strong smokey aromas are a mixture of campfire smoke and smoked ham mmmm nice. Full bodied in the mouth and the smokiness carries all the way through to the end. A very good beer.

One of my favorite Rauch Beers. I always feel like I am on a quest in a haunted woods when I drink this baby. From its black/brown appearance to campfire smell. Drinking it warms me, it tastes of sustenance. Woody, meaty at first, gives way to a more complex finish with sweetness and bitterness. Very smooth for a heavily-smoked beer. Thinner than many smoked beers. Quest on, friends!

Pours a dark red/brown with a beige head.  Aroma is very smoky, and smells like meat.  I can detect a dark fruitiness as well, along with oak.  Taste is smoky and earthy and actually a bit sweet.  Smooth drinking with smoky aftertaste.  Reminds me of a BBQ.  Very different and extremely enjoyable.

The thick head is the consistency of an egg white foam and a light tan color.  The beer itself is dark ruby with just a hint of light shining through the pint glass.  Banana bread and smoke on the nose.   The aroma is quite pleasant.  Smoke forward on the palate with sweet caramel supporting.  High carbonation thins an otherwise heavy body.  The smoke plays an integral part and adds a depth of flavor to an already great beer.

For this style, I love the aroma of BBQ and campfire. Very dark red body and bubbly head. This is very unique style, and of the smoked beers i have had previously, the "smokiness" was usually overwhelming or otherwise unpleasant. This beer, however, has a great balance of light bitterness, smokiness and malt.

Pours a rich brown color  with a decent head.  A bready, smoke aroma, with the taste to match.  Taste is earthy with hints of an outdoor smoker bbq.  You can slightly taste the wood cask as well.  Overall a decent beer, just not my style.
Pours copper with a beige head. Aroma is breaddy malt, bacon and fruity notes. Flavour is breaddy malt, bacon, salami and light fruit.

Cola color high carbonation notes of ashes smoke cigar hickory bacon very good but just a touch thin on the malt profile

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

(bottle). The Stoutragious POTW. This aroma is the smokiest IÂ’ve experienced.  ItÂ’s pleasant and natural without overpowering. The head is thick and frothy and body has dark brown complexion. The flavor is smooth and mild with smoked malt center stage. Very enjoyable and unique. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle - Pours cola-colored with a quickly dissipating khaki head. The smell is--exactly what IÂ’m looking for in a smoked beer. It smells like the smoked applewood bacon I like, with some sweet wood and apple notes. Pungent and smoky for sure, but itÂ’s not overbearing, and a sweet fruity maltiness lurks underneath it all. Layered and complex. The taste is surprisingly laid-back. The smoke is there, but thereÂ’s a barbequed pork sweetness that is more front and center than the smoke. ItÂ’s a nice balanced between smoke, meat, and light bready malt. More meat through the finish, and a touch of spicy, warming heat. Slick in the mouth, with a medium body and lively carbonation. An experience for sure, and one IÂ’d like to repeat sometime down the road when IÂ’m craving the style.

Pours transparent brown but as it gathers in the glass it becomes thick and light doesn't break through. Not much head to speak. A few bubbles grace the top in the form of a thin film. Nose is caramel, cigar smoke, BBQ pig skin and oak. Flavor is sweet, the bitter then sweet again on the finish. Smokey throughout. Mouthfeel is smooth and clean. Medium body with a long aftertaste. Magnificent.

Wow.  Wow.  Never had anything like this.  Smells like our local BBQ place smoke daddy. Smells like bacon and charcoal. Smokiest taste possible in a beer.  The other 3 people I'm with hated it, but they don't appreciate craft beer.  I can't say I like or don't like it. Confused. Interesting to say the least

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a dark murky brown with minimal head, no lacing.  Aroma obvious of smoke, caramel malt, and not a whole lot else.  Flavor is complex, but just not my style.

Ever drank a beer that tasted like steak? Or bacon? The aecht schlenkerla rauchbier series are like no other smoke beer youÂ’ve ever had. They all taste like theyÂ’ve been brewed with a full pig in the boil. This one in particular (the urbock) is the best balanced of the series. Rounds out with subtle bitterness and sweetness. Smoke beers are not usually my thing, but this beer is GOOD!

Bottle 50 cl thanks to Sebastian. Great appearance, brown to ruby with red reflexes. Almost no foam. So strong smoked aroma: it recall food, from bockwurst to smoked provola (cow cheese from South of Italy). And ashes, burned wood, cinder, dark fruits, dried fruits (almonds, nuts, walnut). Body is sugary, but malty and pleasantly full of burned wood and roasted malt. Caramel, vanilla, dark fruits again. Mid carbonation, link the sweetness of the bock with the sharpness of the smoked and itÂ’s a really good marriage. Bitter finish. I remember a freshier one and was spectacular, so I suggest to have it as fresh as possible and my rate refers to the fresh version. In a Schlenkerla top-three I give Urbock silver medal, while Marzen gains bronze and Eiche absolutely gold.

A dark brown color with an off white head. The aroma is like a bonfire with a little bit of sweetness. The flavor is the same: lots of smoke up front with a sweet, smokey aftertaste.

The pour a dark burgundy.  The scent of a bonfire. The taste is oily smoke.  This is my least favorite of the Schlenferla rauchbiers.  Still a well crafted brew, just not my style.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a clear and dark copper beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is malt, caramel, smoke and peat. The flavor follows the nose. The palate is smoked. Overall a good beer.
Smoke, black pepper, charred wood aroma. Clear brown, headless. Smoke flavor, obviously. Wood and leaves, otherwise. Alcohol not noticeable, not overly done.

Deep, dark brown colored pour. Slightly off-white head that quickly falls and leaves behind splotches of bubbles, tiny splotches. Big, oily, bacony aroma with roasted malts. Taste is close to the same with a nice balance of bacon and malt. More along the lines of a smoked salty ham, honestly. Nice subtle smoke aftertaste. A little on the thin side, but still great.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2013 Rerate. Org. 18.2.2012 757415 Pours clear amber with medium foamy head. Aroma is ham and smoke. Hint of coffee. Medium body. Taste is malts, salami and smoke. Burned malts in the finish. Nice.
Lots of smoke in both aroma and taste. Clear black color with medium head. Perfect body between  Maerzen and Porter/Stout. Smoke, and not roasted malt, is the hero here!

Black with a touch of red and a soapy head.  Very smoky aroma of TX BBQ... itÂ’s bordering of the edge of intolerable but still very nice.   More smoke in the flavor followed by a slight sweet cocoa aftertaste.  Overall, itÂ’s fairly tasty but IÂ’m not sure if I  could drink more than one in a session.  Thanks to BarZigKin for sharing!
Flaske 0,5l fra Alko Muonio.  Delt med Rune under seanse i heimen 9 Feb 12. Vanvittig baconaroma. Pen dyprÃ¸d med et lavt, luftig skum. Smaken er rÃ¸yk. Litt sÃ¸t. Forsiktig syrlig ettersmak.

500ml bottle,shared by Finn. Beautiful appearance with its clear, mahogany coloured body and off-white head. Big aroma of smoked bacon. More meat-like in flavour added by chocolate malts beneath. Bitter and sweet malty ending. Good stuff (session in TromsÃ¸, 09.02.2012).
Gravity at Battersea beer festival 2012, rich and smoky, with a fruity roundness, and faintly tart and winey notes.
Another great "smoke beer" love the flavor.  Where the Marzan tastes more like bacon the Urbock takes on a delicious smoke Ham flavor.

Bottle. Pours a very dark brown with plenty of light sneaking through, similar in color to a thin-bodied black coffee. Light tan head. The nose is delicious, like smoked bacon blended with the sweet malts and mild hoppiness of an American brown ale. The flavors are along the same lines, with the nice sweet maltiness of the base beer perfectly mixing with the smoke and leather characteristics. ItÂ’s also surprisingly clean and easy to drink. IÂ’d imagine it would pair wonderfully with a grilled steak or barbecue. Now IÂ’m hungry. And thirsty.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2013 Bottle shared by Dedollewaitor, thanks. Pours redish with a small offwhite head. Aroma is smoke, roast, tobacco. Flavor is smoke, roast, tobacco. Medium carbonation. [7,3,7,3,14]

Re-rate 1/2-2013. Trade from Mads K, thanks. Pours clear brown with a medium offwhite head. Aroma is smoke, tobacco, caramel, roast, charcoal, butter notes. Flavor is smoke, caramel, tobacco, charcoal. [7,3,8,3,15]

Bottle...  Poured brownish, burgundy with a thick, bubbly, beige head.  Nice retention and lacing.  Nose had obvious smoke characters with ash, and tobacco.  Mild body, pleasant mouthfeel.  Oak, smoked characters, campfire smoke, cherries, meat, roast, charred grains, and a hint of sweetness. Flavofull finish with big smoked tones.
16.9 oz bottle poured into a tulip glass.  Deep brown color and thin tan head.  I love the smoked taste of this beer.  It is a great change of pace.

Bottle. Pours clear, dark brown with thin off-white head; short retention and minimal lacing.  Aroma is roasted malt, smoke, oak, nuts, and earthy notes.  Flavor is heavy roasted malt, smoke, with some vanilla and dark chocolate notes; dry, smokey finish.  Medium body, carbonation, and warmth.

deep drown clear head mocca white fat foam. Aromas roasted malts, nuts, Russian rye bread. Palate sticky smooth CO2, smoke , malts, paper. Texture full bodied watery. aftertaste  bitter roasted grains with some hops. Mostly dry finish with hints of bitter.

well this is different!   Pours dark brown   light tan head that goes away fast. Aroma  - yeah smoky like a log fire and barbeque sauce .  First mouthful is a shock  - all that smoky aroma showing in the taste   - light carbonation . Then as you get into it further mouthfuls show semi sweet malts and hints of caramel .  Finish is smoky and long . Medium body . A style you have to try at least once .

On cask at the 2012 NWAF, Manchester. Pours a dark brown colour with a decent light tan head. Aroma is very smoky with oak and chocolate. Similar smoky flavours with roasty malt, burnt toast, chocolate and coffee. Lovely lingering smoke. Moderate carbonation with an oily mouth-feel and light CO2 prickle.

Tasted on 1/11/12 from a capped 500mL bottle purchased at Midtown.  Pours a clear, deep mahogany, with an average beige head that slowly recedes to fairly even lacing.  The nose is heavily smoked with some with some caramel malt, a hint of nuttiness, and some vanilla.  The flavor is featured more on the caramel, nutty, and vanilla malt, with the smoked notes very present, but acting as a bit more of a backbone.  The body is medium with average, but very smooth carbonation, and a long smoked finish.

Bottle from Bottleworks. Sorry if my rating doesnÂ’t make sense, the hash is kickinÂ’ in a bit. Dark brown translucent beer. No head to speak of. What can I say about the Aecht beers, other than theyÂ’re fucking amazing. Oak and smoke dominate the aroma. Bits of jerky come through, and add an even better nuance to the aroma. Smells great! Immediate smoke, oak, jerky, campfire flavor hit my taste buds. Light and crisp texture. Amazing stuff, as always.

Ar: A smoky wood fire.
Ap: Deep chestnut brown - crystal clear - small off-white head with low retention and some light lacing.
T: Like the aroma - lots of smoke, tar, and wood - semi-sweet - deep malt with toasted notes - slightly acrid, with low bitterness.
P: Medium body with medium carbonation - dry on the finish.
O: A big and smoky malt-forward beer - deliciously pure smoke, totally dominates in a very impressive way - delicious!

It is frankly difficult to rate this beer since it is so different from most others. ItÂ’s one of the most meaty beers I have had with its heavy notes of sausages and ham. Very, very smokie and definitely a treat for those who like that.

Thickest beet ever.
The strongest smoked beer I ever had.
Thick dark color, a bit foam.
Aromas of smokiness and dry meat.
Tastes the same as the aromas.
You get the feeling that you are drinking liquid smoking meat.
AMAZING.

IÂ’m certain this is a great brew; my issue is that IÂ’m not a fan of smokebiers.  It starts with a nice malt, which is overcome quickly by smokey ham and a definite hop bite.  It is well-balanced and has a full palate, it just isnÂ’t a style IÂ’d ever choose willingly.
One of my most favorite beers.  The city is beautiful and the beer fits it perfectly.

50 cl bottle @ Nurmo, BBE 04/2012
Aroma has lots of tar and smoked ham. Flavour has tar, smoke and some woody notes. Hoppy finish and somewhat sticky and dry palate. Really smoky and nice, although IÂ’d like this more with a little less hops.

Pours deep dark brown with an off-white/beige head that dissipates quickly.  Nose is of ham, smoke and coffee. Medium bodied and lightly cabonated, somewhat velvety, coats the tongue.  Taste is sweet malt, breakfast meats and smoke.  Overall an interesting beer.

Bottle to start holiday weekend.  Pours deep dark brown with a soapy beige head that dissipates quickly.  Nose is of breakfast skillet of flavors.  Tastes of smoke, bacon, plums, raisins, hay and malt.  Really quite good.  Medium bodied and lingering watery finish

0,5l bottle from SÃ¶rspecialista, Budapest. ItÂ’s a very interesting beer, a special one. Nice appearance, clear reddish brown color with minimal head. Unbelivable aroma! ItÂ’s literally like boiled knuckle. Smoky, coffee, roasty. Medium bitter aroma with some sweetness, what is characteristic of bock biers. Full body with oily, creamy but sour texture. Average carbonation. Long smoky bitter finish. Very good beer. Interesting mixture of the sweetness of the malt and the sourness of the smoke.

0,5l bottle from SÃ¶rspecialista, Budapest. ItÂ’s a very interesting beer, a special one. Nice appearance, clear reddish brown color with minimal head. Unbelivable aroma! ItÂ’s literally like boiled knuckle. Smoky, coffee, roasty. Medium bitter aroma with some sweetness, what is characteristic of bock biers. Full body with oily, creamy but sour texture. Average carbonation. Long smoky bitter finish. Very good beer. Interesting mixture of the sweetness of the malt and the sourness of the smoke.

500 mL bottle from Grape & Gourmet.  Dark brown pour with barely a bubble.  The aroma is of strong smoked bacon, so strong that nothing else dares to peer through.  As strong as the aroma is I was a bit surprised at how subdued the smoke is in the flavor.  Sweet malts are noted and the smoke tends to creep up in the background.  First I will say what did not work for me with this beer.  The carbonation is severely lacking.  The mouthfeel is a bit thin.  Besides the smoke there is little else going on.  That being said, here is what I do like.  While mouthfeel is thin and while there is not much else going on other than the smoke maybe that is the point.  If this had a thicker, creamier mouthfeel and the smoke was something that was even more prevailing this may be overwhelming.  While I tend to prefer smoked porters and stouts this is what I would recommend if someone wanted to try a true rauchbier.  This is a review that is almost in conflict with itself but I think that is fitting.  This is a challenging beer, but probably the best example of a true rauchbier I have come across.

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2014 Tap @ brewpub, 15/11/14. Pours a dark auburn brown with a large, yellowish-brown head. Aroma is a lot of smoke, some smoked ham. Taste is a lot of caramel, some caramel, lightly sweet, light conifer, some wood. Moreish, really fills the mouth. Much better here than from the bottle, not that surprisingly.

Bottle 08/03/13. Pours a very dark brown with a mahogany tinge. Beige blanket of a head. Aroma is smoke, smoked ham, caramel malts. The smoked piece of ham dominates. Taste is more smokey, there is the ham as well, but itÂ’s more in the background. Note that itÂ’s ham, not bacon. No fatty parts in this, no butter. Caramel is strong as well. Small herbal presence of hops. Palate is fairly full, somewhat carbonated. > 8-3-8-4-15 

Bottle 12/11/11. Pours a murky, hazy, orangey brown with a small, beige head. Aroma is smoke, smoked ham, some caramel, smoked malts, tar. Taste is fairly sweet, very smoky, some maltiness. Smoke, smoked ham and herbs in the finish. Palate is full. 7-4-7-4-15

bottle: pour is deep brown with fading white head. Aroma is smoked malts. Sweet body with campfire goodness and dry charcoal notes. Some plums and raisins and a dry piney finish. Smoke on this adds another dimension to an already delicious higher gravity bock. Pairs great with pizza.
Bottiglia da 50 cl. Schiuma di grana fine molto persistente, al nasa un grnade affumicato e al palato risalta lÂ’affumicato su tutto e dopo le prime sorsate rimane un pÃ² stucchevole.

Refrigerated bottle poured into a shaker.  Pours slightly translucent dark brown with small beige head.  A little lacing, medium body, medium carbonation, and aroma is light smoke.  Taste is roasted malt, Virginia honey baked ham (ham, some honey, and a hint of salt), smoke, some oak, and long smoke finish.  Good, but was hoping for a bigger smoke flavor.
500ml bottle.  Pours a very dark brown with a medium head.  Aroma is smoked ham and leather.  Taste has ham to start and a smokey finish.  Not over the top but works well.  Oily, low carbonation.

Bottle/500ml - Pours a very dark brown in color with reddish highlights if held to the light.  Aroma is pleasantly smokey... tar, burnt malts, burnt pork (?) ... and some small amount of hops.  Flavor is also quite smokey, similar to the aroma, with some dark fruit as well.  Slightly sweet.  Decent palate.  Lingering smokey sweetness...  One of the best smoke beers IÂ’ve had.

Bottle from Stirchley Wines, Birmingham. Smells like smoked shampoo - that coal tar anti-dandruff one. Mouthfeel thin, uncarbonated and oily. This is actually pretty sweet and doesnÂ’t feel particularly strong. Deliciously smokey, but a little uncomplicated.

500 ml bottle.  Served in a mug, the beer pours a reddish/brown color with about a half inch light tan head.  Head retention is decent, with a small amount of lacing.  Aroma is strong, it smells mostly like smoked meats and malt, along with some bready malt and wood.  The taste is similar to the aroma, itÂ’s mainly smoked meats/malt, but thereÂ’s also some wood, caramel malt and a bit of sweet dark fruit noticeable, too.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, itÂ’s a bit creamy with moderate, soft carbonation.  I think itÂ’s a pretty good overall brew, IÂ’d buy this again in the future.

smoked ham, xmas
nice smoky nose, nice sweet. good foam. malty tones. makes me feel like xmas

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

50 cl bottle. BBE 04/2012.
Originally rated on 20090310. (9+4+9+4+17)
Pours clear dark mahogany colour with medium thick head, leaves a nice lacing. Aroma of burnt malts, tar, smoky ham, notes of oak and some ash. Flavour of sweetish caramel malts, burnt smoky ham, tar, grain and notes of bread. Medium to full bodied, lingering sweetish taste with a mild bitter finish. Well balanced.
4426

(Bottled)A bit on an antimax for me . The smokeiness has not the charm or potency or the regular Schlenkerla ,that fine line between bizare and brilliant isnÂ’t showcased  .  This is  like having sex near a smokey campfire and it starts raining ..thats the best metaphor this beer gives me .   in the mouth its salty , woody ,dry  and all safely led by a mild smokey flert.  When I drink a rauchbier im not looking for subtle vibes.
Bottle. Pours reddish brown with a nice head. Aroma smoky burnt malts with some earthy hops. A classic winter beers for me to drink here in Finland. Not Bad.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2015 Rerate (5.11.2015): 50 cl, bottled. BB 07/2016. Pours  cloudy, murky red with a decent tanned head. Aroma: Malt, smoke. Sweet, some notes of acidity. Pleasant bitterness. Palate: Medium body, notable carbonation. I like it (No score changes.).
----- cl, bottled. Pours clear red with a nice beige head. Aroma: Amusing smokiness. Wood, malt and berries. Taste: Dynamic sweetness that is pleasant, slight coffee bitterness. Smoke and berries. Palate: Soft, medium bodied. Average carbonation. Delightful. (8-4-8-4-16, 18.11.2011)
Tap, The Euston Tap, London. Smoked port aroma, some prune and bitter cherry. Sweet, with a xmas pudding character.

Bottle.  Pours a deep cola brown with a thin to medium sized beige head that falls off rather quickly.  Huge deep smoke aromas, wood, malt.  Medium bodied, the smoke hits right away, rich and wood filled, big hefty campfire flavors.  Dark malt, roast, a bit of wooden tannic bitterness.  Long finish redolent with loads of big smoke, creamy mouthfeel, and more bitter wood.  Really great.
Smoky, roasty flavor. Almost reminiscent of barbecue. Very dark brown with a small head. Not a ton of bitterness.

Bottle, best before 10/2011 (so just past expiration date).
Dark reddish brown with a large tan head.
Aroma: smoked sausages, malty, fruity.
Taste: sweet and malty, some chocolate, smoke, campfire, smoked meat, candy, quite bitter, almost a chili heat.
Medium-bodied, smooth.
DonÂ’t know whether this or the MÃ¤rzen is better, both are very nice.

500ml bottle into a pint glass.

Appearance is a dark ruby. Minimal head that quickly diminishes.

Smells heavily of smoke. Mostly campfire with some bacon. I canÂ’t smell any malt.

The taste is all smoke up front but as that fades, a malty sweetness comes through finishing slightly bitter. The smoke is present throughout, however. As I get into the beer, the initial shock of the smoke fades and the beer begins to taste more balanced. A lot more malt becomes apparent.

Overall I think I like this beer better than the marzen. It is a lot more in your face with the smoke and I will definitely seek it out again.

Serving type: bottle

Big smoky nose, sausage and campfire, but more of the malt aromas come through with this beer; caramel and toffee, rye bread.  Pours dark brown, good clarity, thick tan head with great retention.  Smoke and sausage come first in the flavor, followed by rich malts and moderate sweetness.  Rye bread and caramel, some light chocolate, some more smoke in the finish, light bitterness.  Medium-full body with medium carbonation, creamy mouthfeel.
UPDATED: AUG 12, 2015 Bottle. Dark brown colour with a tan head. Smoked nose. Sweet malt and smoked flavour.

Brown beer, like coke. Nice white head.
Lots of smoked ham on nose, woody, tar. Hints of licorice and caramel malt.
Like liquid smoked ham. Caramel tones balancing with pleasant amount of hops. Slightly roasted malt and licorice.
Full palate.
One of the classics and best smoked beers, canÂ’t wait the next bottle.
Bottle from Bierkompass web shop. Very dark brown color with huge fast-dissolving beige head. Aroma of smoked bacon or ribs.  Taste pretty the same with hints of caramel. Smoky, bitter finish.  Nice.

This one smells like smoked pulled pork, with lots of promising flavors and sweet notes here. The taste is a little lighter, with lots of smokey flavor and some sweet smoked ham all around the mouth. Leaves the mouth with a bitter and light mellow finish - very filling as well.

Bottle pour. Nose produced huge amounts of smoke paired with chocolatey and nutty malts. Like a good smoked meat fresh outta the smoker. Poured a dark, clear brown with a light tan head. Tasted very similar to the smell. Smoked meat galore. Pulled pork or smoked turkey. Very malty and nice. Great with some German cuisine.
Hazy yellow body, white head. Light smoky cereal aroma with meal. Taste is smokey, bitter, some mild. Aftertaste has fruity notes.

500ml bottle.

Pours dark brown in the glass but shows through a deep clear copper when held up to light.  There is a big fluffy beige head that recedes to a thin cap quickly.

The aroma is, typically, fantastic with a massive smoked wood character.  Some decent sweet malts and summer sausage.  Man do I love the nose on Schlenkerla beers.

The taste also starts with smooth smoked malts, lots of bacon and campfire.  Malts underneath to support the heavy smoke.  Very sweet but completely smoky.

Very smooth feel with solid carbonation.

Well, I feel like a Schlenkerla fanboy, but, damn, I love these smoked beers.  They are head and shoulders above everything other smoked beer out there.  So good.
Love this beer. ItÂ’s not for everyone, but if you enjoy a heavily smoked beer, then this is the champion of all!!! Great unique taste & flavor!!

Poured from a 16.9 ounce bottle into a New Belgium globe. 

Appearance: Pours a dark mahogany brown with ruby-orange highlights and a 1-2 finger foamy grey-tan head. Excellent head retention with head pooling on top in the middle. Nice lacing.

Smell: Wow, the smoke aroma is incredible. ItÂ’s like a bonfire being used to cook bacon. There is an undercurrent of dark fruity sweetness in there too.

Taste: Ashy taste up front reminiscent of the ash from an over-roasted marshmellow up front followed by a touch of dark fruit slipping through in the middle before ending with a strong punch of wood-fired smoke and a touch of hoppy bitterness. Aftertaste is sweetly smoky. 

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied with a decent amount of carbonation. Very smooth.

Drinkability: High drinkability. This would be perfect for a bonfire on a cool autumn evening.

Overall: Excellent beer overall. I am new to the world of Rauchbiers, but IÂ’ve liked what IÂ’ve had so far. I donÂ’t see how they can get much better than this. Highly recommended.

It pours a brown color into my nonic pint glass.  I has some reddish highlights along the edges of the glass.  There is a nice tan head that actually sticks around for a bit and leaves itÂ’s mark with some lacing on the glass.

The nose is packed full of smoke as you would think but there are some nice other notes in there.  There are notes of cherries and wood in there as well.

The taste starts off with a smoked hickory taste that gives a very bacon like taste.  There are some hints of maple in there to give some sweetness to it.  This is like a breakfast side in a glass.

Brown coloured with very little to no carbonation and a medium brown head. Very pronounced smokey, bacon aroma. Full light creamy palate; FInish is light bitter, very slightly malty roasted hinted with a clear and longer smokey finish. Very good.

Cask @ GBBF 2011. A black colored beer, with a beige head. The aroma of smoked malts with some notes of fruits. The taste of bitter smoked malts with fruits like citrus. The aftertaste is bitter with smoke.
Good maltiness mixed with smoke in the aroma and the flavor.  The smoke doesnÂ’t completely overwhelm the flavor, a very good beer all around.

On tap at the Great British Beer Festival 2011.  Almost black with a bit of red/brown when held up to the light.  Light amount of head.  Pleasant smokey, roasted aroma.  Obviously tastes smokey, but there is a bitterness and sweetness to it too.  Very good.

Bottle. Dark maroon with thin beige head. Aroma of chocolate malt, bologna, oak. Oak and smoked meat take centerstage with nutty malt notes maintained. Dark features mix well with the smoky meatiness. Completely different than a smoked porter, in a good way (though I like both).

Nearly black, very dark. Thinnish off white head. Aroma of smoke, damp cedar wood, and raw bacon.  Very pungent aroma, with a touch of sourness to it--not "sour beer" sour, just a smoke sour.  Pretty slick and oily ion the palate, but very coating all the same. Pretty strong flavor. Smoked malts, a bit of wood, and a big dose of bacon grease. Finished really smoky. Not too smokey to be disgusting, but enough to put off anyone who doesnÂ’t like the style. Pretty good all around, and flavorful. But you have to like the flavor.
Bottle (dmg note). Dark with a nice head. Smoke, smoke, smoke. Flavour is smoke with some freshness and a velvet palate. Great beer.

The aroma of this beer is so off the wall it has to be rated high. It has a ton of smoke along with some wood and a lot of alcohol. It looks quite nice, dark amber with a small off white head. The flavor though is a bit to much on the smoky side for my taste. Almost like a slim jim. Finishes very strong and long lasting. Good but not my favorite style.
UPDATED: DEC 25, 2011 Rerating 25.12.2011. Heavy smoky smell. Clear, dark brown with light brown head. Heavily smoky aroma. Faintly bitter, faintly sweet.

0.5l bottle @ Amundsen Bryggeri & Spiseri, Oslo. Then itÂ’s the UrbockÂ’s turn to enter my belly. Pours a clear dark ruby brown body with a big bubbly beige head. Aroma has notes of ash, sweet maltish, light caramel and light earthy. Average carbonation, oily texture and medium-bodied. Tastes also light ashy with notes of malts, leather, bacon and licorice and it has a really longlasting smoky and silky aftertaste. Almost to smoky, but still good stuff.

Bottle at Amundsen.
Dark brown body, thick low light brown head.
The smokey aroma can be sensed all around the table. It contains bacon, chocolate, campfire. 
As in the aroma the taste has a lot of bacon, chocolate and campfire, while joined by dark fruits and coffee in a pretty complex harmony.
Bacon, beer and chocolate at once, how can you not love it? :)

This poured a darker brown color with a small beige head. Aroma was thick thick smoke, campfire and smoked gouda with very light caramel malt there too. Flavor just straight liquid campfire and smokey cheese, light toasted malts there too. Great Stuff.
Bottle from Super Brugsen HÃ¸jby, Dark reddish colour with an off-white head. Aroma and flavour of malt, smoke and fruit.

Dark redish brown with a small off-white heaad. Smoke with malt tones. 
Malt, fruit and smoke. Medium body with a bittersweet finish.

Nach und nach kommt auch ein "normaler" Malzton auf, das Bier bleibt aber trotzdem stark rauchig. Im Hintergrund deutlich herb-bitter. Test vom 10.1.2008, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 12,11,11,14,13,13 - 12,45

Lots of smoke in the aroma, with a little bread/dough underneath.  Smoke follows through to the flavor, with a little sweetness, almost like a combination of beer and barbeque sauce.  Interesting beer, but letÂ’s just say I wouldnÂ’t want to choke down a six-pack.

On drafts. Appearance is dark brown with a tan head. Aroma is much like teryaki beef jerky. Taste reminds me of a smoky barbecue sauce. This is quite the beer experience,  but I wouldnÂ’t want to have more than half a bottle or so.

Bottle purchased from ChanÂ’s in Destin and poured into a Willibecher pint glass. Beautiful dark red with a big head that laces wonderfully. I immediately love the smell. Not so much bacon, but to me, smoked brisket. Smooth, malty, nice bitterness, surprisingly drinkable. I was intimidated by this style, but I am so happy to have finally gotten hold of one. Mouthfeel is remarkably lighter than I expected. Slightly oily, not extremely carbonated. Fairly clean and smoky finish and an absolutely delectable aftertaste. I will buy several next time I go to Destin.

A very good smoked beer that pours dark.  Smells like smoked wild game. Tastes very much like smoked meat.  The only negative on this is it is a little too bitter in the after taste and is why I prefer the Marzen over the urbock.

Had this my first time in Bamburg, Germany at a restaurant near the brewery about 6 years ago. I was with an older couple and they didnÂ’t want to eat around all the drunk people in the restaurant at the actual brewery. They did tell me that I had to get this beer and I have loved them for it ever since. The older gentleman that told me about it was too old to drink but had to have a sip none the less. One of my favorite beers to smell and of COURSE drink. It smells and drinks like liquid sausage. This  brewery is king of the smoked beers. IÂ’ve had many delicious ones from various other major breweries as well as all their other beers all of which are smoked but nothing comes close to the flavor of the Schlenkerla Urbock, Their Marzen is a good substitute if this isnÂ’t around but if you want a meal in a bottle this is the one! IÂ’ve been happy that this beer has been easier and easier to find. When I started working for Union Distributors, I was flabbergasted that we help distribute this awesome beer. This is in my top 3. Check out Sunturnbrew for another good smoked beer (one of the only smoked barely wines) or SchlenkerlaÂ’s Oak Smoked.  I buy this in my neighborhood at either Eagle Provisions (one of my favorite beer stores) or Bierkraft.
Bevuta a Les Vignerons,miglior birra mai bevuta in assoluto.Da non perdere!

500ml bottle. Pours a dark mahogany colour with average tan head that dissipates quickly and leaves little lace. Good and smoky on the nose with an almost gamy feel. ThereÂ’s some heavily suppressed fruit and maybe a nutty note? Fairly light on the palate with the smoke dominating all facets. ThereÂ’s a touch of sweetness in there and a nice fruity note across the mid-palate. Really easy drinking with a semi-sweet smoky finish.
Pour is rather dark with a light tan head. Nose is of campfire and smoke. Taste is purely the same and the most honestly smoked beer in the category.
From smoke tasting with the Liquor Loft crew:  bacon meaty smoked aroma.   big malty smoke taste.  not my thing, but interesting nonetheless.  6.8

500mL bottle.  Pours clear dark brown with a thin off-white head.  Aroma of smoked meats, a little malt and some dark fruit.  Flavour of malt, some dark fruit, smoked and chargrilled meats and alcohol.  Light-medium body, average carbonation and a slightly burnt finish.
50cl bottle @ Les Vignerons (Rome). I thought the MÃ¤rzen was the best beer of all time, before trying the Urbock. Same aroma, with more alcohol.
this beer tastes like bacon. smoked aroma slight meat. slight pork and smoke flavor. i guess this is the best for what it is, not my bag though.

Just tried this beer for the first time...about an hour ago. CanÂ’t say i would recommend it. ItÂ’s not a great drinking beer (unless you really like smoked beer). But it wasnÂ’t awful either. I marinated some pork chops with it. They came out okay but i had to add some bar-b-que sauce...which tasted great together with the beer flavor!
I wouldnÂ’t drink it again, but i might cook with it again.

Draft pour at Prost in Portland, Oregon, This was basically a copper to brown color with a nice fat off-white head. Nose is very smokey.  Medium body and nice clean mouthfeel. Flavor is like licking the inside of  a fireplace,  Actually a delightful taste, with a remarkable amount of flavors mixed in the smoke, Dry finish. Wonderful brew.

50cl bottle. Pours a chestnut colour with a red hue, steady bubbles and a good head. The nose is smokey and perhaps a bit chocolately. The taste is creamy with a slight hint of chocolate but the overwhelming and lasting taste is the smokiness which lends a little to smoked cheese. The palate is big in structure, creamy in texture with good refreshment though I have to say that the smokey finish leaves  something that reminds me of an oak chip in the back of my throat. Overall, a classic beer but not as drinkable as some of the every day beers.

500 ml bottle purchased at Lukas in Kansas City, Missouri. The pour is almost clear brown, copper and ruby with a frothy two inch head. Thick coating lacing is left behind. The aroma is campfire smoke, fresh cut wood and smoked ham. There is also a light nutty sweetness, though this is certainly behind the smoke. Its a very natural, engaging nose. The taste is the nose, mildly sweet smoked ham up front, followed by dting campfire and finishing with a flinty charred woody smoke. The finish is dry and clean, what lingers of the smoke is soft and pleasant.  The palate is medium bodied, nice active carbonation and the dry finish. This really is a classic beer.

In the glass deep, almost black with a high, long-life creamy head. The smell is smoky and pleasantly like smoked ham. Starts smoky, not quite as intense as the MÃ¤rzen, but again more intensive than the Lagerbier. A subtly sweet note played with in the background. The taste is licorice, bitter coffee, similar to a good Porter. The best Schlenkerla beer so far!
Strong smokey malte aroma. Dark-Brown. Round well balanced brew with oak flavours. A little sweetness to control the smoke into a horney like taste. One of my first smoked beers but not the last.

Im Geruch wird der malzige Grundton von Buchenholzrauch und RÃ¤ucherschinken Ã¼berlagert - dennoch angenehm. Sofort rauchiger Einstieg. Die Rauchigkeit hÃ¤lt sich auch in der Mitte konstant. Hier kommen aber verstÃ¤rkt malzige und fruchtige Noten hervor. Im Abschied dann starkes Rauchschinkenaroma in dem malzig-sÃ¼ÃŸliche Noten schwimmen. Im Nachhall leicht alkoholisch. Sehr gelungene Rauchbiervariante!

500 ml bottle from hi time. Pours a hazy dark brown color with a medium beige head that has good retention and some minor lacing. The aroma is rich with multilayered smoke  evoking memories of Cedarburg summer sasuage and other rich smokehouse flavors. The taste is similar to the aroma, lots of rich smokey flavors. The palate is full and smooth with soft carbonation. Finishes long and dry. Overall: First rate smoked beer.

Dark brown/black color; Medium creamy body; Aroma of rich smoked meat, & burnt oak; Flavor of smoky/roasted sweet malt, caramel, light chocolate, and some salt; Finish is slightly bitter; Nicely balanced; As with other Schlenkerla brews, the aroma is awesome - excellent brew overall.

Amber brown in the glass with a thinnish tan head.  Aroma is wonderful deep and malted smoke, bacon, sizzle, and char.  Taste follows the aroma with well-integrated smoke and roasted malt throughout.  The best smoked beer I have had yet.  Soft feel in the mouth.  Amazing.

Pours clear red-brown with a light tan head.  Strong smokey aroma with some peatiness underneath.  A little thin in the mouth, but deep.  Taste is smoky with a mild caramelly sweetness in the background.  As it warms, takes on a bit of a nutty character.  Very unique and tasty, but at the same time, not something IÂ’d drink regularly.  From personal experience, this also makes an excellent base for a pot of chili.

50cL bottle at Ã˜lbar in Copenhagen. Smells smoky with a bit of vanilla. Taste is smoky with a bit of licorice, chocolate and vanilla. Well balanced -- the smokiness is not overpowering but rather complements the rest of the beer. The finish is a bit dry -- otherwise very creamy. Full bodied with a bit of malt sweetness. Very good.

Oh my goodness this is smokey.  Smell is heavenly.  Like a smokey bacony awesomeness.  I am using this beer to marinade some steak and drinking some too :)  Taste is smokey too!  I recommend this beer to any bacon lovers out there!
good taste, light percentage, prononced aroma, no long after taste like belgian ales but itÂ’s german hÃ© ;-), and just the best "Rauch" taste in the world

Moderate sized pale tan head somewhat lasting like an oil slick. Deep red/brown colour. Wow, thats different; aroma of smokey cheese with some smoked bacon and sausage (didnt think it would be true), not too strong, still pleasant. Taste initially a mix of malt with smoke - seperate rather than entwined. Extremely long smooth smokey finish. A little oily on palate and tightly fizzy. My first rauchbier: strong, drinkable, interesting, and for me something to enjoy infrequently.

Bottle @ Cask Pub and Kitchen in London. Pours a dark brown color with a slightly tan head. Aroma is very bacon and meat like, with alot of bonfire smoke, toasted malt and wood. The flavor is very smokey filled with bacon and smoked meats, along with wood, bonfire, peat, toasted malt and some faint caramel notes. The body is medium with a creamy mouthfeel. Overall one of the best smoke beers I have had!

6 dec 2010, bottle. dark brown almost black and clear. nose is all smoke, no sausage, and much fainter than the nose of the marzen. thin/med body and not very fizzy, kind of syrupy. taste is thin smoke w/ some italian sausage as well. nose and taste are much more subtle than the marzen. flavour is subtle but longer finish. i prefer the marzen.

Draught. Dark brown, thick beige head. Malty nose, pronounced smoke, tar, wood, caramel, cured bacon, spicy, faintly hoppy. Dry, with a hint of residual sweetness, full bodied, medium bitterness. Very rich and complex, malty flavour, pronouncedly smokey, cured bacon, spicy, herbal, tar, iodine, extremely well balanced. Lingering, very smokey finish. (2010-11-28)
Aroma of peat and Bacon.  Dark and redish in color.  Tastes roasty and malts with heavy smoke.  Decent balance of smoke and malts but I am not a fan overall.

Bottle from Zly Casy bottleshop, Prague. Pours dark ruby with a big creamy off-white head. Aroma of campfire and light smoked bacon. Taste is smooth caramel, the smoke is well integrated here, good and full bodied as this beer is. Lingering malty aftertaste, a real treat. Better and better for each mouthfull.

Annak ellenÃ©re, hogy finom, nem az Ã©n vilÃ¡gom. Randi elÅ‘tt kerÃ¼lendÅ‘! :-)

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2013 Bottle @ Hessen Haus. Pours a reddish brown appearance with a light brown head. Smoky/meaty, charred, woody, toasty chocolate/caramel malty, somewhat herbal nose. Really a rich, burnt dark chocolate malty, caramel, somewhat meaty smoky, a bit ashy, somewhat woody flavor. Yummy.

The taste and smell are amazing. There is smokiness with a bit of pork, like smoked sausage. The flavor is not overwhelming though and would allow you to drink a couple of these without killing your tastebuds.

There was a time when I was scared of the uber smoked beers of Aecht Schlenkerla.  No longer.  The aroma is intense smokiness of the highest order.  It is seriously hard to get any other notes because of the power of the smoke.  They must have brewed this thing over smoked coals for many hours.  Flavor is not quite as intense as the nose, but still not for the faint of heart.  An underlying sweetness which makes this beer quite drinkable.  Quite a treat and IÂ’m so glad I have acquired the taste for the smoked.  Impressive beer for sure.

As soon as this was poured I smelled chicken wings. Aroma is smoked ham and smoked ham. The flavor is indescribable. It is like smoked salmon and a smoked ham had a love child. There is a slight brown sugar sweerness, but it is pretty much all savory. Ooh, sooo good.

bottle ... Deep amber pour , dark beige head , excellent lace . Aroma is smoke and malt sweetness . Flavor is a wonderful smoky sweetness . Notes of caramel , bacon and wood . Medium bodied , low carbonation . Complex and wonderful .

500ml bottle.

It pours a deep brown with a fizzy off-white head that leaves spots of lacing as it recedes.

The smell is sweet and smoky. The smoke is like campfire almost with a burnt scent while the sweet malt adds an almost fruitiness to the brew along with the hops.

The flavor follows. It has more of an earthy flavor with the smoke mixing with the bitterness of the hops. It still sweet and malty though and that provides the balance.

This is the quintessential Rauchbier.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-09-2011 04:19:46

Bottle, courtesy of Yngwie. Pours a deep, wooden brown body with a small white head. Aroma is smokey caramel tones, hints of tar and smoked meat. Nice. Taste is equally nice, with smokey sausages, leather, hints of ash and general smoke. Mmmm...so much smoke. Me like. Moreover, the body of the urbock version provides a lot more space for all the flavors and aroma to live in; itÂ’s just what this beer needs and a tiny improvement from the already grand MÃ¤rzen version. A truly great smoked, original German style.

UPDATED: APR 11, 2011 500ml = 1pt .09 FL OZ = 16.09 FL OZ = big bottle.  ItÂ’s a lot of beer.  Pours an explosive but fast-dissolving sandy head over an attractive, dark reddish, body that shines around the edges.
Aroma is smoked fish and woody with some pork.  It doesnÂ’t get much better.
Taste is similar to the odor but much less so.  Salty, light sweetness that vanishes abruptly to a bitter finish.  Savor the very good, classic beer taste.
Urbock has a medium to full body, sticky, small bubble carbonation yet lively, 
I really enjoy this smokebeer.
Very strong smoky flavors, almost like bacon. I really like smoke flavors but it takes over the brew and you really canÂ’t taste much of the bock beer.

Colour... golden brown with a thin head. Nose... LIQUID BAND-AIDS! Palate... Good goy, Rob Roy! This is like a Lagavulin impersonating a beer! Holy Islay! Someone mustÂ’ve invited Ardbeg, Bowmore, Laphroaig  to the brewery as well! Smoke, bonfire, peat, phenols, brine, smoked kippers,  smoked salmon, ham, roast beef, roast beast, hickory smoked bacon, Jimmy Dean sausage and the rest of the butcher shop thrown in for good measure! Skip the amino acid drink: this is meat in a glass!!

Quite light in colour for a porter, though still a dark red/brown. The aroma has an immediate impact - feels like a smokehouse full of hams! I have no other way to descripe it other then drinking a smoked ham. The taste is that abrubt.

500 ml Bottle - Pour is deep brown/reddish with a little off-white head that disappears quickly.  Aroma is huge smoke, bacon, ham, other smoky meats, dark malt, sweetness, caramel, toffee, woody/earthy.  The beer is mildly sweet/malty upfront - which immediately gives way to a sharp smoky/meaty center.  The end is bit bitter and the smokiness lasts forever on your tongue.  Literally tastes like bacon or smoked ham, obviously this is an acquired taste.  I have acquired said taste, however.  Mouthfeel is medium, carbonation is a bit on the higher end (the one characteristic IÂ’m not crazy about) I like this a lot - I think the Eiche Doppelbock by Schlenferla is a better beer overall - but this can definitely hold its own.  It is much smokier than the Marzen, quite a bit smokier than the Lager and of course, much more full-bodied and thicker - itÂ’s almost on par with the Doppelbock, which I think is a bit more balanced and complex.  If you are interested in Rauchbiers (Smoke Beers) this and the other Schlenferla brews are must haves.
interesting smoke aroma with a  strong caramel and molasses backing. a little bitter, moderate sweetness. decent

500ml bottle.  Deep chestnut amber-brown.  Creamy beige head.  Smoky chocolate aroma.  An absolute masterpiece of a beer.  Sweet smoky burnt chocolate tones.  Deep fruity undercurrents, a touch pungent, not unlike a Foreign Stout at times.  Fluffy on the palate, smooth body, easy drinking despite the massive flavor.  Smoky burnt caramel aftertaste.

Dark orange-brown pour.  A bit sweet.  Slightly watery.  Lots of smoke and meat.  Bitter finish.  Goes down pretty easy.  Had side by side with the marzen and doppelbock.  Not as dry and flavorful as the marzen.

Medium dark clear brown, white head.  Strong ham-like smoke aroma. Moderately sweet malty flavor loaded with lots of bacony smoke and a slightly floral vegetal note near the finish.  ThereÂ’s a touch of charred roasted malt flavor lurking there as well.  Nice, this breweryÂ’s tasty smoked beers are definitely one of my favorite German imports.

Poured into a stange.

4.5 A: Clear mahogany color. Three fingers of sticky frothy/creamy hybrid head with excellent retention and lots of randomly placed lacing.

4.0 S: Smoke, smoKE, smOKE, sMOKE SMOKE! This smells like a campfire or, more precisely, oneÂ’s clothes the day after hanging out by a campfire. Underlying malt is pretty hard to pick out, but I think IÂ’m getting bready malts.

3.5 T: The smoke is nearly as aggressive in the taste as well. ItÂ’s perhaps too smoky for my tastes, but itÂ’s still a well crafted beer. Anyway, campfire smoke, musky dankness, toffee, and some crystal sweetness.

4.0 M: Medium body, yet thereÂ’s a large thick and chewy aspect. Carbonation is good, but a little aggressive. I imagine this is as smooth as a Rauch will get.

3.5 D: This is my first true Rauchbier and itÂ’s quite a ride. The smoke flavor is massive and I probably wasnÂ’t prepared. IÂ’ll try to find a bunch more of these, then come back to this one and see if I feel any different about it.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-06-2010 02:47:39
Clear dark red brown with beige head. Aroma and flavor are dominated completely by smoke and smoked ham. There is a medium sweetness as well followed by a smooth finish. 150111

Tasted with Azlondon 26.12.2010, itÂ’s getting very late now!

Black with a small head. Smoke, smoke and roasted smokey malt, but still quite sweet. NICE

Been here, Bamberg, the old city is very beautifull, so this brand means something special to me. Because first time I hated it, now iÂ’m always looking forward to Aecht Schlenkerla Rauchbier!! Cool name also!

UPDATED: NOV 24, 2011 Bottle @ home. Aroma is huge smoky with bacon and other smoked meats/fish roasted malt, some ashes. Very nice.Flavour is roasty smoky meaty goodness. Thinner palate than expected. Great stuff.

500ml bottle. Small, relatively loose & slowly fading light tan head leaving a light lace atop a clear, deep mahogany ruddy-brown body. Bacon, latakia tobacco, wood and lapsang souchong tea aromas with a hint of fruit eventually coming through as it warmed. Salty bacon predominantly - initially at least - with roasted malt tones progressing to a lingering smoked malt, burnt toast bitterness. Quite a dry lapsang & peatiness in the aftertaste with a gentle fruitiness too. As it opened up a balancing, almost chocolatey malty sweetness came through before the bitterness kicked in, softening & rounding it out on the tongue. Medium body with a minor initial warmth in the throat. Medium carbonation adds further dryness on the palate. Complex without becoming overbearing.

The most confronting beer IÂ’ve ever tried. This brewerys reputation precedes it and the first beer can be an intimidating and overwhelming experience. However if you can get past the first half glass or so this beer is very rewarding and as smooth as silk. This is one big beer with a stong personality and I admit that its not for everyone although I loved it...

Courtesy of Nordcore, thanks!
Appearance: Dark brown, clear. Some tan head.
Aroma: Smoke, roasted. Bacon and malt.
Taste: Dark malt, roasted. Coffee/chocolate.
Info: 500ml bottle, 26/12-2010

Schlenkerla urbock. 500ml bottle purchased from west lakeview... Pours  
a dark chocolate reddish brown pour with a quickly dissipating barely  
off-white head... Smoked meats and campfire essence in the aroma with  
a grainy sweet malt backbone... Flavors are less smokey with a sweeter  
malt presence through the middle. Smoked malts return towards the  
finish but then succumb again to the grainy sweetness. Smooth body  
that also extends to the carbonation level. All-around nice quality  
smoked.
8/4/7/4/14

Just a wonderful companion to SchlenkerlaÂ’s smoked octoberfest. I like to start with their smoked helles, move on to the Marzen, and finish with this bad boy. Lots of acrid beechwood smoke balanced with some malt sweetness, which has some nice raisony, toasty and woody flavors, hints of chocolate, leather, and chestnuts. The smoke might be a bit strong for some, but for me its just right.

~dr

Bottle from Beer Ritz, Leeds. Very dark brown pour with a beige head. Smoke, wood, malts, raisins and chocolate aromas with some light caramel notes. Flavours of woodsmoke, raisins, chocolate, burnt caramel. Beautifully balanced. Bitter-sweet and dry finish. Classic.

With the aroma ofsmoked meets IÂ’m kicking off the New Year with this amazing beer. The color is dark red brown with an off white smokey lacing. The palate a little thin up front with mild maltiness. The flavor has mild bitters but is smooth and crisp overall. The smokiness continues throughout the entire drinking process and last forever. Happy New Year to BEER!!!

Bottle 50cl. A brown beer with medium head. Smell is on smoked notes. Aroma is quite sweet, on a good brown ale basis with caramel and malt sugar body. Smoked flavor is there but not too heavy, properly balanced with the alcohol and the malt body, just spicy, near to old porter like beer, very nice and a bit creamy. Good spicy hops at the finish, very pleasant and balanced beer, quite complex and easy drinkable, a very good brew.

Aggressive. Dark red/brown colored with a light brown head. Strong smoked aroma, peat, malt, strong alcoholic hints, and light sweetness.
Intense taste and mouthfeel, with an average bitterness. 
Not so full body, but very long mouthfeel. 
Challenging beer, but very good.

500ml bottle from Alko

Great smoked beer with a medium body and a great taste. Not too sweet or strong, well balanced. Goes nicely with christmas ham.
on tap in ZlÃ½ Äasy prague, very nice rauch aroma, dark, stable brown head, nice smoked bitterness, medium sweetness, full body, slick, strong beer, nice expierience
user_location: Cambridge and Kladno(Czech Rep.), Cambridgeshire, ENGLAND

text: One of my favourite beers. Really rich, smoky aroma and taste. Not too heavy but still really tasty.
UPDATED: FEB 22, 2012 Bottle.Chestnut red with a small head,aroma of,...................ItÂ’s just great stuff.

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2011 Bottle 500ml @ fonefan
Pours clear reddish brown with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of smoke, sweet malt and caramel. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.
Bottle from FOneFan. Clear brown with small head. Flavour is malt, caramel, sweet with massiv smoke.
Bottle at fonefan tasting. Nice head with good duration. Color is brown. Aroma and taste are rich smoke, salami, bacon, malt and hops.

Bottle. Deep dark brown with an off-white head. Powerful aroma of smoked bacon. Creamy roasted malt with a sweetish start and hint of dry caramel, rasher finish. Long lingering palate. Very satisfying experience.

This is one beautiful beer!  Super dark amber, like a fine piece of antique furniture.  An aroma like a old smoke house.  Off white head.  Very smokey malt flavor, not sweet.  Medium thick mouth feel, slightly hoppy after taste.  If you like Rauchbier you need to try this!

Appearance: deep dark browns and polished mahoganies. Soft light khaki head retains an almost mousse-like texture even after fading into a thick blanket. Swirls with a touch of lace.

Nose: sweet mesquite smoke. Like standing in front of a campfire, the richness of burning woods as flames crackle and lick at her fuel while smoke wafts through the air. Pumpernickel breads mingle with dark fruit pits. Black earth. Burnt dark sugar sweetness.

Palate: smooth, rich, and soft. Definite a rich breadiness permeated with mesquite, smoke, and a hint of chocolate cake. Smoke permeates and soothes each aspect of her palate; front, middle, back, finish. Burnt charcoal and burnt mesquite strongest in the back. Red plums flitter through the front and middle, mingling with a kiss of candied apple skins. The chocolate cake underneath is subtle and solid; a pleasant addition. Only lightly dries my palate.

Final Thoughts: ever since my first smoked beer, the Marzen from this particular brewery, I have been in love with Rauch beers. Subtle and in your face at the same time, whatÂ’s not to love about something which oozes cozy fireside tenderness with a hint of old time charm. Personally, thereÂ’s everything to love, and so I do.

From 500 ml bottle, picked up from Heritage Liquors in Maplewood, MN. Pours a semi-clear dark brownish copper colored brew with a thick and lumpy off-white that has some excellent retention and lots of lacing. Aroma of smoked bacon and beef jerky, a hint of peat, and caramel malt. Taste is medium bodied, flavors of smoked bacon, caramel malt, a hint of chocolate, iodine and some peat. Finish is semi-sweet, more smoked bacon and lard with more caramel malt aftertaste. Must try this with my beer bread recipe.

Bottle.  Pours a ruby brown with beige head that dissipates rather quickly with little lacing.  Nose is bread malt and hickory smoke. Taste is toasted bread malt with a nice balanced hops note fading into the smoke flavor.  Excellent unique and well balanced beer.

A: poiurs a beautiful rusty garnett with a nice off-white head and a good amount of lacing.

S: great smoky character atop plenty of wood and a bit of sweetness. Fairly one dimensional but itÂ’s definitely done right.

T: smoke and almost a bit of gamey meat. Another impressive smoked beer from the folks over at Heller Trum.

M: a little bit on the thin side for flavors this full.

D: a great beer for a few ounce glass, but a little more than that (especially without an accompanying food pairing) and this will get overwhelming.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-07-2010

[Tap] Pours a dark shade of brown with about a half inch of tan head. Strong smoky aroma of smoked meats, peat and charred wood. Grilled ham and bacon in the taste. Heavy malty backbone includes molasses and burnt bread. Salty notes come out in the finish especially. This beer is much fuller in body than some of the other varieties I have had from this brewer. Strong roasted and charred malt finish. YouÂ’ll be tasting this beer for hours after youÂ’re finished. Pretty tasty.

Bottle 50 cl. Pours very darkbrown almost black color with a beige somewhat fluffy head. Aroma is smoked bacon and tar, some sweetness and more smoke again. Flavour is a smooth combination of tar and smoked bacon. Aftertaste is very rich, warm and smoky. Great beer.

Enjoyed from a 16.9oz bottle in a pub glass.  The beer pours a deep brown color, with a small to moderate tan head.  The nose initially shows smoke and bacon-esque notes almost exclusively, before German character malts become more evident.  Complex and extremely appetizing.  The palate shows a medley of flavors, with rich malt flavors coming through initially, and the rauchmalt making itself felt toward the mid-palate and finish.  The latter lasts for several pleasurable moments.  Carbonation heightens the flavors without interfering with them.  Overall, perhaps a beer that is not for everyone, but beautifully complex and highly enjoyable.
Richer aroma and flavor than the marzen.  Still lots of sweet smoked malt of course, just more intense.
Dark brown beer with light brown head. Smoked ham and bacon aroma. Smoky and roasted malt flavour. Somewhat dry and sour. Drinking this is like consuming liquid smoked ham.

Bottle, 
has a clear dark pour (that is a clear, dark ruby when held up to a light) and gave a two to three finger high head of off-white bubbles, 

this beer had aromas of camp fire smoke, oily wood smoke, fire place smoke with faint malt in the background, 

there were flavors of oily wood smoke, camp fire smoke, bread malt in the background, and there is a little malt sweetness, 

mouth feel is a touch less than medium, 

a beer with lots of smoke influences, a nice beer.

The aroma of this beer is quite smokey and reminded me of smelling the clothes you wore at a camp fire the night before.  Luckily it tasted better than that.  The smoke flavor was very strong on the first couple of sips but mellowed after that.  A very unique beer.

Â£1 bottle from Dranken Geers- at home in requisite Schlenkerla glass, naturally. Cola brown with a fine, subsiding beige collar. Smoked mackerel with black peppercorn aroma, crumbled with Allsorts. Has a smoked mackerel lightly spread with Nutella sort of character; less smoky, sweeter, more bitter and more chocolatey than expected. Quite a roasted, liquorice finish, with a bit of an annoying sweetener or chiccory-type bitterness that clings more than the smoke. Good but feels a bit processed, and probably much better from the wood...

dark color of molases. nearly no head. nose is purely campfire with light detectable malt in behind the smoke. Taste starts malty sweet then fades to a wonderful smoke reminding you of smoked meats and outings around the fire with friends. Sweetness does not linger. fantastic

500 ml bottle from The Royale.  Pours a clear deep mahogany, awesome color, with a small beige head.  Aroma of campfire, smoked meat, roasted malts, and toast.  Flavor of roasted malts and smoked meat- pretty similar to the nose- with a lingering ashy finish.  Medium-bodied, with mild carbonation and a smoky mouthfeel.  Certainly lives up to its big and smoky reputation.  I liked this about the same as the marzen, and probably would have liked that one better if not for its metallic note.
Fragrance reminiscent of a tarred boat. Flavor is soft and smoky and have elements of malt, tar and sausage. Nice!

From the cask @ Schlenkerla in Bamberg. Dark with a off-white head. Nice smoky tone, with some caramel and chocolate notes. The beer is sweet but not cloying, at least for me as my fellow guys donÂ’t feel the same. A lovely strong wintry brew.

Bottle, German club, Brisbane
Deep hazy bronze body with tan head.
Punch in the face of smoke! Smoked meats, charcoaled wood with good support of rich mollasses malts.
Texture is truely thick and sticky with carbonation spot on and tremendous length without any sort of harshness.
Once again, the flavour of smoke just hits you like a hurricane; bacon, charcoal, chocolate, roasted nuts, rich caramel, dense bread packing plenty of sweetness without being cloying. Finishes dry, smokiness lingers in the best way possible.
Tremendous smoked beer, best of the range with just a huge amount of body and complexity. Certainly not for everyone, but certainly up my alley!
