Bottle.  Pours a deep, dark brown....smells like a campfire....literally.  Smells like a fire.  Some background coffee and hidden sweetness.  I like it....not something I could drink every day, but a good beer.
Nose of sweet smoke, weak bacon, frankinscence, light body, medium carb, taste is smoke, walnut, blood
Trovata in un negozietto a Berlino; Ã¨ piÃ¹ dolce e alcolica della Marzen con lo stesso livello di affumicamento. Molto buona

Grazie marcot (L); la Urbock di Schlenkerla Ã¨ una birra robusta, con dolcezza piÃ¹ spiccata che contrasta lÂ’affumicato e al tempo stesso vi si sposa in un perfetto amalgama. Meno estrema della Marzen proprio per questo, altrettanto eccezionale.

Wow, what an interesting beer!

A- color was a clear red to medium brown. Two finger head that stayed for a good while. Ample carbonation

S- This is the interesting part. It smelled like a roasted pig in a campfire with burning and browning meat. ItÂ’s was almost like taking a whiff in a beef jerky bag. Intense!

T- I was expecting a very strong flavor but was pleasantly surprised by a sweet but meaty malt flavor with earthy and smokey tones. 

M- Chewy highly carbonated smokey feel

D- This is my first experience with a rauchbier and it was very enjoyable. I canÂ’t say I will be craving this type of beer every week, but I will definitely try this beer again.

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2011 500 ml bottle. Rated @ 21.3.2009.
Pours a beautiful black colour with a brownish head. Aroma of excellent Bamberg smokiness, bread, rye and roasted malts. Flavour of smoked malts, burnt wood, leather and mild coffee. Full bodied and a very pleasant slicky mouthfeel. Top 10. (10-4-9-4-17)
500 ml bottle.
Pours a beautiful dark brown colour with a firm, creamy, thick head. Good retention. Aroma of smoked wood, birch leaves and smoked ham. Flavour of sweet smoked malts, birch leaves, sweet dried fruits, quite bitter hops and loads of smoked wood too. Full bodied, thick mouthfeel and a lovely smooth, dry, smoked finish. Not as good as I remembered, but still one of the best smoked beers. Eiche is better, though.

Wow that is something amazing. Pours a very dark clear amber with medium but strong creamy head. Aroma is in your face, with big notes of chocolate and smoked pork.  For such a smokey aroma the flavor is quite balanced and by such i mean that malt sweetness and light bitterness is not completely blown away by smokey character.  Full bodied but has a very thin mouth feel ending very smoothly with just the right aftertaste.

Amazing beer. Pours amber with medium off-white head. Aroma is of bacon and chocolate. The taste is similar. Very smoky and bacony, with chocolate, some toasted malt and hints of coffee. Nothing about this beer is bad from start to finish. ItÂ’s unique though and I could understand some people not enjoying. But if you want chocolate covered bacon that you can drink until drunk, then this is your beer.

500 ml bottle purchased a year ago at Total Wine in Tustin ($4.79).  Pours a deep lovely garnet color with one finger of beige foam.  Aroma full of old leather horse saddles, liquid smokiness, bacon, smoked jerky.  Flavor also full of thick campfire smoke, leather, charred wood, and chewy baked beans cooked over the campfire.  There are also some dark fruit notes hidden amongst all the smoke.  There is even a bit of sweetness emerging late in the flavor.  Surprisingly light mouthfeel considering the intensity in both the nose and flavor.  This will go quite well with the grilled pork chops that I am about to heat up.  (900, 379)
Pours a mahogany color with a slightly off-white head.  Aroma of smoke and nothing else.  Lots of smoke and roasted malt flavor with some pear flavor to sweeten it out.  Really good beer!

Pours dark amber with ivory head. Medium bodied with soft carbonation, great earthy mouthfeel. Smoky nose. Flavor of smoke, peat, roasted malts. A little too smoky  for me for stand alone drinking, but awesome with bbq.

Clear brown pour with little off white head.  Intense smokey aroma, roasted malt, reminds me of bacon drenched in maple syrup. Similar taste, smoky up  front and smoky all the way through to the bitter end.  Medium bodied.  Smooth and easy to drink, a higher abv version of this would kick ass.

Pours dark brown with just a touch of red. Smells smokey as hell, bacon, pork rinds, beef jerky, and rich rib yumminess. Tastes malty and medium rich. Smoother than I expected. Not nearly as smokey on the palate as it is on the nose. I like it. WouldnÂ’t want a lot of this though.
Pours a tan head with a brown body.  Aromas of bacon and brown sugar.  Flavor is much, much the same.  Great palate.   ThatÂ’s some smoke.

Been scared of this one for a while.
Pours dark copper with an off-white creamy head leaving great lacing.
Most prominent aroma is of course the smoky character, seemingly mixing smoked almonds with smoked ham. Very nice! Underneath is a lot of caramel malt, but this beer is definately more focused on the smoke.
As a flavour, its even more noticeable, very woody. Accompanying it is some nice caramel that just canÂ’t keep up with the smoke. Grassy and spicy hops are also noticeable, contributing a mild but pleasant bitterness.
Carbontion is just a little too high in my opinion.
Pleansantly surprised with this, I really liked it!
Found this when I found the Four Firkins. Great store, great beer. The smoke is so smooth, such deep hardwood and roasted malt. Not a bad price for this luxury. Need to buy again.
UPDATED: AUG 26, 2010 From a bottle,dark red,brownish head,taste like bacon (very strong flavor), Smokey,medium body,It take a couple sips to get use to.

A: snifter. Rich mahogany color, rubyesque. Nice tan head. Good retention and light lacing.

S: wonderful aromas of smoked bacon and some apples.

T: great smoked cured pork, with the sweet urbock apple and pear notes.

M: medium mouthfeel. Great body. Mild carbonation level.

D: all I need is a platter of pulled pork and some sweet BBQ sauce

Tap. Finger of lightly tan head, deep, dark copper brown color.  Beachwood, and loads of smoke. Woody and burning.  Smoke is the key here, roatsted, woodsy finish.  Just awesome.  What an inspiration of a brew.

Bottle: Disclamer-  my first "smoke". Pours a dark amber, with a thin head. Smell. well  - so this is a smoked beer. Flavor starts the same as well - the smoked element dominates at times. I noticed also, the flavors of a good roasted ham, perhaps, with a touch of sweetness. I have to say I enjoyed it overall, though more than others in my party.

This was my first time having a smoke beer, and I was pleasantly surprised.  Initially starts off sweet,  with a bitter finish, and smoky throughout.  Medium body with a slightly oily feel.    This is definitely different, the smell and taste of smoke is very strong, but the taste is very smooth and flavorful.  I would recommend trying this at least once.

1pt9floz bottle. 6.5% ABV. Pours deep opaque amber with ruby tinge. Head, light tan of average stature. Aromas of smoked ham with light sweet caramel malt. Medium chewy mouthfeel, hop flavours shine through the semi-sweet light medium carbonated body. Smoked flavours and aromas are there but to a lesser extent than the marzen, with the malt sweetness and some roastyness coming through well with the hop flavour and bitterness. Hop flavours seem to linger a touch longer than usual, combining with a complex finish of smoke, sweetness, savoury flavours and a touch of bitterness.
Man, itÂ’s just so good. Sippin on a campfire. Plenty oÂ’ ratings, nuff said.

Draught at Churchkey, courtesy of Nahem - thank you sir!  Clearish maroon color, small white head.  Aroma of BACON!!!  Taste has lots of dark roasted malt, and chestnuts roasted on an open fire.  Delicious.  Violates the reinheitzgebot, but who cares!

By far the best Smokebeer I have ever had. Mouthwatering smokey smell, almost toasty. Dark brown/black in color with a Creamy head. It tastes as good as it smells, refreshingly smoked. Great with smoked salmon lax and bagels.

Appearance:  dark brown, with ruby-to-gold notes at the edge; short white bubbly head that fades to a collar with good lacing.  Aroma:  like a campfire--WOW--, and a little like beef jerky; thereÂ’s a note of sweet malted dark grains in there somewhere.  Taste:  liquid smoke, roasted tree bark, well-done steak; smoky bitterness gives way to a hint of sweetness.  Finish:  short and dry, but the smoke lingers.  Of course it does.  Notes:  Very interesting beer.  Love the uniqueness of the flavors, but didnÂ’t actually care for the beer all that much.  However, IÂ’d recommend it to anyone, just for the experience.  Who knew beer could even taste like this?  This should be the official beer of camping.

Shared with potbeercollege. Bottle. Poured a dark cocacola color.  aroma: was big smokey, bacon fat, smokehouse.  taste:  similar to aroma, but deeper and richer smokey flavors, taste the bacon, caramelized sweetness.

My notes are not detailed enough, but this was beautiful.  Big smoke aroma, like a campfire bbq, toasty and roasty flavor - if any beer could be called meaty this is the one.  This is one of those brews that reminds me why I drink beer.
bottle.  campfire, tuna, jerky, doughy chocolate.  smoked salmon.   neat.

Bottled. Shared with Hatchattack. Brown and red/orange with thin but lasting tan head. Aroma is sausage and bacon grease with seasoning like the seasoning smoked out the kitchen and the windows were closed. Flavor follows with malty goodness sweet, burnt caramels, a little oaky, and all good. Finish goes lightly more bitter and lightly dry, still that grease. Caramelized bacon.
ItÂ’s like drinking a Summer BBQ in a bottle.  Tastes of smoke and BBQ meats.  Very interesting, almost shocking at first.  Definitely worth trying, but once is probably enough.

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2010 Aroma of hickory, bacon and campfire with sweet malt undertones. Appearance is dark cola with frothy tan head. Flavor matches the nose. Palate is creamy and bubbly. Wonderful beer.
Bottle. Dark amber colour with a beige head. Aroma is fireplace, caramel. Flavour is sweet, fireplace, malt, caramel, hop, bacon. Weird and sweetish beer.
Bottled 500ml. -Red/brown coloured, medium sized beige head, heavy smoky nose. Smoke, wood and touch of chocolate well balanced. Some random touch pf salt. Deadly drinkable and superb smoked beer.

A dark brown pour with a lively beige froth. The nose is hugely smokey: smoked salmon, smoked hickory, and smoked meats. The malt character is dark, rich, and bursts with smoke tainted chocolate, caramel and toffee. The flavor is filled to the brim with charred and smokey flavors. Deep roasted malts, and smoke all around. The palate is rich, thick, velvety, smooth, supple, and finishes smokey like a cigar.

Poured into my G Schneider & Sohn glass.  A dark mahogany with creamy off-white head.  Malt as fresh as any brewpub and burnt flesh great my nose as I near the glass.  The beer tastes like an amazing smoked jerky, fresh with just a little juiciness left.  First Aecht in years - forgot how much I love the stuff.
Waaay to smoky for me. This beer is a heap of smoke and I couldnÂ’t taste or smell anything past that. Not for the feint of heart (or taste buds).

500ml Bottle Â– Trade Â– Foppa78
Big smokey as hell Urbock. Great malt this was just a super thick forest fire of a beer.  If you like smoke here you go.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2010 Dark pour with a foamy lid.  Smoky and malty aroma with a little grass.  Attractive label with a fake wax seal - was there once a real wax seal on the label?  Very nicely blended smoky taste.  Lots of beech smoked malt, not too dry or sweet.  Mellowly bitter and smoky finish with a little sparkle.  It does not taste much like a bock, but it does taste like another superb rauchbier from Heller of Bamberg.  RB scores this higher than their marzen, altho I liked that just a tiny bit better.
This beer is an absolute treat. Think bacon, eggs, and ham....a liquid breakfast. Sounds weird, but it works. A masterful example of a smoked.

The beer pours dark red with a tan head. This is an awesome looking beer. The aroma is lots of meaty smoke with a little roasted malt. The flavor is heavy on the smoke with some darker malts and some dark fruits mixed in as well. As the beer warms, the smoke becomes more intense. Medium mouthfeel and low-medium carbonation.

UPDATED: MAR 23, 2011 roasty, bread, caramel,more smoke, brown, tan foam, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, sticky, soft carbonation, long smoke finish, det kan ikke gÃ¸res bedre, en rigtig urÃ¸l.

Bottle. Pours very dark ruddy brown with an inch of light tan head. Aroma is mostly glazed porky smoke. Taste has heavily sweet dark toffee malts under the charcuterie. Some earthy/ grassy hop bitterness creeps into the dry finish. Works a treat with hard cheese. Oddly more approachable than the MÃ¤rzen, and I didnÂ’t like it quite as much (but perhaps because it was not such a revelation).

16.9oz bottle at ChappyÂ’s in Dayton, OH.  Poured a dark brown color.  Aroma of a smoke house.  No joke.  Beef jerky all the way.  Taste is holy smokes, smoky.  IÂ’ve never had anything like this before.  This takes the style "smoked" to a new level.  Literal feels like IÂ’m drinking a grilled piece of meat.  Amazing really.
Bottle. Pours a dark red with a brown hue and a small grayish brown head. Aroma smells like smoked meat, specifically beef jerky. Flavor is similar with a taste of smoked ham and beef jerky.
Deep red pour with tiny white head. Scent is smoke and malts. Taste is smoke and malt. This is fantastic!
Dark amber brown, big beige head. Aroma of caramel, bacon, jerky beef. Taste is toasty malt and lighter smoke than expected from aroma. Medium body, lively carbonation

Bottle.  Pours a dark clear brown with a thick tan head.  Aroma of smoked meats, charred malt, smoke.  Flavor of sweet meats with a smoky, charred body and charred malt finish.  A sweet, meaty, smoky, hearty palate.  I enjoyed this one more than the Marzen.  Very nice smoked.
8/4/8/4/16 [4.0/5]

Pours a dark brown with thin white head.  This is an incredibly smoky beer.  Strong notes of smoked salmon with undertones of smoked jerky and cheese.  I found that was all that I really noticed when drinking it.  The smokiness is truly excellent.

A-Body is a completely transparent mahogany color that pours with a minimal off-white head that fizzes away immediately and leaves a very thin collar. Tiny traces of lacing left on the edges of the glass.

S- Wow. Very strong smoky aromas. Smells liked smoked meat. My dog hasnÂ’t left me alone since I popped open the bottle.

T- Upfront is some mild smoke bitterness with a faint malt background. The flavors really come out for the finish which is all smoked meat. A little bit of spiciness emerges as well. Minimal smokey bitterness lingers.

P-Medium to high carbonation and light drinkable lager body. Body almost feels a bit charred.

O- This is my very first rauchbier. Smells and tastes great but this is more of a novelty drink to me than something that I could enjoy regularly. Not as drinkable as most lagers... I like it though and would buy it again.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-02-2008 00:39:53
--

Draft. Great surprise for my non-beer friends. They said it tasted like christmas ham, canÂ’t disagree. Salty, smoky. honey baked ham. Sweet, full flavor, densely packed. In your face smokehouse, much more forward than others of the style IÂ’ve had. Finishes chalky and dusty like a breath from a bonfire. Interesting, but not my go-to.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2010 Bottle 500ml. Magnificent; IÂ’d slightly go for the Marzen, but this was great too. Aromas of bacon, nuts, cookies, burnt caramel, and also some copper. Taste is mostly sweet, with a hint of salt, and a light bitter touch. Palate is silky and tingly, with a medium body, Very dark brown, with a frothy white head.

Draught at Olutkellari Helsinki, courtesy of our pubcrawl leader (huge thanks Matti!).  Very dark red colour with an off white head. The nose is lovely, pancetta, smokey, some Â´fine maltiness, sweet underneath the smoke.  The taste starts with more of the same, which is actually wonderful!  Smoked ham and pancetta rollicking before a fine full malty background, trailed by some banana too! All in all, very nice. Very, VERY, nice.
On tap at Sergios in Lousiville, KY.  Was recommended by Piscator.  Am not that familiar with Smoked beer, but enjoyed the small sample of this one.  Thanks for the recommendation.

Purchased in Whitefish. Pours a dark chocolate colour with a small gray head. The aroma is very smoky. The nose is like smoked deer sausage and jerky. The flavor is all I could want in a smoked beer. The smoke pushes the edge and then backs off to reveal a beautiful sweet, earthy, epic taste. Gaminess, intense smokiness, and then caramel, spice, chocolate, oak fruit and a long earthy finish. Very, very good.

flavor is about 40% smoke tempered by intense chocolate and a crunchy candy finish whoÂ’s sweetness is actually a bit difficult. i prefer the full on smokebombs of weizen and marzen as this is quite sweet. still masterful and well drinkable at cellar temps as i took it on.

World classic original.  if you donÂ’t like smoke, donÂ’t try this.  But itÂ’s much more than just smoke.  What a nice balance, yes smokiness dominates, but at least it is of hickory or something like you would taste in a BBQ sauce.  This beer is excellent with almost any meat dish.  Delicious X2.

I cant get enough of the authentic bamberg rauch. Look is clear brown with a small light brown head. Charcoal and salted smoked meat in the aroma. Medium sweet malty flavor with some apparent salty notes and a smoked finish.

Looks like coca-cola... dark brown with little to no head and very carbonated. Aroma is dominated by the sweet malts but hides a nice smoky background from the barley. Taste is nice and dry with a hearty smoke finish and hints of sugary malts spread throughout. Texture is lacking a little, but besides that it is very good. Its like have a sweet BBQ dinner in a beer. Would get again.
Aroma of smoke and sausage. Appearance is red-brown with small white head. Taste of smoked sausage, tar and salt. Overall this beer taste a lot like smoke (or only smoke).

Bottle, huge thanks to hobbersr for the share! My mouth just got Schlenk-raped! Pours foggy brown, solid medium head, reduces to a skim, spotty lacing. Nose is crazy salty and smoky, bacon, Montreal smoked meat, maple, forceful yet intriguing. Flavor is very rich, more smoke and bacon, intense but not overwhelming, malt is present and can be picked out even over the smoke. This tastes like eating bacon, while being gang-raped by a forest fire, which IÂ’m apparently into, because I love this.
Mmmm Breakfast time. Nose is all smoke, salmon and bacon. In the mouth it is medium bodied and like drinking an assortment of smoked dishes. Quite flavourful but a really polarising beer.
pours deep brown not much head. It smells like a smoke haus. The aroma is all jerky . Tastes like campfire and burnt meat this is a heÂ’ll of a smokes beer. A little intense butvi like it!

Bottle from probstk. Dark reddish brown pour with beige foam that recedes to a ring around the glass. Aroma is, duh, smokey but a particular kind I found it smelled of smoked salmon. Taste is very nice, well balanced mellow smokiness with lots of malt sweetness. Palate is very good, smooth and creamy and not as watery as the MÃ¤rzen. 300th rating.

A full bodied rich toffee; caramel, roasted malts, nutty texture and massie smoke from this wonderful German brewery. Poured from bottle by Bob at CaskinKitchen in Plimco. Wonderful dark rich beer. Reminds me to buy some more and to enjoy at home. Lovely stuff.

Bottle.  Pours a clear, reddish-brown body with an average, off-white head.  Smoky, BBQ bacon and beef jerky nose.  Big time smoke dominates the flavors.  Not getting much else out of it.  I dig the smoke, but it definitely overwhelms anything else that might be there.  Medium bodied, average carbonation.  Malt forward with a bitter, smoky finish.  Smoke lingers.  Overall a nice beer, but I donÂ’t think I could drink more than one bottle in an evening.

UPDATED: SEP 6, 2010 Bottle.  Dark amber pour with a rich tan head.  Nice lacing along the glass.  Similar aroma to the Marzen but with a more intense smoked flavor.  Also includes bittersweet dark chocolate and coffee notes that pair nicely with the smoked meat and mesquite flavors.  Very tasty.
Bottle.Dark brown colour with medium beige head.Aroma of bacon and and wood,less smoked then many of the other beers from the brewery but more complex and balanced.

2nd December 2008. Clear dark red brown beer. Very mild cream head. Fresh clean strong malt followed by a smoky finish. Not smoky dry and therefore quite palatable. It also has a toffee fruity undertone. One of the better smoked beers IÂ’ve had.

Bottled sample via and shared with oakbluff. Dark brown in colour with medium carbonation. Massive woodsmoke on the nose, followed up by some moderately sweet malt notes. ThereÂ’s an interesting flavor progression with the smoke leading the way, the malts taking over midway, then the smoke returning on the finish. Heavy bodied, with a slightly salty mouthfeel. Great intensity.

Bottle.  Pours transparent mahogany-brown with a thin, tan head that dissipates quickly.  Aromas of salty, meaty, roasty malt with little to no hop aroma present.  Semi-sweet somewhat chocolate flavored malt with a heavy smoked wood flavor.  Just the right amount of hop bitterness coupled with roasty carbon to finish off the taste with wholesome flavor and medium dryness.  Not only is this beer unique, but itÂ’s in its own league.  Currently my all-time favorite.

Bottle. Pours dark brown red with off-white head. Taste is relatively sweet, with a bit of bitterness and a sweet finish. Palate is full bodied and long. Aromas have roasted malt, smoky wood, caramel. Overall the smokyness covers almost everything, but in a smooth way not astringent.

Clear dark red/brown pour with a creamy light tan head, good retention and lacing.  Looks nice!  I can already smell the smoke and my nose is about 2 1/2 feet away from the glass.  Smells like campfire, bacon and band aid.  Tastes like bacon wrapped smoked gouda balanced nicely by a subtle malty  sweetness.  Medium body, lively carbonation and no alcohol warmth.  A delicious beer that is probably better when paired with the right food.
Bottle.  Dark brown pour with white creamy head.  Smoke, bacon, band-aid, leather but not overpowering.  Complex beer with sweetness, coffee and spice.  Nice bitter finish to balance the smoke.

Bottle. This beer is obviously dominated by smoke. Although its not as one dimensional as a lot of smoked beers tend to be. This one has got some sweetness, som chocolate and a semi-dry aftertaste with a touch of leather.

Bottle. Brown pour with slight white head. Bacon, smoke, malt, and some alcohol. These beers grow on you and scare a way non beer enthusiasts and vegans at the same time. Would like to see this use as a marinade.

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2011 500ml bottle poured in dimpled mug - Big beer, hardcore smoke! Lots of malt, smoke and alcohol with sausage like smokey flavour. Comes with all the expected aroma too.  Great experience!   Creamy tan head pours about 2 fingers and quickly settles with some lacework.  Sweetish, full body with lots of roasted malt and caramel.  Bittersweet finish.

1 pt. 9 oz. bottle.  Pours beautiful deep brown, with wonderful looking off white head.  Very bubbly frothy.  Smells like a georgia barbeque.  Smell of brunswick stew, pork smoke with sweet corn, roasted meats, peas.  Taste is of earthy malt, slight chocolate tones, with the sweet sour smokey roasted meat finish, vinegar and pepper.  This beer is very interesting to say the least, kind of making me hungry for barbecue.  Very enjoyable but pretty strange for me, overall certainly worth a taste.  A big thanks to Mansquito for this, one of two very unique and good beers given to me for my birthday.  Cheers.

Appearance: 3/5
Very dark brown-amber liquid with a small light brown foam that left very little lacing.

Smell: 7/10
Smoke, smoked ham and salt.

Taste: 7/10
Lots of smoke, salt, smoked ham, malt and burned toast.

Mouthfeel: 4/5
Smooth, creamy and buttery with just a little bit of sting. Thick body and fairly low bitterness.

Comment:

This beer is very smoky, not sure if itÂ’s heavier then the mÃ¤rzen. From my notes it seems like the mÃ¤rzen is more intense but I would have to test them together to make sure. IÂ’m personally not a huge fan of smoke beers but I think this works well. Tastes a bit like it has been filtered through an old hunting cabin.

Regarding food I think this would work well with regular home cooked food. Maybe some oven roasted potatoes and veggies with a big chunk of meat or sausages.

Pours a deep mahoganey with scant off white head.  Smoke is abundant in the nose and flavor.  Smoked meats and campfire, but in a very pleasant way.  There may be some toffee and other malty notes in there as well, but smoke definitely takes the front seat in this one.  I wish I could recall how closely this one compares to the Marzen version.  Pretty close I think.  This isnÂ’t the kind of beer most folks are going to pick up on a regular basis and it could be argued that it is somewhat one dimensional, but it really is quite enjoyable.  Medium mouthfeel with good carbonation that prevents this one from sinking too deeply.  We served it with smoked ham last night for dinner and it was very good.  If your not a huge fan of smoked beers, I understand the Wheat version of this beer is a little less smokey.

Draft at redlight redlight.  For a while when I would skip dinner and head straight for the beer, this was always my first of the night.  Though IÂ’ve started eating food again, I still like it quite a bit.  It remains the smokiest beer IÂ’ve ever had.  Pours a deep amber with a light tan head.  The aroma is wonderful and bears a strong resemblance to pork bbq.  The flavor is actually milder than one might expect, like someone took a delicious and refreshing bock and strung it up in their smoke house for a few weeks.  Nothing but the best from Schlenkerla.

Bottle. 

Dark reddish brown with a small off-white head that quickly goes away. Lots of lacings.

Big smok aromas of ham or other smoked meats. Notes of wood and hints of ashes. Surprisingly lots of heavy malt aromas (caramel, toffee) break through. Dangerously close to being cloying, but quite impressive smell.

The flavor is quite sweet and not as dominated by smoke as expected. Full malty flavors of caramel and toffee. Well integrated smoky aromas of ham, bacon, salami... you know the deal. The finish is spot on with juicy malts, burnt wood, ashes and ham, and ha hint of spicy alcohol. 

Full bodied and very smooth. Quite demanding.

A big and heavy beer, but I really like the complexity and balance between malts and smoke in this one. Liquid bread? More like liquid ham disguised as liquid bread.

cold brown pour with some red tints, has a small off white head.  Aroma is of smoked meats,  bacon,  salami,  etc.  Has a rich meaty flavor,  smoke,  and a bit of caramel.  Has a big smokey finish with a good bit of carbonation that helps it from feeling too rich.  I wish I had more to say about this one as I really enjoyed it,  the smokey meat dominates and everything takes a back seat.  Either way,  great beer.

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2010 Dark brown beer with medium, brown head; aroma of smoked ham, campfire and tar; full body and thick mouthfeel, but still very easy to drink; flavor of smoke, tar and salty ham; slightly bitter aftertaste - the best substitute for ham for veggies in the christmastime!

This is the smokiest of all the Schlenkerlas, as soon as you open the bottle it hits you like a campfire.  Has that smoky bacon flavor, and much heavier than the Marzen or the Weisen.  This is for when you really want to get your bacon on.
UPDATED: MAR 6, 2010 Poured mahogany with small head smelled like charcoal tastes very Smokey prett good beer I like the smoke has the aftertaste of smokey beef jerkey
Pours deep reddish brown. Smells sweet and really smoky. Tastes like smoked meats, campfire, sausage, sweet malty goodness and a strong bitter finish. Hell yes.

On tap at PigÂ’s Ear 09.
Smells of bacon, very dark ruby beer. Sweet fruit and smokiness. Highly drinkable, but some extra bitterness would have lifted it a bit further.

UPDATED: DEC 5, 2010 lct-mhny, Â§head, Â§co2, med-bod.

bbq pit aroma.

Â§smokey malty T1, Â§bitter T2, mineraly smokey T3, maltier Tf.
smoke flavor is meaty but not lingering, simple but ^character.

Truth be told, I have never had a beer like this, and after this tasting, probably never will again.  The smokiness is so far over the top, the aroma is of bacon/ham/burnt wood/smoke/and just general meatiness.  ItÂ’s not something I would wish on my worst enemy.  Despite that, once you get past the aroma, this Urbock is generally drinkable.  However, every sip I took smacked me in the nose with itÂ’s rancid smokiness.  Pours reddish brown (mostly brown) with a bit of carbonation, and could almost be tolerable with a smoked ham or turkey.  ALMOST.  Probably could have gone a lot lower on the ratings, but like I said, if you can get past the smell, the taste isnÂ’t all that bad.

a smoldered and burnt sienna. Smells like a house burnt down. Enough smoke, guys. Under the aroma is a sticky sweet, malty, cola, oatmeal raisin cookie of a beer. delish. med-full body for a rauch. too bad they couldnÂ’t get some of that cookie to hit you in the nose.

Great beer, if of course completely DOMINATED by the smoke. With some thought and consideration, other qualities become apparent. Poured with very little head and a tiny bit of lace. Color is an almost opaque dark, aged cherry wood. Aroma is as stated above Smokey and then some malt and thatÂ’s about it. FlavorÂ’s the same with a little malt and dark ripe fruit sweetness. Finish is pretty much smoke. And then thereÂ’s the smokiness. DonÂ’t notice the alcohol much. Pretty good beer within the narrow class. Not a session beer unless youÂ’re a smoke fanatic.

Basically this beer reminds me of alcoholic version of a grilled pork chop.  It has a nice full smoked flavor from the dark roasted malts.  The hops are well balanced.  There is a slight sweetness to the beer.  Full of flavor.  A great with meat and potatos.
UPDATED: MAY 12, 2010 Bottle. Reddish brown colour with an off-white head. Aroma: tar, smoked meat and malt. Flavor: tar, smoked meat, caramel, malt, salt, mint. Smooth carbonation. Damn good!

50cl bottle. Dark reddish brown beer with very strong smoky aroma. Smoke dominates the sweet taste aswell but this is also salty. Quite nice body IÂ’d say. A very good smoke beer and makes me want to taste the weizen even more.
Bottle thanks to richlikebeer. Pours black with a little head. Has the smell of beef jerky. Also reminds me of my spit cup when I chewed mint skoal. Taste just like a beef jerk as well.
Great head on this smoky monster.  Aromas are the typical smoked ham deliciousness.  LIQUID MEAT? Who could argue with that?

Maybe IÂ’m not ready for this kind of beer. It pours reddish brown with a small disappearing head. The aroma is chocolate, wood, smoke, spice, and salt. Yes, like beef jerky. The flavor is thin and kind of sweet up front like brown sugar. It then fades to a smoky, meaty, barbeque/jerky flavor that finishes bitter. This may have its place, but I donÂ’t see myself wanting to revisit it anytime soon.

Deep brown reddish with a small beige head that leaves minimal lazing. Aroma is straight forward "meat smoke" with a light undertone of malt and minerals. Flavour is much more malty and delivers a rather solid bock underneath a lovely layer of smoked meat and wood. Mouthfeel is very smooth and rather full, it manages to be both heavy and very drinkable at the same time which is.. Odd and fun.
Bottle.  Poured dark red brown with thick foamy head.  Strong aroma of smoked malt, smoke and caramel.  Full malty flavour with some aged cheese notes.  Smoky finish with a little malt edge.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text:
UPDATED: OCT 8, 2012 24/11-09 .50cl bottle @ Zly Cazy, Prague. Pours dark brown with a small creamy white head and lacings. Lots of meat, bacon and camp fire. Chewy caramel and very full bodied. Quite heavy in all aspects. Still growing on me!
Various bottles. Lovely smooth and full bodied. Smoke, bacon, meat and caramel. Really nice. 3,8-4
Pours fairly clear dark brown with a light beige head. Aroma has a heavy smoked meat aspect with a subtle saltiness. The flavor is reminiscent of a smoked cured meat with a sweet component.

Bottle. Pours a clear amber color with a small white head. Nose is rich in salt bacon meat. Lovely smokey aroma like jerky. Palate is thin and a bit watery. Flavor is light caramel with minimal hints of smoke.

Bottle into a pint glass.  The aroma is all campfire smoke and smoked salty meats.  The flavor is sweet and malty. The smoke isnÂ’t as forward in the flavor - it reminds of salty smoked fish.  The exhale is mild tobacco smoke from a nice smooth cigar.

Brown with a nice off white head. Aroma is smoked fish (the smoke part not the fish), and caramel malt. Taste is sweet with just enough bitterness to balance it out. Very smooth palate, low carbonation, dry finish.  Strange beer, but very good.
Copper with a lasting off-white head. Wooden smoke, with bacon notes, and a good caramel maltiness. Sweet and very malty flavour with a very pleasant smoke character, that just lasts

bottle shared and courtesy of my sister Linds- a super light bodied, very drinkable smoke beer- enjoyed this thoroughly. The sweetness of the malt complements and backs up the substantial smokyness enough to make you want another sip.

Bottle, 50 cl, 2009-11-13, 10 C
AR: tar
AP: High beige compct head, diminishing, dark bownsih body
A: tared boat, vanilla pod, smoked ham,

Cask Stillage at the GBBF, EarlÂ’s Court 06/08/2009
Big smoked aroma. White head. Dark coloured strong in alcohol and a little rich on the palate with a crisp and slightly dry smoky malt finish.

Bottle. Dark brown-reddish, clear liquid. Aroma is filled with peat, smoked ham and malt. Flavour is round and rich with some sweetness from the malt, and apparent but sublime notes of tar and peat. Some slightly burnt notes as well. Quite drinkable, not at all extreme beer, but a really nice one.

500 mL bottle from Wine Warehouse in Charlottesville, VA. Pours a dark brown color with a moderate  brown head. Decent head retention and lacing. Aroma is very smoky with notes of salty bacon, smoked wood and faint earthy caramel. Taste is thankfully not as smoky. Smoke up front and in the finish with subtle meaty notes. In the middle is caramel and other malty notes. Medium bodied.

Serving: 500 ml bottle.
Appearance: Very dark reddish brown color with a small, light tan head.
Aroma: Nice and smokey up front with notes of wood smoke but not so much smoked ham as the Marzen.  Still, it does smell like a barbeque, just more bacon and other meats.
Flavor: A wonderful balance between the smoke and malt of the bock.  Earth, leather, tobacco, caramel, smoke, smoked bread (if that makes sense).  Just fantastic!
Palate: Medium carbonation with a medium body and a medium, smokey finish.
Overall: Surprisingly I found this to be lighter in body and feel to the Marzen and a little less "meaty" if you will.  I really enjoyed this one and thought it was superb.  Recommended.

(Bottle) The beer pours clear, dark mahogany brown with beautiful red hints. Creamy, off-white to pale yellow head. The aroma holds typical Schlenkerla smoked tones up front of tar, campfire and meat. Almost peppery with hints of earthy tobacco. Some sweetness is notable from the dark bread-like malt. Undertones of herbal hops, salt, caramel, nuts and some chocolate. The flavour is near medium sweet and light to medium bitter. Lots of clean smoke and chewy dark bready malt. The bitterness is clean with notes if bitter herbs and grass. The mouthfeel is round, silky and fat with a gentle carbonation. Earthy and smoky notes in the aftertaste. Medium to full bodied. As most smoked beers, this one is not super complex but the malt structure is fantastic.
Bottle. I love smokebeers. This one is the best. I ordered it from Germany.Smoked like hell. Just great.

[emailÂ protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */

Apperance: Ruby-red with a small, white head.

Aroma: Bacon, Ham, Caramel, Smoked wood.

Flavor: Smoked ham, Caramel, Grain, Smoke and some pleasant bitterness at the end.

Palate: An easy drink which goes down way easy for being a smokebeer. Nicely balanced.

Aroma: Smoky, sweet malt with hints of banana, dried apricots and hops. Very well balanced with a delicious smokyness.
 
Flavour: Smoky and sweet initially and throughout. A grilled flavour takes over after about half a second, although this is mostly taking part in the nose.
There is a pleasant bitterness of hops on a carpet of smooth, but elegant malts. Surprisingly mild however.Slightly sourish and bananlike aftertaste.
Lastly there is a very pleasant taste of smoke left in the mouth, somewhat earthy and coal-like. 
 
Appearance: A very dark, reddish brown body with beige, bubbly head that quickly sets but clings slightly to the glass. It looks quite nice.
 
Palate: Thin but somewhat oily, feels weaker than it really is.

This beer is really good, but is somewhat lacking in depth and potency Â– flavourwise.

Bottle from Systembolaget. Pours a dark brown color with a medium-sized beigewhite head. Aroma is smoky with charcuteries, mostly smoked meat, but itÂ’s also almost some smoked fish. Behind this you can find a sweetish maltiness with dark bread and liquorice. Flavour is smoky and malty. ItÂ’s lot of charcuteries which is balanced by a a nice sweetness and liquorice-like notes. Medium to full bodied. Pretty smooth mouthfeel. Good and balanced smoked bock.

A nose of firewood, smoked sausage, iron, some sweetness, and lots of tar. Taste is of roasted malts, iron, smoked ham or sausage and caramel. Some acidicy and bitterness initially, but it is replaced by a distinct smokeyness and a kind of dry character in the finish. The regular mÃ¤rzen is a bit boring; this Urbock is what its all about! I usually donÂ’t like smoked beers, thinking the sweetness donÂ’t mix with all the smoke, but this brew is really balanced in that aspect.

50 cl bottle via trade with smith4498 - Pours a dark brown color with a one finger thick light tan head.  Very light lacing.  Aroma is smoke.  ThatÂ’s about it.  And itÂ’s awesome.  Well, flavor is smoke too.  Bottled bacon!  Gotta love it.  What I really like about this beer is the balance.  Not overbearing or under whelming.  Medium body.  One of the best Smoked Lagers IÂ’ve had.  Thanks Jason.
UPDATED: NOV 5, 2009 smoke, molasses, red, brown, tan foam, heavy cloying sweetness, medium body, soft carbonation, long finish, good peat,
Brown coloured beer with small off-white head and no carbonation. "Jambon FumÃ©e" aroma. Finish is smokey with only a litte taste of ham.

Bottle. Pours dark, clear copper with a light tan head that diminishes quickly. Good rauchbier nose of smokey bacon, salt, peat, smoked ham and a little bit of malt. Flavour is very similar to the aroma but with more malt plus some toffee and nutty hints. Medium body and a long smokey finish, without much bitterness. Well balanced, great beer. Easily could have gone over the edge, but pulls back just in time.

Unfiltered. Have had this before but this has to be even more smokey. Serious aroma of smoked bacon. Like a bbq in a glass. Flavor is meaty, bacon, liquid smoke. Well done but a bit too foody, smokey for me.

Unfiltered tap at Redlight Octoberfest. Pours a dark brown with a thick light tan head. Huge smoky meaty bacon ham aroma. Taste is smooth malt, chewy bacon, some bitterness. Finishes with a big puff of smoke. Awesome brew.

Tap at Hagges bÃ¤rsklubb German beer festival (2005?). Light brown to beige head that lingers. Holy smoke, this is smoky, but I like it. It isnÂ’t a harsh smoke but a plesent smoke. Alcohole is clearly present in the taste toghether with the smoke taste.
This was my first smoked beer. The aroma and palate was everything i envisioned of a smoked beer. I did not hold the same sentiment for the flavor.

Holy Crap, thatÂ’s a strong smell! Like beef jerky and sharp cheddar, this beer is a clear dark blood red color and is really violent. It should be your last beer of the last beers of the night because that flavor and smell is hard to get rid. Palate is then and whispy, tho. Not hoppy, but a strong roasted barley bock flavor is present. A chock-loadof beer, but not yet to my taste. Bottle from Lucky Liquors, Miami.
50cl bottle. brown/beige head, aroma of bacon and smoked ham. Sweet finish. A favourite!

Unfiltered tap at Bavarian LodgeÂ’s Oktoberfest Cask & Keg fest, Oct. 1. Stouty black, stiff brown head in an 11 oz. goblet. Smell of bacon, gouda, and burnt barbecue wood. Smoked beer: you either love or youÂ… youÂ’re not a man. Makes you feels like youÂ’re drinking some primordial beer found in old clay bottles in the back corner of a cave, behind the drawings of the sabre-toothed deer hunt. DonÂ’t know what the difference is between this and the filtered, bottled version, guess just some yeast filtered out that canÂ’t make itself felt over the big smoky malt power punch.

500ml bottle.  Pours a deep translucent walnut brown with a lovely 2 finger tan head.  Mmmm...I love me some rauchbier.  Nose is intoxicating with smokey goodness.  Alder smoke, meaty, some type of roasty nut, touch of ash.  Also when you get past the smoke I pick up some apple and caramel malts.  Great carbonation some a bit heavier than medium body.  Lovely smokey flavor with hints of malt and some bittering hops around the edges.  Very quaffable.  I really need to start planning a trip to Germany.
UPDATED: OCT 7, 2009 Poured dark reddish brown, salty smoked meats, roasted malts, wood, little tobacco.

Tap at Blind Tiger, NYC.  An unfiltered version of the original.  The aqroma is smoked meats, bacon, salt.  Awesome.  The appearance is a hazy brown color, lighter than a porter, tan head.  The flavor follows the aroma, smoke, malts, bacon flavor.  Amazing.  The finish is mainly smoke, slight bittering.  Excellent beer.  The smokiness tends to dominate all other flavors and aromas, but itÂ’s still a great beer.  Nice thick mouthfeel as well.

Bottle, at Cardinal. It pours a slightly hazy brown body under a beige head. Caramel sweetness, bacon, some peat-like notes, woodfire and some hops in the aroma, but the smoked malts are pulling most of the load. The flavor continues what the aroma started, smoked, ham-like caramel malts with a good sweetness, and some bitterness trying to balance it. ItÂ’s not a very balanced beer, but thereÂ’s no need for it either. Full-bodied and slightly warming down the throath. The finish is sweet and smoked, with a little bitterness. IÂ’ve been longing to taste this one for quite some time, and wasnÂ’t disappointed at all. Now, bring me some fine sausages to enjoy with it. 090728

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2011 Bottle. Pop the cap and it smells like smoked almonds, but the flavor will prove to be more subtle. Appearance is like a schwarzbier or porter. Slightly light on the carbonation. Quite sweet with mellow smoke, but I donÂ’t know how old my bottle is--perhaps it should be smokier. Sort of a BBQ sweet+smoke thing going on, where the smoke holds the sweetness in check. 
Re-Rate: just growing to like these more.
Magnificent, it was probably mopre smoked and less annoying after few sips than the mÃ¤rzen but itÂ’s awesome.

Dark brown with a creamy tan head.  Aroma of heavy smoked meats and roasted malts with notes of caramel and fruit as well.  Taste is obviously smoky with salty smoked meats, toffee, mild smoked wood but overall a nice balance between smoke and sweetness.

A tad disappointing given the reputation but still a good, smoky beer.  The beer is a dark mahogany-red with a slowly dissipating head.  The aroma is smoky but more restrained than expected.  ItÂ’s the smoke aroma of a subtle refined smoked meat.  ItÂ’s complex and sweet; malt manages to peak out from the smoke.  The flavor is good and smoky without being completely dominated by meat or smoke.  The malt is a bit lighter and simpler than expected, but thereÂ’s more hops and bitterness.  ItÂ’s warm with notes of fruit (berries), sweet coffee and citrus.  The mouthfeel is a tad thin but not too bad.  I do enjoy a smoked beer, though, and this one is fairly delicious.

Cask at GBBF 2009: one of the best beers iÂ’ve ever tasted, truely amazing beer, very malty, some dark chocolate, loads of oaky smokyness which is perfect, smoked cheese, salami, bacon, pork sausages, great balance between all the flavors, i could drink this all the time and never get bored.

~Pours a dark clear brown with red tints and creamy tan head. 
~Smoked bacon and woodsy aroma with undertones of a malty bock.
~Aggressive smoke flavor that is quickly mellowed out by the crisp malty bock. Good balance between the two.
~Light refreshing feel, smoky malty sweet finish, a bit dry.
~Another delicious brew. I did enjoy the Marzen better. This one is much maltier and sweeter.

Pours a very dark chestnut brown color with amber/mahogany edges when held up to a light source and a huge frothy dark beige head that has excellent retention throughout, leaving large chunks of lacing throughout the glass.

Beautiful smokey aroma with smoked chocolate malts, charcoal, BBQ, burnt wood notes and subtle hops.

Very smooth drinking medium body, especially since it is so smokey. Huge smoked malt flavor with hints of oatmeal, chocolate malt, barbecued bacon, charcoal and subtle hop presence. The smokiness is not overbearing and I actually wish there was more of it. This beer is awesome!

Bottle.Pours dark brown with a small tan head.Aroma of smoke , ham/bacon ,sweet malt  with some burnt and roasted notes.Flavor is sweaty meat ,smoky/burnt and sweet malt.Medium body.didnÂ’t notice any significant bitterness but thatÂ’s probably because I found the ruach/smoke a little overwhelming .Interesting
Dark red brown with a decent sized off-white head. Aroma is of pepper, bacon, brisket and smoke. Taste is of ground black pepper, smoked meat, malt and beef jerky.
Pours brown with a small off white head. Aroma is mostly smoke with a little sweet malt. Flavor is again mostly smoke with a bit of meaty saltiness, and some sweet malt hiding there as well.

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2011 500 ml bottle. Clear, reddish amber body with a big, dense, beige head. Aroma is totally dominated by smoke but also a hint of caramel. Flavor dominated by smoke, campfire sausages, skin from mackerel, bacon, and also some sweet malt and hops. Quite complex but not totally in balance, feels over smoked.

Keg at the GBBF 2009. Not as dark as the bottle version which is inky black. Outstanding aroma of fireside smokiness, hay and a touch of a meaty quality. Lovely, rich umami flavours, touching on smoked beef jerky (in a good way). ThereÂ’s some caramel and licorice as well. Absolutely fantastic.

[emailÂ protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */, 2009.  Dark brown/almost black looking beer.  The aroma is very smokey and mildly malty, and the flavour is smokey, mildly bitter and malty.  Overall a nice smokey beer.

IÂ’ve been waiting a while to try this one, thanks Hessen Haus! 
Pours a dark almost ruby color with a nice fluffy head. Aroma is bacon, campfire, some sweet roasty malt, and a bit of nuttiness. But of course, it mostly smells smoky. The flavor is very smoky with some bacon and a little bit of salt; there is a nice roasty malt sweetness here as well. Obviously with something like this itÂ’s a little one dimensional, but what it lacks in complexity it more than makes up for in quality, this tastes absolutely wonderful.
dark brown/black pour with light head.  smokey rich dark malt and some mustiness.  Fantastic smoke flavor, not as abrasive as some, works well with the hearty sweet malt.

UPDATED: AUG 23, 2009 deep brown pour with a small, light tan colored head. Aroma is very smoky, with notes of bacon, wood, caramel, and roasty qualities. Flavor holds much of the same, but isnÂ’t as aggressive as the aroma; the flavor slowly develops, and the full complexity of the smoked style hits its zenith right near the finish. The palate is fairly smooth, but a bit thin- would like it to be a bit denser. Still a really nice brew.

50 cl bottle at hotel in Copenhagen, June 2009. Brown color, big beige head. Aroma is extremely smoked, also Â«cellar/oldÂ». Flavor is very fine balance beteween smoke, and caramel malt. Ok bitterness.

Bottle. Wow, I opened this and the smoky aroma poured out of the bottle. Poured a deep dark brown with a big foamy light brown head. Aroma is mostly smoke with some wood and ham. Flavor is, wellÂ… smoke, the heavy sweet malt base is there but the smoky roasty flavor adds a slight bitterness. This is about the smokiest beer IÂ’ve had that I really enjoyed, as the beer warmed over time and my palate got used to the flavor the real enjoyment started.

I love rolling this one out to mess with my friendsÂ’ perceptions of what beer is...dark brown pour, it almost smolders, smells like a campfire & tastes like a smoked ham. Amazing aftertaste of caramel, malt, and, of course, smoke. IÂ’m a vegan & this beer makes me feel guilty for loving it...

Bottle at the German Club. Pours dark brown with a large beige head. Beautiful aroma of smoked malt, meat, oak and caramel - all smoked of course. The flavour is of delicious smoked meat, caramel and whiskey. Medium bodied. Smoked finish. A fantastic smoked beer...wow!

Pours cola brown with a nice speckled bone colored head.  Aroma is undeniably smoky, like one of those rough-hide dog chews, and this carries prominently into the taste, and lingers into the finish, long after the caramel subsides.

Bottled 50cl. Courtesy of joss. It pours a ruby nut brown beer with a small creamy beige head which leaves a beautiful lacework. The aroma is fantastic; exceeding my expectations which where very high. Complex, nicely smoky (very balanced and not overwhelming), with caramel, molasses, wood (beechwood and oak), bourbon, black olives, leather, black pepper and tar being most present. Hints of ginger, eucalyptus, tobacco and mint. Deeply inviting. Quite a lot of black olives in the taste which is woody, sweet, medium bodied. Low carbonation. Late bitterness. Extremely pleasant. The finish is slightly medicinal, very strong, wonderfully smoky, surprisingly dry and reminiscent of a single malt from Islay (Laphroaig 10 comes to mind) with mint, dark chocolate, paprika, tar and tarragon appearing. Absolutely fantastic! Thanks a lot joss!

Nasty aroma, but the flavor is not as intense thankfully. But I could smell it every time I sipped it so ruined it for me. bThe flavor was strong hickory smoked bacon with a light bitterness and dry maltiness and a light fruity hop presence. The finish was long, woody and smoky. Too one dimensional

Bottle. Pours deep brown. Aroma is of cured smoked meat, touches of summer bonfire. Flavor is thick and malty with mild wood, only a hint of smoke. Aftertaste has minor bitter and smoke notes. Excellent.  A big bad beer.
Clear reddish brown color and a decent white head. The smell is awesome with smoke, bbq, bacon, meat, malts, and goodness.  The taste is about the same but does wane slightly from the smell.
dark chestnut color, tan head and excellent lacing.  flavor of smoke and dark malt.

I used to hate any and all smoked beers, but IÂ’ve really grown to enjoy them.  This one is dark red, a little darker than the Marzen.  The flavor also has a bit more malt.  Extremely smoke dominated in the aroma and flavor.  Smells and tastes like a liquid campfire....but in a good way!  IÂ’m not sure which one I enjoy more though, this or the Marzen.  IÂ’ll have to try both of them again.
similar to the marzen version but with the maltyness of a doppelbock. lots of malts and lots of smoke flavor makes this one the better of the two.

Near black pour with a thin off-white head. Aroma of smoke and maybe a little malt underneath. Flavor is very smokey malt, rich. Bittersweet throughout. Still too smokey for my tastes, but better than the marzen.

The first thing youÂ’ll notice is the smell of smoke. It hit me in the face and took me back to my first job at the local barbecue. ItÂ’s like stepping into the smokehouse. It pours an opaque and dark brown that my fiance mistook for Pepsi. You couldnÂ’t be more wrong, ha ha. Every review of this beer tells me it tastes like pork, bacon, or ham and they are absolutely right! If youÂ’ve ever had a smoked beer, you havenÂ’t had crap until this one.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2010 Draught at Q-Brick, Strong Ale Fest 2010. Dark brown, almost black, with a tall off-white head, lingering well. Very smokey aroma, with rich dark malts, caramel, lighter smoking than their maerzen, and a bit of sherry. Strong, rich malt flavor, well smoked but less so than their regular. Sweet, rich, well balanced, though, and very interesting. Smooth and thick. Really well done. Fabulous. Much better than in the bottle.
Wow, now this is a smoked beer.  Strong nose and strong flavor of smoke.  Smoked ham, smoked turkey, smoked sausages...  Great, but I canÂ’t drink a lot of it.

Sampled from a 16.9 oz brown bottle this beer poured a dark brown color with a large dark tan head. The aroma was strong dry wood smoke. The flavor was strong hickory smoked bacon with a light bitterness and dry maltiness and a light fruity hop presence. The finish was long, woody and smoky. Too one dimensional but enjoyable.

Pours dark mahogany with a 2-3 finger foamy gray-tan head that has o.k. retention, but fades to a skim eventually and holds. Aroma is smoked fowl, campfire, housefire, some mildly sweet toasted grain, lots of earthy notes, burning moss, a little grilled pineapple, dried orange peel, and old birch bark. Flavor is smoked meat, toasted hardwoods, burnt softwoods, lots of toasted peat, dark caramel, a hint of aged vanilla, a nice sweet wholesome graininess, sugary figs, some sweetbread spices, more grilled fruit and some milk chocolate. Finish is chocolate, smoky vanilla, dark caramel, hints of lightly toasted marshmallows, hickory and other hardwood smokes and some sweet dates and figs. Palate is medium thickness with with a slightly syrupy/oily, but overall creamy feel and a nice light and smooth carbonation that doesnÂ’t cut in too much. Great stuff, probably the best smokebeer I have had, other than possibly NG Smoke on The Porter.

500 ml bottle poured a clear dark reddish brown with a lingering ring of tan foam. Aromas of smoke, ham, earthiness and dark fruit. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of smoke, earthiness, cocoa and a hint of dark fruit with a smooth lingering smokey finish.

16oz bottle.  Pours soil brown with a healthy sized head.  Aroma is remarkably of smoked meat, favoring bacon and ham.  Palate remains soft throughout, and the moderate carbonation keeps this beer relatively refreshing.  Flavor has the same meaty qualities as the nose, with some lightened flavors (perhaps wheat?) through the mid-palate.  Initial flavor just blasts you with bacon bits, honey-glazed ham, wood-grill smoke, and a touch of caramel.  Finish is dry, and flavors conclude with some bitterness and dark chocolate.  Interesting brew, but I just couldnÂ’t get into this.  I think the Marzen is more drinkable altogether, but I warn that this assessment is coming from someone without much experience with these beers.

Smoky aroma with notes of tar and salt. Taste is hellaciously smoky, very intensively so, drowns everything out. I really love this as well as the mÃ¤rzen, glad I can have this as a winter seasonal at least.

Poured from bottle.  Smells like a good BBQ sauce.  Dark ruby red, just a bit of a head.  Smoked flavor dominates, wood and kinda tases like a pig roast, if you could imagine such a thing.  Mellowed a bit as it warmed, but still that smoked signature persisted.  Not my favorite style, but a great well made diversion to the normal brews.
user_location: York, SC via NJ, South Carolina, USA

text: Bottle from SamÂ’s, Durham. Mmmmm, bacon, baby! ItÂ’s been a while since IÂ’ve had this one and itÂ’s a delight. Dark and highly carbonated pour. SlamminÂ’ powerful nose of wood and smoke. Rich, thick mouthfeel. Nicely chewy old ale notes in the flavor, with some sweet malts in there to balance. Some hints of roast and dark fruit add further complexity, and even though the smoke is dominant itÂ’s far from one-dimensional. YUM.

0,5lt Bottle. Dark brown color with a light brown head. Malt and smoke in the aromas . Lots of smokey flavors which I absolutely love. Very complex and well made. I like it even more than the Maerzen.

It pours dark brown to black, but thin like a cola, not viscous like a heavier stout. The beer forms a small, light head that fades quickly (a bit to quickly), and IÂ’m disappointed that mine doesnÂ’t look like those in the Google image search. This beer smells for all the world like the bush a couple of days after it burns, there is no subtly in this beer, it is ALL about the smoke. Very strong smoky smells dominate but in behind it I can pick up some caramel/coffee from the malts. Surprisingly UN-smoky flavor, in the mouth the malts jump forward! Roasted malt flavors dominate, warm caramel and burnt coffee, mildly bitter with some late sweetness. A medium body beer with a mild carbonation and the higher alcohol content (6.5% - ish) provides a warming feel. Smoke tends to overpower as the drink progresses and the glass and content warms.

1 pint 0.9 fl oz bottle (first of this style i have had).  For starters, there is no doubt that your about to drink a smoked beer after smelling this one for the first time.  There is just a lot of smokiness to the aroma, and basically everything about this beer. If only sitting there drinking this one without really paying attention, the main qualities you would get out of it would be solely the smokiness, but if really appraised closely, there is much more to this beer.  In the aroma though, notes initially of smoked pork and smoked Gouda cheese, but underneath there is some nuttiness and rich caramel to it.  Good head on the pour of medium thickness tan cream, stays nicely, medium opacity in the body, rusty sangria in color.  As far as the drinking experience goes, its much easier to describe the overall feel than the flavors.  Medium bodied, a stimulating feel, and very smooth overall finish that to me shows off the quality of brewing that took place making this beer.  The flavor notes on the other hand, I find harder to judge.  Maybe just too inexperienced with this unique type of beer.  The notes that I get are not as meaty and unbeer-like as the aroma, but smokiness obviously plays a large role, more of in a fire smoked grain sort of way.  Some nutty notes, caramel, as well as chocolate, maybe even some minor dark berry sweetness, with an actual hint of leafy hop bitterness in the rather dry finish.  Positive impressions of this beer definitely grew as i drank more, but uniqueness of this one didnÂ’t quite grow on me in all that positive of a way.  I definitely didnÂ’t dislike it because thereÂ’s alotta good things going on here.  I just feel that I will need to rerate after i trying more of the style.

One of my first really out there experiment beers.  When I first started getting into beer, the Urbock 23 was one of my favorites.  Saw this also said Urbock and thought ooohh, should be tasty.  This was not tasty.  This was an assault on my mouth from which I may never recover.  Might as well drink a bottle of liquid smoke and call it a day.

Bottle from SamÂ’s.  Had this a few years ago and it freaked me out.  Blew my mind.  Made me scared.  For real, I had no idea what to think.  Some parts of it intrigued me and got me excited, while others made me think too much of smoked gouda and ham.  Moral of the story?  This might not be the best smoked beer to start with.  In the remaining years, IÂ’ve trained myself on some lesser smoked beers (tough work, I tell ya) and worked my way into figuring out what these meaty bastards are all about.  This one is damn fine.  Dark brown pour into a Duvel glass with massive off-white head that quickly recedes but sticks around.  Meaty, smoky nose with some lovely charred wood notes as well.  Campfire smoke might be the clearest note in there.  Some bacon and ham.  Some roasty malt notes and a hint of chocolate, I think.  I ate it with some salami and smoked gouda and both seemed weak in comparison.  Fuck, this is good.

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2010 Deep red with a medium beige head. Aroma was intensed smoked with notes of smoked ham, bacon and roasted malt. Flavour was bamberg smoked with roasted malt and bacon.  Finished very smoked.

1pt., 09fl oz. bottle.  Pours a clear cola brown with a moderate tan head that dissipates to a thin whisp.  Aroma is intense, with smoked meats, campfire smoke, charred wood, and background roasted malts.  Flavor is more meaty and campfire smoke, charred wood and roasted malts.  Very drinkable and a fine cold weather beer.

500 ml bottle. Pours a dark brown color with a medium off-white head. The aroma is awesome; sweet smokiness, smoked meat over a slow burning fire of oak and cedar. The flavor is awesome; smoky and barrel aged flavors, not overpowering but complementary. A medium toasted malt and light chocolates. It reminds me so much or tasting and smelling a campfire, drinking this around a campfire, now that would kick ass.

16.9oz bottle.  Pours a dark brown with a nice foamy off white head.  Aromas of fucking bacon bitch!  Fantastic aroma, smoked meat, smoke, chocolate malt, bacon, and some toffee.  Flavors are sweet malts up front, light coffee and you the smokey meat flavors donÂ’t show up until the finish.  Fantastic stuff, not sure why it took me so long to drink this, but rest assured I will be buying more.

Bottle at the London drinkers Festival. After 3 years of searching i have it at last. The one beer thats harder for me to get than selection lambic, millenium gueuze and J&JÂ’s. Alround rating: Its worth the wait, but hopefully its shorter next time. When you are so excited about something that youÂ’ve wanted to try for like years its probably best not to be immencly tierd, hungover, feeling a bit sick and have a serious dry mouth, but with such a great beast this works. Smokey hamish goodness, sweet satisfying malts, all completly balanced and super drinkable. Its awsome, absolutly awsome stuff. I had a half in like 2 mins and then drank my mates for him.

Pours a deep ruby/mahogany with a nice tan head that leaves great lacing and has nice retention, wonderful looking beer... Aroma of smoked meat, leather, mild hops, a touch of sweetness... Huge smokey flavor of fresh campfire, wonderful, though no description could justify how good a smokey, fresh fire tasting beer could actually be... There is a touch of bacon and a hint of sweetness, amazingly complex with the right amount of subtlies to offset the smoke, awesome beer... Medium bodied, amazingly drinkable...

Aroma is super pungent. First sniff is of bacon, and enough to fend off the squeamish beer drinker. However the smell is so unique that it prompted a 9 rating for aroma. 

The color was nothing special, yet enough of a deep reddish brown to be appetizing. 

First sip. Flavor of campfire filled my mouth. Sweetness upfront is very limited, yet the mid palate, comes up strong, with a creamy texture and a bitter finish. 

Not an every day beer. IÂ’ve been dying to try it though, so cruising BevMo today I decided to grab it.

Pours a clear red-brown with a thin off white cover.  Smoke just wafts away from the glass.  Aroma of bacon, campfire wood, smoke.  Taste is a more pronounced ash campfire wood smoke, some burnt bacon underneath.  Just amazin.

Brown bottle, 500 ml, best before 04 08, savoured on March 16 2009; eye: chestnut, clear, no effervescence, slight lacing; nose: smoke, smoked bacon, camp fire, burnt; mouth: smoke, smoked bacon, camp fire, burnt, finale in smoke with presence of maple syrup, medium body, average carbonation, lightly sweet, slightly bitter, medium-full body, creamy, average carbonation; overall: quite likable

FRANÃ‡AIS

Bouteille brune,  500 ml, meilleure avant 04 08, savourÃ©e le 16 mars 2009; Âœil : marron, claire, pas dÂ’effervescence, petit anneau de mousse beige, trÃ¨s lÃ©gÃ¨re dentelle; nez : fumÃ©e, bacon fumÃ©, feu de camp, brÃ»lÃ©; bouche : fumÃ©e, bacon fumÃ©, feu de camp, brÃ»lÃ©, finale en fumÃ©e avec prÃ©sence de sirop dÂ’Ã©rable, corps moyen, carbonatation moyenne, lÃ©gÃ¨rement sucrÃ©e, trÃ¨s lÃ©gÃ¨rement amÃ¨re, corps moyen-corsÃ©, crÃ©meuse, carbonatation moyenne; en rÃ©sumÃ© : bien aimÃ©

Bottle. Clear dark reddish body with a long lasting off-white head. Aroma of smoked malt with a hints of sweet bread and some rubber. Sweet smoked malt with notes of tobacco and bonfire in the flavour. The smoke is not overwhelming but very smooth. Lovely beer.
The bottle looks good, the beer in the glass also. Deep black, creamy foam. Starts very, very spicy, notes of bread, very malty. A little bit over the top, I think, tastes too much like bacon.

Bottle. Pours a deep brown reddish-brown with a small off-white head that lingers. Smoky aroma, with meat, malt, and wood. Taste is quite smoky wood and meat, with hints of sweeter caramel and malt. Lingering smokiness. Very tasty.

The appearance is dark brown, the aroma.... holy cats, itÂ’s like smoked meat! (This is my first rauchbier, pardon my surprise). The flavor also is definitely dominated by the flavor of smoke. ThereÂ’s a little sense of malt as well. To my surprise, this is actually a smooth beer as well. All else I have to say is that trying this beer was an interesting experience. Try it if you are adventurous or if you really like smoked foods.

Damn this is good.  Pours a rich brown color with thin offwhite head that fade quickly.  Aroma is of smoked ham, bacon, and faint chocolate.  Taste is oily bacon, smoked meat, light herbaceous quality, and some mild chocolate.  Finishes is clean but not watery.  This is a lot easier to drink the the marzen.

500 ml bottle shared with the KW crew. we did a side by side with this the Marzen and the Weizen and this one was my fav. reminded of an amped up version of the marzen. more malt background but still huge smoke. these guys sure no how to integrate the smoke into a brew while still leaving it true to original style. a nice smokey treat. thanks for the share Mat.

500ml bottle shared at our 2nd KW group tasting, thanks Mat for sharing! Pours a dark burgundy with a small beige head. The aroma is almost all the smoked malts, very enticing, smoked ham, but with some good malt body under there. Flavour is basically a more intense version of this breweryÂ’s Marzen, tons of campfire smokey goodness swirling around a very tasty, sweet and strong malt body. Very powerful and biting of the lips but not too over-powering. A very nice, filling beer!
Last glass of the keg tasted at Olutkellari Helsinki. A fine nose of smoke. Pale beige head. Dark black reddish colour. Smoky soft slightly sweet taste. An excellent and delicious beer.

Bottle. Light black in color, small tan head that faded quickly. Nice nose, sugary sweetness, malty and some smokiness.Taste is nice, a little bitter up-front, campfire smoke and i can pick up on some of the oak. It does taste like smoked meat (in a good way). All the flavors are well balanced. Texture is oily and slides right off your tounge. A little thin but doesnt take away from anything. Overall a unique beer that satisfied the "smoke" I was looking for.

UPDATED: NOV 19, 2010 Draft at Schlenkerla. Small creamy off-white diminishing head with good lacing. Clear sparkling dark brown body. Average malt body with aroma of bread, grain, vanilla and roasted malt. Heavy aroma of smoke, leather, tar and tobacco. Medium body, creamy and fat texture. Well balanced moderate sweet and light bitter. Delicious.

500ml. bottle from Trinity Liquors in Spring Hill, FL. Pours an opaque dark brown with a very thin white head. Aroma is strong smoked sausage, bacon, and campfire. Flavor is malty up front and fades to smoked meat, charcoal, and liquid smoke. Medium mouthfeel...warm/smoky aftertaste. Its pretty damn good...unlike anything else...its definately worth a try.
scura buona schiuma persitente note affumicate in bocca un attaco di amato poi affumicatura poi ritorna il doolciastro del malto

2/21/2009:  I love Aecht Schlenkerla Rauchbiers because of the deeply penetrating smokiness and their Urbock is no exception.  It pours a clear, deep amber color with ruby hightlights and a frothy light tan head.  The aroma is slightly sweet and has a large bouquet of smoke like that of smoked cheese rind.  The flavor is rich and smoky as well with plenty of chocolate and sweet, caramelized and roasted malts accompanied by burning wood and smoke.  Really, the smoke and maltiness of this beer are quite well-balanced.  It has a smooth, medium body and is hard to stop drinking.  One bottle is not enough!  The Urbock is quite good, but the Aecht Schlenkerla Rauchbier MÃ¤rzen is still my favorite of ther rauchbiers!
1 pt. 09 FL. OZ. bottle (6.5% Alc./Vol.) from RiverÂ’s Bend Wine and Spirits in Maineville, Ohio.  Rating #708 for this beer.
Nice dark brown and red color.  Smoke smoke smoke.  Reminds me of smoked meat and cheeses.  Really dig this style.
bottle. lots of smoke aroma with a dark brown pour ad dissipating head. creamy mouthfeel, but seemed to finish a bit thin, to me. solid.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2009 Completely biased due to this being my instant favorite of the last few years.  Poured a beautifully smokey ruby color with an off-white head that hung around for the duration of my session.  If youÂ’re not careful, the aroma will knock you off your feet.  A deeply smokey aroma distinctively reminiscent of deer bologna.  Very smokey and pungent in the best possible way.  The flavor is singular in the world of beer tasting.  Much like your first brettanomyces funk beer, but at the delicious end of the spectrum.  It tastes just as it smells, with deeply smoked character blended delightfully with sweet malts.  You may think the finish will blister your throat, but nary a cleaner and milder finish have I experienced. A+

On tap. Pours a dark ruby colour, with a medium beige head. 
Aroma is pleasant but very smoked malts and saltpetre, with notes of caramel. 
Flavor has a lot of soft smoked notes. Reminding me of homemade smoked lamb salami, and ends up in a long smoky aftertaste. Really delicious!!

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2009 Pours dark-dark brown, pedestrian beige head.  HELLO, Aroma! Nose sweeps me into a salty cheese plate and pork campfire dream.  Wow!  Creamy mouthful of a body.  Deep oaky toasty smoked flavor.  Just when you think it might be overwhelming, itÂ’s finish is surprisingly, relatively clean.  Unique and simply delightful.

A- Pours the darkest of browns, head is tan, creamy, and mostly sustaining, nice sticky lacing on the glass
S- Nose is dominated by smoke reminiscent of a campfires and BBQ meats, plenty of burnt wood, tinges of charcoal, truly unique, I loved this!
T- Initial taste is just like eating ribs in the south, plenty of smoke, roast, and carbon burning, I am flabbergasted by how much smokiness is in this beer and could only imagine how awesome this would be with a plate of beef brisket, sweet malts are also in there as well, finish is sweet like molasses
M- Medium/full-bodied beer, creamy texture, good carbonation
D- This seems to be the ultimate food-pairing beer and is slightly overwhelming to drink by itself (feels like IÂ’m drinking a meal), truly one of the most unique beers IÂ’ve had in a while, this is a must-try if you can get your hands on it
Incredibly rich, almost overpowering smoke flavor. Full body and a bbq quality to it. CanÂ’t drink much, but itÂ’s a taste sensation.
Smells like a house fire, looks like burnt would and tastes like smoked gouda.

oh baby, This is a GREAT beer. ItÂ’s like drinking a bottle of campire smoked bacon. For such a complex taste it drinks pleasntly smooth, A must drink for anyone who enjoys smokey beers, or anyone who likes smoked meat, thats what she said

UPDATED: JUL 10, 2009 500 ml. Chestnut with ruby highlights. Small head settles to a lasting, partial circle of mist. Satisfying aroma of holding a plateful of bacon and molasses next to a campfire. Maybe a hint of wheat also. Wow, flavor is chunky, smoked lean bacon with an occasional nibble of some crisp apple to cleanse the palate. Some earthy-metallic mineral hints also provide some balance from a different direction. Nice drippy lacing on the glass. Medium body seems thin, but this may be a good thing with the strong flavors. Lightly carbonated, yea!

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2015 draft at plan-B cph.appears dark brown, ligtr brown head.aroma is smoked stuff, bacon, malts, aroma is pretty much centered around smoked bacon.flavor is a lot of smoked notes, smoked ham. charchoal. malts. caramel.

50cl bottle. Much cleaner looking than the Weizen. Pours a dark red mahogany with no haze or cloudiness. Inch thick, beige, fizzy head that dissipates quickly and leaves a decent amount of lacing. Not the funky look of the Weizen. Aroma is more of a sweet smokiness. Still has a nice bonfire aroma, but not as meaty as the Weizen. More woody. Some deep caramel and nuttiness as well. Flavor is nice, I already know I like this more than the Weizen. Initial roasted bitterness, sweet and deep caramel middle with some molasses too, finishing a bit nutty, smoky, and bitter. Slightly salty and pretty dry, however, much more enjoyable drying finish when comparing to the Weizen. Palate is medium to full and very smooth. Overall, this is a damn good beer. Great complex flavor and extremely well balanced. This is less smoky than the Weizen and actually works much better with the sweet maltiness. Enjoyable bitterness makes it that much better. Very good, hopefully the Marzen is similar to this instead of the Weizen.

Pleasant smoked aroma. Reminds me the slovakian smoked parenica cheese.
Dark mahogany red color. Dirty brown colored  medium sized well lacing head. Well balanced, complex flavor. The roasted, sweet caramel or maybe coffe flavors quickly turns into warming liqueric dryness. Medium to full bodied, decent carbonation, dry salty finish. This one is less smoked in flavor than the other products from this brewery. The malty sweetness   and the smoked dryness are brilliantly balanced in this particular brew.

Bottled: Intensive somked aroma, notes of bacon, dark smoked meat and smoked cheese. Some sweet malt aromas. Dark brown color, small creamy, brownish head. Flavor is light sweet, malty with grain notes. Taste as you lick a charcoaled tree limb. Black smoked meat notes. Astringent, bitter and intensive smoked. Very good balanced, few alcohol remarkable. Bitter end with smoke and roasted malt. Very pleasant smoked, give me more of this stuff.
Heavy and very very smoky. everything ok but some strange flavor reminding me of a burnedbad quality grilled sausage.

Bottle. Deep meaty smoke aroma with caramel in the background. Clear cola-colored with a thin head. Flavor is deep with caramel flavors that complement the smoke. More depth than most rauchbiers. Thick palate. Very enjoyable.

Liquid Germany.  Drank my share of this growing up, but have not had it in awhile.  Pours like a nut brown from the bottle with an oatmeal colored head.  Smells and tastes of meat and smoke.  There are also faint traces of caramel and almond, but this beer is all about rewarding the hunter.  Game on.

500 ml bottle. Deep brown color with red highlights, tan head. Sweet smoky aroma. Bitter smoky flavor with a long finish and hints of alcohol. Full body, medium-light carbonation. Smooth mouthfeel. A pleasant smoked beer, but definitely not sessionable.

SÃ¶tÃ©t vÃ¶rÃ¶sesbarna szÃ­ne Ã©s piszkos sÃ¡rga habja van.Illata enyhÃ©n fÃ¼stÃ¶s,pÃ¶rkÃ¶lt malÃ¡tÃ¡s,kellemes.ÃzÃ©ben mÃ©g jobban kijÃ¶n a haraphatÃ³ fÃ¼st,mint egy jÃ³ ParenyicÃ¡ban.Ezen kÃ­vÃ¼l szÃ©pen Ã©rezni a malÃ¡ta gyÃ¼mÃ¶lcsÃ¶ssÃ©gÃ©t  Ã©s egy kis pÃ¶rkÃ¶lt aromÃ¡t is.Komplex,kÃ¶zepesen testes Ã©s kellemesen melegÃ­t az alkohol is.KÃ¼lÃ¶nlegessÃ©g!JÃ³fÃ©le fÃ¼stÃ¶lt disznÃ³sÃ¡gokhoz kivÃ¡lÃ³ kÃ­sÃ©rÅ‘!
Pours dark brown with reddish hues. Aroma of smoke and beech wood. Taste is of wood, smoke, cured meats, and molasses. Mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with lively carbonation.

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2010 500 ml bottle. Finland.
Excellent. Better than MÃ¤rzen version of Schlenkerla Rauchbier. Pure smoked ham flavour. I would say Rauchbier at best. Great!

This has the highest ABV of all Schlenkerla brews.  I used this one in a marinade for a huge filet of Scottish Atlantic Salmon on Christmas 2008.  Very dark reddish brown hue, thick and creamy eggshell colored head.  Very attractive lacing.  Nice smooth aroma of smoked meats, sweet malts.  Heavy smoke, big smoked malt aroma.  It is not for he weak.  Rich malt flavor,  nice smoke on the sides of the palate.  It is like drinking sweetened bacon.  Bonerific.  Medium bodied. Finishes  with some more smoke and a balancing hop character.  Prost.

Wow, what a beer! Deep colored appearance, fine and stable lacing tan head. Yes, it has a barbeque aroma with a sweet malt character, some liqueric ham perfume. The taste is complex too, around a liquid smoked ham or bacon with  sweet malt and roasted malt. In the finish i can feel the touch of the wooden cask. It is very exciting beer! I hope the tradition of the smoked beers will never die!

Pours adeep brown with nice tan, foamy head.  Nose is barbeque smoke with a touch of molasses and malt underneath.  Tastes like Texas barbeque in liquid form, roasted malt, and possibly some brown sugar.  Medium carbonation, just about right.  Very good brew, is not going to be for everyone but definitely worth a try.

This one is different. Smoky as hell, like eating a smoked ham sandwich...in liquid form.  Medium bodied with significant carbonation.  They say you love it or you hate it, but I am in the "it is decent" camp.
