Ultimately the best way to describe this is that it is to Bock what the MÃ¤rzen is to regular MÃ¤rzen. The aroma is more or less exactly the same as the MÃ¤rzen, though perhaps slightly more powerful; loads of woody smoke, good sausages being cooked on a campfire, vanilla and a little roast malt. In the mouth it asserts itself more as a genuine bock, with loads of salty, smoky, powerful malt that verges on soy sauciness with some plum sauce thrown in. PalateÂ’s ever-so-slighlty dull. Call me stupid but I was a bit surprised that this tasted so much like a bock - and IÂ’m not really a huge fan of bock. I really liked this but there are less of the things I really like about the MÃ¤rzen (roast + bitterness) in this one, and itÂ’s just not as easy to drink.RR: Fresh 07 bottles are in town now (Nov 07) and itÂ’s tasting fantastic. Definitely not too "bocky" this year, just bucketloads of smokey intensity. Sausagey again too, IÂ’m not sure why this tastes like sausages and the MÃ¤rzen doesnÂ’t. Delicious.
Bottle. Red brown colour with a medium off-white head. Smoked eal aroma and taste. Medium body with a light sweet smoked finish.
Huge smokey, leather aroma. Dark red with a creamy tan head. Very smokey flavor upheld by sweet caramel malt. Nice body. Finishes clean and slightly bitter.The smoke lingers.

Deep copper-chestnut, with a big tan-colored head, intense smoky aroma, notes of smoked bacon, hint of fire beech wood in the nose, follows through on a medium-bodied smoky palate, with a sweet caramelized malt, toffeeish hint, smoky character, roasted malt, leading towards a malty, faintly smoked finish.

Bottle. dark amber brown beer with a nice light beige head. Strong smokey aroma - woodsy/earthy with some salty cured pork. Seet malt and smoke flavor with some light saltiness. Smooth finish. Saltier than the marzen.
Dark brow colour with a think longlasting tan head. Very smokey aroma. Flavor is malty and lots of smoked meat. Very well balanced. Malty and woody finish with a smokey aftertaste. A lovely beer.

Hickory smoked aroma, very intense with tons and tons of smoke.  Dark, dark brown with a thin, off-white head.  Great smokey and mesquite wood flavor with a malty, caramel background.  Smoke really stands out here.  Medium body with a slightly oily texture.  This is really tasty stuff.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2006 Wow.  My first smoked beer - IÂ’ve never tried anything like this.  Strong aroma of a campfire, with a flavor to match.  Wonderful flavor of smoked meat and burning wood.  Body is a bit thin for such a strong smoke flavor.  Still a great beer.
Bottle. Oh dear. Does it get much better? Well I dont think so. A bit wood and very smokey. A hint of malt at first but then the smoke sets in - wow.

Ah the smoke is good. What IÂ’d like here is a bit bigger of a beer to back up the smoke, but given thereÂ’s no smoked imperial stouts yet, nor are there too many smoked doppelbocks, IÂ’ll have to settle with this one. Nothing beats this beer with smoked pork, or better, proscuitto. Notes of hickory and oak meet molasses and brown sugar. The smoke is actually much more evident on the nose than on the palate, given thereÂ’s enough going on in the beer itself. Great stuff, and if I were rating to style, this would be the finest smoked beer out there right now.

Bottled.
Clear brown coloured with a huge beige head.
Smokey aroma with notes of wood.
Sweet flavour of malts, smoke, wood and hops.
I donÂ’t like smoked beers, but after 4 days in Bamberg with decent german lagers and smoked beers, IÂ’m appreciating beers like this.

MÃ¤rzenÂ’s bigger, hermit-like brother; I swear if these beers got any better IÂ’d be applying for a long term visa and tenancy in this historic village to guarantee a constant flowing supply of BambergÂ’s finest. Tasted from the bottle and poured into a tallboy glass. Sadly lifeless to look at; brilliant reddish brown hue with no head passed an island of tan bubbles that later filled the surface with a thin lather and left a little legs. Complex, rich and savoury aroma of dried and cured meats; salted, pickled fish, bread crumbs, burnt toffee, plums and other zesty fruits, with a light prickle of spice coming in late. A little thinner than expected on the palate, not as full on as the aroma, but flavoursome enough. Smoky ash fills the mouth from the get go, mixing well with toffee and caramel, woody malt flavours, rashers of over-cooked bacon and some dried calabresÃ© sausage. Soft in carbonation and lightly sweet upfront, this was another treat for the senses. Getting better as it warmed, it became richer with more treacly fruit flavours coming in. Finish lacked the malt notes of the palate but the typified lingering smoke and burnt meat flavours were sumptuous and truly refreshing. Another divine beer from Heller-Trum, and a few steins of this at the restaurant next year for World Cup would possibly push it up on the top ten. Lovely!!! (50cL, BBE 07/06, IntÂ’l Beer Shop, W. Leederville)

Deep, translucent mahogany with rose colored accents when held to light.  Dusty, icy tan head.  Aroma is rocking: jerky, rawhide, mighty bones, pigs feet, summer sausage, kielbasa, chocolate and caramel bock attributions.  Sweet smoky bliss is confirmed in the flavor.  Chocolate and caramel duet joins a hickory, rawhide and crispy bacon tribute.  Smoked edge takes on flavor traits of toffee dropped into a breakfast skillet, dripping with bacon and sausage grease.  Slight moss and muddy mulch engrain an earthen edge.  Sweet mouth composure, fumigating all the porous pockets of the palate.  Toned carbonation and a malt profile that could put on a clinic.  Finishes with smoked ham and caramel ribbons.  Tasty stuff.

Pours dark brown with a red tint and a large frothy tan head.  Aroma is sweet and very smoky, like smoked sausage or beef jerky, with some dark fruits and malts as well.  Has an amazing flavor - I can actually taste smoked meat in the finish.  There is also an oak taste in the flavor - from the aging in the oakwood cask.  Flavor is sweet and slightly bitter, with an excellent malty malasses and caramel notes.  It would be better if it were thicker and had more alcohol content.  But as is, this is a wonderful beer - makes me want to go out and buy some beef jerky.

On tap at the Dominikanerstrasse: Dark ruby to amber coloured, thin but stable yellowish head; smoke and dried fruit in the dense aroma, traces of alcohol too; the almost vinous, full sweet-malty taste harmonizes very well with the mild "Rauch"; a smoked brew, which is more suitable to beginners than the regular MÃ¤rzen, because the smoke is distinctive, but better "integrated" than in the Maerzen.....Moreish, a class of itÂ’s own !!!!!!

[500 ml bottle, 14.1c]
Tasted with the guys from Institut de la BiÃ¨re.
Holy smoke! I still have the taste of that bacon grease in my mouth 12 hours later. This is an amazing beer, but i would never be able to drink more then 1 per evening or else, I might fall on the floor. IÂ’m not sure if I truly like the Â’animalÂ’ smoke flavor.. I think I prefer the more Â’vegetableÂ’ way. IÂ’ll have to disagree with the mass because compared to other smoked I had, this one lacks refinement. I will try it again in a near future.

Bottled. Dark copper colour with big beige head, lacing. Aroma of smoky wet wood. with sweet hints. Sweetish caramelly flavour at first which turns into strong smokish wooden malty flavour in finish. Pleasant palate and overall too very nice.

(500 ml bottle from http://hitimewine.com) Thick khaki head sits atop dark caramel brown body. Nice lacing.  Aroma is good smoked sausage, sweet woodsmoke. The taste is mellow and smoky and good. The mouthfeel and finish are smooth. Boy this is good, just right!

This was intresting,my first smokey ...big smokey bbq smell, as well as alot of beef jerky! some tar and wood too...full smoke flavour, smooth and medium dryness that blends nicely in the mouth, leaves a nice kiss of smoke, sampled 3 types of cigar..one special...went like a dream! a true classic, gotta get my hands on the marzen, takes getting used tooo

Aroma:very goos smoke aroma..
Appearance:dark brown,good tan head..
Flavor:smoke and caramel from the urbock...
Very good but a prefer the marzen...

16.9 oz bottle.  Pours a dark brown with ruby highlights, with a 1/2" head, off-white in color.  Huge smoke aroma with maybe a little tobacco as well.  Flavor is almost like swigging on a bottle of liquid smoke, and made me long for some smoked sausage.  Hugely malty, with a muted, but finely balanced level of bitterness.  Medium bodied with soft carbonation on the palate.  Not a whole lot to say about this one in the descriptive sense, itÂ’s kind of a one trick pony, but what an awesome trick!  ItÂ’s hard to believe they actually derived all the smoke flavor from the traditional method.  This has to be one of the best Rauchbiers in the world  that is widely available.

500 ml bottle.  Amazing beer.  Nice dark color with a decent head that lasted the whole glass.  The nose was super smoky.  Did it actually smell like Smoked Salmon, or do I just automatically associate that flavor the the pink fish.  Nose of teryaki even.  What a strong smoky aroma anyway.  The smokiness continued into the flavor to be accompanied by some molassas and other dark malts.  Very tasty stuff, but you gotta be in the right frame of mind.  I liked it.

The darkest and sweetest version of the Rauchbiers. its a a molasses taste of high malts and low hops. Very sweet, the smokeyness is plentiful.
Thsi the first beer I have rated that I put with a food pairing.

The sweetest of the Aecht beers so far. The aroma is sweet as well as smokey. The appearance is a deep maroon brown and the head is smaller than the other Aecht beers. The sweet flavor in this one is similar to molasses. The palate could be a bit thicker. Overall this is the best of the Aecht smoke beers.

Bottled.  I can appreciate this beer for what it is, but itÂ’s not going to be a session beer at my house any time soon.  The smokiness dominates all the aspects of this beer.  From the "neighborÂ’s fireplace" aromas to the "eating beef jerky at a Barbeque" flavors.
I love things smokey, so this is a natural. I only drink one once in a while on special occassions not to ruin the novelty.

Yellowish head, fast gone; dark brown beer with some red highlights. Sourish, leathery rind of smoked bacon, immensely intense, makes you ravenously hungry and thirsty at the first sniff. Horse chestnuts aroma, earthy. WOW! Quite sweet & malty taste; the "Rauch" of course overwhelms it all, but it is very perfumey, taste much less smoked baconlike than the regular MÃ¤rzen. Some cigarett ash, near no bitterness. Bit buttery, but no trace of diacethyl, tad of liquorice. Thick, full-mouthed, meaty, oily, tarry (Lapsan Souchong!). Omegod, this is even better than remembered, this is a balm for sore throats, food and drink at the same time. Oh Lord, why canÂ’t I get this around the corner, every day of the effinÂ’ year?
(Served by gravity from a wooden barrel at the brewery) Dark copper colour. Nice head. "Meaty" aroma of smoked ham. Very smoky, woody flavour but still surprisingly easy to drink.

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2015 The smoke flavor seems artificial; my buddy described it as bbq potato chips.  The smoke is prominent in the aroma, and less so in the sweet flavor.  Black, with a very small off white head.  The weizen is much better.  RERATE. I dont think I was ready for this beer years ago. Big smoke aroma and flavor, malt is on the dry side, full palate, full aroma and full flavor. I need to add more notes bit this is one of the worldÂ’s best beers.

My first tasting of a Rauchbier.  From the onset of the aroma, I knew that this would be something quite different but not unexpectingly.  Just from the name, I knew that IÂ’d be in for some smokey-goodness.  What I expected and what I got where just about on par with each other.  A lot of smoked flavor, like bacon or something from Hillshire Farms.  I was scrambling to find some ribs or smoked gouda to go with the beer, but alas! none were to be found.  Still, I managed to enjoy this and went back for seconds.  The beer itself had a decent, full feel to it.  Some sweetness was imparted by the malts with a note of hops in the end.  But the smokiness lingered on and on.
UPDATED: OCT 17, 2005 Dark brown color with tan head. Intensly smokey smell and flavor. Taste is a mixture of hops, malt and hickory smoked ham.

Pours a rich dark brown with hints of red shining through. Thick tan head that lasts for awhile but retreats to film with tons of lacing. Aroma is of smoked turkey and ham with some sweet malt. Flavor is dominated by the rich and sweet smoked flavor that compliments just about any meat you can imagine and makes generic cheese taste gourmet. Almost as if Capricola was smoked. It ends in a malty sweetness that lingers in a perfectly balanced state with the smoked flavors. One of my favorite beers, period.

Bottled. Dark, clear ruby red colour. Off-white medium foamy head. Aroma is typical Aecht Schlenkerla plus a heavier sweet maltiness than in the mÃ¤rzen. First the smokey, ham-like flavours which settle into a quite sweet caramelly maltiness. Mediumbodied, good mouthfeel. Excellent, though I like the mÃ¤rzen better, as the sweetness of a bock doesnÂ´t pair that nicely with a  heavy smokiness. Many thanks to joss for this.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2009 Bottle.  A strong smoked sausage or ham aroma .  Dark brown color with next to no head.  Smoked meat flavor - astrigency just detectable with a moderate bitter finish.  I really canÂ’t tell much of a difference between this and the Maerzen.  I think the smoked flavor overwhelms the more subtle bock flavors.  Still a very nice beer with strong smokiness.  If youÂ’re in Germany, you canÂ’t get this beer easily until the Fall - I was at the brewery in Bamberg in May and June and they didnÂ’t have it and neither did the nearby tourist shops.  I had to buy this in Atlanta.

Pours a beautifull garnet/mahagony with a creamy kahki head.  Smells like my back yard when I have my smoker going.  Boston Butt anybody?  Sweet caramel malts are just along for the ride.  It tastes like bacon or sausage.  Again, the malt is just kint of hanging out, and there is some bitterness there too.  Very easy to drink.  If you like the smoke there is nothing offensive here.  IÂ’m packing my bags for Bamberg.

Dark brown colour witha ruby red shine and light fizzy white head.  The nose is meaty and very smokey with a light sweetness and touch of roast.  The body is of course very smokey with a semisweet malty beginning.  Finishes bitter.  A great big smokey beer, the smokiest of the three that IÂ’ve tried, also the most robust.

Pours very dark brown with a generous pearl head. Some lacing. Smells exactly like some smoked sheepÂ’s cheese IÂ’ve had recently--bacon, sausage, etc. Also some malts, but the smoked aroma is completely dominant. Tastes like frigging sausages. Incredible. Excellent. A great change of pace.

UPDATED: AUG 11, 2005 Robe rouge claire surmontÃ©e dÂ’une mousse beige fugace et en dentelle. ArÃ´me de bacon. Saveurs de bacon, de houblon amertume, de caramel et une pointe de chocolat. ArriÃ¨re-goÃ»t en amertume.
Smells like  a hickory barbque of sorts.  Tastes similar.  ItÂ’s quite unique.  DonÂ’t know if I like it but it reminds me of meat.
This is beef jerky beer (smell & taste) - I donÂ’t think I need to say much more.  Interesting and attention grabbing.  Points for the unique taste.

this was by far, hands down, the strangest beer i have ever had ever.  :)  upon opening the bottle, before it was even poured, there was a thick bacon, pepperoni, sausage, pizza smell to it.  hugely thick white head.  very dark brown with some ruby highlights.  tastes like kilbasa, smoked swiss and cheddar cheeses, smoked summer sausage.  sweet malts and yeasts, very chewy flavors.  thanks b

This is sweet BBQ in a bottle.  Nice strong caramel smokey taste.  This is BBQ in a bottle.  I canÂ’t help craving BBQ after drinking this beer.

Available at Downtown Wine & Spirits in Somerville, MA

Mahogany hue with a small, sudsy head.  Cured meat and campfire smoke aroma, probably the strongest of the Schlenkerla beers that IÂ’ve tried.  Medium-bodied mouthfeel that was nicely carbonated.  Tasted some caramel malts behind all that smokiness.  Strong desire to barbeque something now.  Long lasting, lingering finish.

MarcelloÂ’s Wine Market, Baton Rouge, La. - 500 ml bottle. Pours a dark ruby red, slightly murky with a tight off-white head - slight lacing. Meaty, smokehouse like aroma with touches of bacon cooking. Flavor has some sweetness - reminiscent of toast with jelly - (have breakfast on my mind) to it with touches of beef jerky. Also pick up some cinnamon notes as well, but the sweet smoke flavor dominates. Not quite to the point of cloying, but takes a while to appreciate this style - still not a huge fan. Mouthfeel is thick and sticky. Overall, a good smoked beer - probably would enjoy more if I was not in Baton Rouge where it is 85 at night!

A clear red beer with a nice but collapsing brown head. The aroma is nicely smoke - obviously from beechwood - with notes like tar and rope on an old sailship in summertime. The flavor is sweet and quite smoke, though not as extreme as I had expected, it also has notes of caramel, wood, toffee, as well as hints of coffee. A very complex flavor. The end is quite smoked, roasted, and dry. The mouthfeel is very well rounded. I must admit I had expected more - but it is a nice beer.
bottled, the aroma is of smoke.  malty body, the flavor is dominated by smoke.

Bottle: Pours a rusty bronw hue with a small fizzy head but produced good lace. The aroma has notes of smoked beachwood and bacon, peat, floral hops, and a touch of caramel. The taste starts smoky as expected with a undertone of lush malt. The finish has a peaty or salty quality with some bitterness lingering. The feel is oily and surprising a tad sharp around the edges, sticky finish. This a very good brew with some nice complexity. I enjoyed it again and will in the future. Just a step below the other outstanding smoked biers I have had in the past month.

Poured a clear brownish red with a golden tint.  Aromas of smoke, wood, and malt.  Flavor was a little sweet from malt and caramel with a pleasant amount of smoke.  Light to medium body.  Nice balance and very natural tasting.

Bottle.  In honour of the language thread going on currently I am writing this review in Canadian.  50cL bottle.  This  specimen is a fine example of a smoked beer.  Pours a deep chesnut color with the red tones barely making there way out of the darkness, eh.  Smallish off-white head fades out slowly, leaving a brown, liquid centre and white ring of foam.  Fair lacing.  Aroma is intoxicatingly smokey, some sniffs I get olive also.  Body tends to be a touch thin.  Sweetish malt flavors blend fairly well with smoke.  Nice bitterness at the finish.  I believe that the Marzen would be my favourite at this point, but this does quite well.

close to room temp:  midnight ruby color, clear garnet at the edges.  head is medium tan, rocky & foamy.  smoked beef jerkey/bacon aroma.  a little chocolate malt in the backround after the head dies down.  flavor is smoky campfire malt, a little dry and bitter, but surprisingly a little caramel malt too.  medium to thick mouthfeel, lively carbonation.  dryish bitter finish and lightly salted aftertaste.  If I was at the Toronado IÂ’d be sure to get a juniper berry sausage from RosamundeÂ’s to go with this one!

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2005 A very good rauchbier which will most likely appeal more to drinkers accustomed to the American smoked porters.  The smoked character here is quite different though with more wood ash flavor.  Tthis is a good beer  in a unique style with an authentic flavor. It has a rich color, a touch of sweetness, and a pleasant campfire aroma.

Nearly clear mahogany appearance, sturdy, lasting, creamy foam on top.
Aroma wafts around the atmosphere on first cracking the crown and pouring the brew...smoke and meat, and all those associations...smoked salmon and sausage...a beefy nose, yes, indeed. Rich and invigorating.
Taste: full, massive, muscle-y...like drinking meat! Weird, eh? But, a refreshing change of pace on the palate... the smoke never abates, and I can remember the tinfoil around the fish, from when my dad smoked his salmon...brings back memories...rich and tangy on the tongue...the bock that lies underneath adds to the tastiness of this brew, which cannot be denied.
Extraordinarily unique...a malty thing, dominated by the smoke and itÂ’s tenacious associations....

bottle-pours a deep crimson red hue with a small off-white head that was fluffy and big bubbles.  Man, now thats a smokey aroma-smoked pork, bacon, alderwood, campfire, all smoke and nothing else.  sweet malts and smokey flavors that are slightly ashy and salty as well.  some char and bbq rib flavor in there as well.  Nice lucus body that coats the mouth well and deploys the flavors well.  This tastes like liquid smoke and thats a good thing ;)

This was great with barbeque at Blue Smoke in New York.  The beer is dark, almost black, small head, but leaves wonderful lacy rings around the stein.  Taste was sweet and smokey, perfect complement to the smoked beef.  Good slky mouthfeel.  I canÂ’t pretend I loved it, itÂ’s not my favorite German, but it sure worked well with dinner.

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2007 Drinking this from a stein as suggested  by fellow RateBeerian jjpm74. Thanks!  Oh my goodness.  This is one damn good beer... the aroma is pure campfire, and the taste is a liquid representation of one.  Perfect balance of smoke and malt, with a mouthfeel that is so smooth and subtle (as subtle as a smoked beer of this caliber can be), it leaves you begging for more.  Choose your favorite smoked food-- sausage, beef, chicken, whatever-- itÂ’s in this beer.  There is a slight sweet tang on the finish, but chalk that up to a pesky breeze that blows the smoke for just a moment; the smoke soon returns and lingers wonderfully on the tongue.   A bit dryer than the Marzen, but no less spectacular.  I must have this from a cask before I go to the Happy Hunting Grounds.  I must also have EVERY offering from this brewer.  People, if you have the chance, GRAB THIS BEER!
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Okay, IÂ’ve been weary of this ever since I bought it, but I need to try this. From Celebrator glass. Wow, smell caught me offguard, even after all of the reviews IÂ’ve read. Definitely campfire, smoked salmon, beef jerky. God, I never thought IÂ’d use those words to describe a beer... Hidden under it all is beer. Hops, barley. It looks really nice, too. Deep brown-red with thin tan head. The aroma goes on forever... Okay, I think IÂ’m finally brave enough to taste. First, the mouthfeel is oh so nice and rich and creamy. Feels as good as any beer IÂ’ve ever had in my mouth. The unfortunate, though, is that this tastes more like smoked venison than a traditional bock. Yes, there is a fantastic bock underneath it all, at times I can taste its brilliance, but it is overshadowed by the meats and cheeses and campfires that define this beer. The second sip contains a lot less smoke at first, in fact, the bock show through. ItÂ’s pure silk, sweet, even hoppy. In the end, this is a phenomenal beer, worth trying. Not sure when IÂ’ll try it again, but I will. Long aftertaste, very similar to having been sitting around a campfire for hours, telling stories. Superb.
Bourgogne red with a creamy beige head. Strong smokey aroma of tar, anise, wood and ham. Smokey tarry flavour, hints of anise, salmiak and burnt wood. Lots of tar and smoke in the long aftertaste.
This beer is equal to the MÃ¤rzen, but itÂ’s more intense. More malty finish, which goes great together with the heavy smoke. A fantastic brew. I want to taste this from oak cask!

Wild smoky nose, smoked meat, bacon, with some underlying malt. Very dark brown body, with a reddish tint, medium off-white head. The flavor is not as smoky as the aroma, subtle sweet malt notes, the smoke is still there, but is far more pleasant and not as aggressive as in the nose, ends on a nice little hop note. Very nice beer.
(Bottle)  Pours a medium brown body with a spare white head.  Aroma of smoked sausage, BBQ Ribs, and malt.  Tasted like the juices of smaoked sausage.  Somewhat thin in the body.

Clear brown with ruby edges, quickly diminsing tan head. Huge smoky, salty, bacon aroma. Some light sweetness. The flavor is a mirror image of the aroma, maybe a bit more salty. The body is medium full, soft. As with all of Aecht SchlenkerlaÂ’s beers, good stuff. Yum. Now all I need is a roasted whole pig to go witht this.

Bottled: Dark amber coloured. Light brown head. Aroma is dominated by smoke. Reminds me a little of bacon (donÂ’t know why!!!) Flavour is smoky and sweet. Almost tar. Has a roasty smoked end. Good one.
Black with ligth brown head. Smoke in the aroma. Good balance between the smoke and the sweetness. Long lasting aftertaste. Good stuff.

WoW! This is not for the weak. Aroma is of smoked bacon, flavor is almost the same. Get past the first sip and it will grow on you. If you love BBQ this is the beer to accompany your summer parties. However, proceed with caution.
Poured a hazy, brownish red color with no head or lacing.  Aroma of smoked sausage and other salty meats.  Super smokey taste, roast, tobacco, maple, and light hop bitterness.

I really want to be around for the first Thursday of October tapping sometime.  Anywho, beer pours chesnut brown with a modertely retained beige colored head.  Aroma is the absolutley most wonderful curing room smell of all time.  Tons of bacon, ham, smoke, wood.  Flavor is delightfully smokey and the base beer seems to be a bit more substantial than some of the other SchlenkerlaÂ’s.  Flavors of smoke and sweet malt.  The promise of the aroma outshines the flavor of this one, though I do like it a lot.  I love the Schlenkerlas.  Prost!!!

Bottle.  Deep ruby in colour with a long lasting beige head.  Aroma was of deep smoke, dried salted meats, roasted malt.  Utterly amazing.  The flavour was roasty, spicey, very smokey, roasted malts and meat.  Rich medium body, medium/high carbonation.  Finishes with a very long smokey bitterness. Wow, this is great stuff, a beautiful smoked beer.
pours brown like a cola, Favre. meaty smokey aroma with molasses. liquid meat taste like ribs without much sauce. chalky mouthfeel tea like consistency.
Bottle. Brown with no head. Nose is berry and brown sugar. Very thin mouthfeel. Lots of smoke and bitter on the back end. All one sided-smoke.

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2005 (on bottle) Either you dig or you donÂ´t; I do. Darkbrown/black, with a pale withe head. Lghtly sharp smoked nose, witch becomes milder through the pour. "Schwartzbier"-taste and the caractaristic sent of open fire remains with a watery mouth in the finish.Like sucking on your shirt after a day in the woods with the barbieq and kids.

Bottle. Dark brown/red with tan puffy head with medium retention. The aroma is, as expected, powerful smoked with some sweet malt coming through. The first sip of this beer is overpowering with burned sugar and bacon, but as you drink it it becomes more malty and balanced. Mouth feel is syrupy and fulfilling. As subtle as a fork in the eye, but a lot more pleasing.

Deep copper in color with a large off-white head. Aroma is of smoke,meat,wood, one hell of a barbecue. Smoked malt flavor from start to finish,wondeful. Great on itÂ’s own with food, or if you can afford it, a great marinate.

Smells like Chicken, I mean, Turkey. Dark brown color with slight carbonation and minimal head. This thing reallly taste like smoked turkey neck beer. Beyond the smoke and turkey, I taste a hint of carmel, nuts, and maybe toast, all be it burnt toast.

oh, god. I AM NOT A FAN OF THIS STYLE> I COULD NOT FINISH THIS> smelled like a soagy pile of shes. Tasted worse thenthat. Sorry, I do not like it. This is a very strong version of the smoke style. Not even after 5 very hot spice nuclear wings can I get the taste out of my mouth and nose. If you are  not a fan of smoke beers, lease, stay away. Sorry.

500ml bottle, at least in my stash for a year, no date found on bottle.  I tried to help it head, but I got very little from it...dark chocolate color.  Instant smell of char, smoke hits me as I pour the beer.  Smoke of a fragrant sort...malt stands behind it.  THis doesnÂ’t scream campfire, but so much more....layered with all kinds of subtle nuances...char, ashtray, ham, hickory spice, fruit, roasting beans, chocolate...Luscious aroma.  Beer comes through smooth & light in the mouth.  Finish is fairly clean with remembrances of a smoke filled maltings.  This is one of the smokier of the smoked beers IÂ’ve had recently.  But it still has a good beer standing behind that smoke.  I lthink this would make a wonderful winter drink, in front of a fire...I find some subtle minty character in there too...This is juicy, robust, and scrumptous...Awesome beer.

My first smoked beer.  This is an amazing dark brown with a nice long lasting head.  The aroma and the flavor are totally taken over by the smoke.  This not my favorite style, but a nice thing to try and an interesting beer to add to my list.

Like Â’rookworstÂ’. Or any meatthing that has been smoked. Smoke all over in the aroma.  Beautiful dark brown beer with a nice head that remains. Sweet caramel taste, quickly developing into a smokey aftertaste. Not totally my thing, but this must be a good interpretation of the style.

Wow! Liquid smoked turkey jerky!  Impressive flavor combo, melding malts and hops into the smokiness quite effectively.  Wow.  CouldnÂ’t drink a whole bottle by myself, but luckily my favorite woman and a friend were to hand to help out.  An interesting and delicious treat.  Unique.
Dark brown with a small though lasting tan head. Salami, bacon, kippers and coffee. Sweet bacon and choc flavour, so insanely balanced and tasty. Medium bodied. Bloody brilliant.

UPDATED: FEB 10, 2005 Bottle @ Beer Circus, Croydon with Duff & Kook. Aroma is sweet cured smokey bacon. Huge smoke taste balanced with some sweetness. Outstanding!
RERATE: From a wooden barrel @ Battersea Beer Festival. Sweet and full with huge smokiness. Better than the bottle.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2005 Pours a slightly muddy brown color with a thin tan head. Amazing aroma of smoked ham with a strong and rich malt character, the aroma doesnÂ’t seem different than the Schlenkerla Marzen, letÂ’s see about the flavor now. Oh God ! The flavor is even more amazing than the MarzenÂ’s, thereÂ’s the same strong smoked ham flavor that gets me damn hungry, the same rich, heavy maltiness and toffeeish sweetness but thereÂ’s a fruity flavor that complement the whole package very well, thereÂ’s also a mild bitter finish. This wonderfull brew has a full, round body, creamy and slightly oily texture and soft carbonation. Again, IÂ’m amazed by a Schlenkerla, I guess I love full bodied smoky beers ...

Big big smoke!  Even the color reminds me of slowly roasting pig flesh at the end of a long day in the smoker.  Intense smoky aroma, taste slightly bitter, rich and meaty, smooth full mouthfeel.  It may be cold out but I can feel the campfire.
Very smoky of course. Really great. Soft and pleasant mouthfeel, yet even more powerful aroma and flavour than the MÃ¤rzen version.

My first Rauchbier. This shit was badass!  Popped this thing in a bit of a nervous fashion. Right away the aroma hit me. Its like sticking your head into a bag of really good jerkeyed meat and taking a huge huff like some sort of glue-addict. Poured ruby-brown with no head at all. Taste is of jerkeyed bacon and sausage smoked and aged over hickory. 4 hours later and the taste is still with me. How many BBQ places can you say do that!? Well, maybe Jenkins BBQ on Union street in downtown Jacksonville, but thats about it.  Well worth the $5 I dropped on this!!
Love this intensely smoky brew, my first, by the way.   IÂ’ve had many since then, but still come back to this one again and again.   More smoked beers of all kinds please!

This beer smelled like a camp fire with hamburgers and hot dogs cooking.  And oh yeah, bacon, smoked sausage, etc.  The  color was a deep brown with a small white head.  The flavor was smoky, but actually allowed the malt to come through.  The finish was clean with a nice lingering smokiness.  Highly recommended.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2005 Anyone for bacon? This German Â’smoke beerÂ’ packs an extraordinary aroma like pig roasting on a spit. A beautifully balanced ale that is often recommended with smoked meats but which I found paired equally well with a hard cheese.   It poured with a thinnish head that was more than compensated by that Â’bacon-and-ashesÂ’ aroma. ItÂ’s firm-bodied with deliciously lingering smoky finish. A great beer to have with food. (Bottle)

Pours a dark reddish-brown with big light brown head with large bubbles and good head retention.  Aroma intense with beechwood smoked malt, which tends to give it a bacon like aroma.  Beautiful flavor.  The maltiness of the bock beer and the smoke balance out perfectly.  Moderately carbonated.  I like this one better than the other Schlenkerla rauchbiers, probably because this one is a bock and it balances better.  Very nice brew!

Pours ruby/brown, with a huge, light tan head.  Big aroma of smoky sausage, salmon, firewood smoke, and the kisses of my 3-pack-a-day grandmother.  Tastes malty, with some hops which give way to a gigantic smoked bacon/sausage flavor.  Dense, smoky palate.  Whether you like rauchbiers or not, you have to admire the aroma and taste of these things.

Mmmmm....the initial aroma is thick-sliced bacon as soon as I opened the bottle. Poured a rich dark brown with little head, some lacing. Pour aroma was amazing, smoked bacon and ham, wood smoke, dark malts. Flavor was more of the same, with hints of chocolate, caramel, and molasses showing through the wood smoke. Medium body, lingering smoky aftertaste. Goes well with lox or smoked ham. Well worth it if you can find it.
pours dark brown red with very thin head. smells like smoky bacon and ham. weird. flavor is pretty much the same. yep, good, but pretty weird.

Pours a velvety dark brown with an off-white head.  Aroma is AWESOME, tons of smoke, a little sweet, and some bacon.  Flavor is the same, which I find very enjoyable.  Aftertaste is very slightly dry.  Very cool.

Pours a clear dark brown with ruby edges and no head - the weird thing was it didnÂ’t really foam at all, kind of like watery bubbles that quickly dissapated. Anyway... the aroma is awesome, straight smoked pork and wood. Taste has obvious strong notes of smokey bbq along with caramel, chocoalte, roasted malt, molasses/brown sugar and a touch of dark fruit. Medium soft body with only a tiny bit of carbonation. Perhaps my bottle has been on the shelf awhile? Either way, a very solid enjoyable brew. Avoid if you donÂ’t like smoked meats or if youÂ’re a vegetarian.

This poured out a very dark brown with a reddish hue and a small tan head that was the result of an aggressive pour. The small head quickly falls to a coating of bubbles leaving not much in the way lace. HOLY SMOKES, is all that came to mind when I first poured this. The smell of the smoke quickly filled the room leaving not much else the way of smell besides a faint trace of smoked meat I believe was bacon. Following in suit was thee smokiness that dominated the flavor. I started to detect slightly sweet dark fruity malt notes as well as a bit of caramel as this warmed and some of the smoke died down. A bit of a smoky aftertaste lingers around after each sip. This was about lighter medium bodied and hard good carbonation and a smoky coating feel to it. Pretty drinkable stuff once the smoke mellowed out, definitely a beer I would have to be in the mood for. Overall an excellent beer that delivers on the rauchbier experience. I would like to try it next time with some smoked meat as the scent and flavor would seen to go perfectly with it.

Well it looks like a barbecue beer in the glass. Deep brown and great head. The nose is a knockout. This is a truly unique beer that has a great depth of character. The smoky flavour in the nose is given another dimension in the taste where the flavour takes over as one of a traditional beer profile. Bitter and significantin the mouthfeel I really do rate this beer highly.
user_location: Potts Point, New South Wales, AUSTRALIA

text: Strong smoked sausice aroma. Dark brown color, light brown head, very nice lace. Sweet, moked sausice, fruity, bitter finish, strong flavors. Heavy and warming.

Dark brown to red color, nice beige head. Aroma strongly smoked with obvious bacon and smoked ham, mild chocolate comes up too. Flavor starts with strong bacon, mild chocolate and sweet tones, ends with even stronger smoke and ham, that taste lasts very long with some hops. Some alcohol comes up also in the end, but that is not disturbing. Excellent brew, nicely balanced with all smoke and mild chocolate!
clear deep brown, off white head.  smokey malt and ash at first, but as it warms some spice , brown sugar and hops open up.  woody smoky finish.

I sampled this at Gingerman in NY and the taste was not my style in a beer.  It had a barbacue flavor too it which I was not into.  The Germans make very good beer.  For a person who likes Smoked Beer this would probably be great.

Definitly an interesting beer. I think that i just canÂ’t get into the smoked catagory. I have had this and orkney skullsplitter and didnt like either. I just cant dig drinking a beer that tastes like smoked jerkey. I am sure this is a great beer, so I wonÂ’t rate it TOO low just because i donÂ’t dig the style. I donÂ’t know if all Smoked beers have this smoked jerkey taste, but I think I am gonna stay away from them for now on.

Deep red, borderline mahogany with white head and strong lacing. Aroma is that of a strong smoked fish. Slightly musky. Not a lot else going on there. Flavor is mostly smoky, but not so much fish this time. There is a touch of fruity hops admist the smoke, but not too much else. Caramel malts come through after a couple of drinks. Fairly thin body, finishes smoky of course.

Bottled 2004 version (BB 04/2005)
Nice dark red with foamy and creamy off-white head, lace. Strong smoked ham aroma. Full-bodied, malty and well smoked mouthfeel. Hoppied bitter aftertaste. Pleasant, well-balanced brew.

Dark pour, but not opaque.  Large tan head. Aroma, smoke with a little tang.  Each of their beers has a distinct pork product aroma.  This one is BBQ pulled pork.  Slight malt finish balances it well.

16.9 oz. brown bottle. Poured out a deep, dark brown color, with a minimal tan colored head. Aromas are of a frickinÂ’ campfire! Smells like smoked country bacon. Yech! I couldnÂ’t even choke down 1/5 th of this rank beer. How do people even drink this crap?
A nice brown beer with a small head.Heavy aroma of smokiness.Taste of malts and smoked meat.Wow what a combo, smoked beef and beer,tastes like another.
Pint bottle.  Pours brown with decent head.  Nice aroma of smokeness.  The taste is almost exactly that of a 2 pound block of smoked cheddar I had about a year ago.  Deliciousness.

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2010 from old notes Brown hue with burgundy highlights under a beige cream.  Cinders and caramel from the start, a savory edge, then deep cocoa.  Rich, malt and toffee sweetness, dark chocolate, mildly smoky Â– near sharp acidity keeps it lively, lengthy roast and smoke aftertaste.  Creamy with lively carbonation on a medium-thick body.  

A vivid mix of aromas and flavors; dangerously sessionable.

50 cl bottle, best before April 2009.

Pint bottle, snifter.  Not as smokey and bacony as I remember the other AechtÂ’s being.  Some chocolate and molasses are behind the smoke (I think!).  There are some prunes also.  Overall, a dirty, smokey, earthy aroma.  Husky brown-red body with a glacieresque creamy, brown head.  Lightly sweet, moderatley acidic, moderately bitter (burnt) flavor becomes a moderately acidic, heavily bitter (burnt) finish.  Medium body, creamy/slick texture, lively carbonation.  The bottom line is: a little sharp by itself, but would likely be great with salmon or gouda!

Rerate on 7/6/05: Not much more to say about the beer, I just enjoy it a heck of a lot more.  Moving it up from a 3.8 (8/4/7/4/15).  (1 / 8 / 18 / 1 / 14 / 92)

Pours brown with an off white soapy head. Mildly smokey by Schlenkerla standards. Brown sugar, smoked malt aroma. More smokey ash in the flavour than the aroma. Sweet raisins, salt, and hop bitter. Hot doggy finish. Quite good.

Well this is a bizarre beer.  Pours a dark brown with no head.  Aroma of, well, smoked bacon, charcoal, and wood chips.  Flavor is even more burnt and bacony, with notes of kielbasa and oak (seriously).  Almost too smoky, but certainly an interesting beer.
Holy smokes!  This one is THE smoked beer to end all beers.  DARK brown with no head.  Bitter sweet smoked salmon flavour.  ItÂ’s tough to get through, but certainly worth it.  Flavourful!

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2004 Thanks for the beer skaughty! The last Smoked beer I had was the Alaskan Smoked Porter. Damn that was a good beer. This? Not so much. The beer is a nice dark brown color with a medium beige head and thin lacing. The aroma is equal parts ashtray smoke and Purina BegginÂ’ Strips.  Medium-bodied with a very smoky character, as a matter of fact it dominates everything else in the beer. The finish is more of the same. I think my wifeÂ’s question of why I smelled like a cigarette (I donÂ’t smoke) after drinking it about sums it up. ItÂ’s just too much.

Pours dark amber/orange with a thick and foamy tan head. Aroma is dominated by smoked bacon with tones of sweet malt and light spices. Also smoked bacon in the flavor. Rather sweet with brown sugar notes. A soft and thick mouthfull with lots of flavor. A very interesting beer but surprisingly mild in the smoke tone!

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2005 

The color was a reddish brown. Healthy head with some lacing. 

Staggering aroma. The smokiness from the beechwood smoked barley and the sweetness from the traditional bock malts (DonÂ’t know what they are) made this honestly smell like barbeque ribs. Very smoky in the aroma with underlying notes of cherry, chocolate, caramel and grapes.

Previously I have had the weizen from this brewery and the smokiness is much milder in the bock. Very juicy. Very smoky. Ripe fruits and smoked bacon dominate the palate. 

This beer was awesome.

Beautiful color that can be best described as burnt amber.  The body was clear and was topped with a foamy tan head.  The head thinned out, but never quite died.  The aroma is that of an intensely smoky grill sprinkled with sugar.  The sweet and acrid smell hit me at an armÂ’s length and nearly put me into a higher orbit with its intensity every time the glass touched my lips.  The taste was just as good as the smell with a caramelized sweet maltyness and a smoky bitterness.  There were some mildly grassy hop presence, but that was only a secondary pleasure.  The mouthfeel was full and satisfying, and the smoky aftertaste lingered on forever.  Very good and intricate beer that is the best of the Rauchbier offerings in my opinion.

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2005 This pours a deep brown-red color with a pale halo of a head.  Great smoked sausage & bacon aroma.  Not as thick a mouth-feel as the Marzen, but seems to something more than the smokey-ness in the flavor.  Tasty light bitterness in the finish.  An excelent, warming drink.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Liquors, Oak Forest, IL<font size=-1>

IÂ’m a bit new to the Rauchbier style, only having had Rogue Smoke before this, however I am quickly becoming a big fan.  Meaty, smoky, campfire nose that showcases the smoke much more than what appears in flavor.  The taste is a good dose of smoke, but there is a subtle bitterness and other elements going on as well.  Overall, damn delicious.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2006 Dark brown with a very small tan head.
Strong smokey, sweet aroma. Flavor of
smoked bacon and sweet malt. Well made but just not my thing.
Rerate 1/6/06: IÂ’ve been trying these beers more often and am finally starting to "get" them. I now seek out smoked beers whenever I can.
No head, but a nice mahogany color. Meat aroma. Taste is smokey, meaty but more subdued than the Marzen which is a good thing. Also has more bitterness. Very good!
Brown Coloring. With Medium Head.  Very Smokey in Aroma and Flavor.  Some Caramel.  Friend Mentioned the Aroma of Whiskey in it As Well.   This Would Be My Favorite of the Three.

Pours a solid brown color with a big head.  Good whisky and wood notes in the nose and taste.  Heavy smoke.  The smoke does tend to cover the rest of it, but the malt and wood do make an appearance.  Best of the three.

Deep amber/brown w/small white head. Smoke, sweet carmel, and malt aromas. Med-heavy malty mouthfeel with a large smokey finish that lingers on. Carmel, smoke, chocolate, oak and a slight bitter smoke note on the end. Fun beer though the smoke tends to overpower the other elements.

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2007 Very dark ruby red color and a super thick head. It has the aroma of a campfire...definitely smoked. Who ever said bacon was right on the money. One of the most interesting & surprising beers IÂ’ve had recently.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2009 Very tasty.  Dark brown colour, slight ruby tint with a thick yellow-brown head.  Rich deep smokiness with a lot of soft maltiness on the back as well.  There is a touch of soft chewy sugary aroma as well as a bit of herbal hoppy flavour on the back.  The flavour is excellent, lovely smokiness initially that is then cut by the sweetness and late kiss of hops.  Mmm, I loves me some schlenkerla.

Wow  guess they werent kidding when they said this was smoked.  I smell lots of campfire/smoked salmon.  Slight malt chocolate vinous notes.  Transparent garnet mahogany color witha  small off-white head.  Lots of smoke in the front leading to some sweeter caramel maltiness to finish.  Extremely smokey throughout and slightly overbearing.  ThatÂ’s the style though...  BACON!! THATS THE TASTE I WAS THINKING OF.  Thanks duff for mentioning bacin in your rating, cause I could not place the taste/smell of this.  Yup, bacon bits.

dark with amber highlights, thin white head, smells like sausage and absolutely nothing else, tastes like sausage, dry finish with a lingering smoke flavor, this is weird, I can see why its so highly rated though, most smoke brews taste nothing like smoke, and this is defined by it, a very different brew that definatly deserves a try, if you like smokey links you will love this.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2013 updated rating: i finally had this in season at schlenkerla and was blown away. it emerged from the oak cask a rich jet black with a bulbous beige head, leaving thick texta lines of lacing. bottled schlenkerla beers tend to show their age in their aroma quite quickly with some creeping splintered woodiness that is thankfully largely disguised by the smoke; fresh on tap the aroma is simply a delight - beer-marinated spare ribs, wet grass thrown on a fire, honeyed rye, old well, muddy gumboots. drinking this is like the entire process of smoked food in reverse - starting rich, smoky, sticky and meaty, and ending up in a scenic grassy field wide-eyed with wonder. perhaps the most impressive feature of this beer is its sheer drinkability - a litre disappeared in no time and i expect the same will be true of the 5 litre party keg that i see before me now (a steal at 14 euros). urbockzeit will be a permanent fixture on my beer calender.     
old rating: never managed to find this in bamberg so i was glad to see it in san francisco. not the freshest bottle but the aroma was still a treat, burnt hay and bacon. a little sweeter than expected, rotting fruit and a little chocolate crackle and pear, lightly salty dryness, looking forward to a fresh one some time, hopefully in october at the brewery

Amber thick head and dark ruby body. 
Strong smoke aroma at the pouring that fades away relatively quickly. Malty flavor with nuts and berries aftertones. Smooth with little carbonation, it leaves a hint of bitterness in mouth. Complex beer which needs the right environment to be enjoyed fully.

Well, the smoke was indeed very powerful. It was also quite a different type of smoky flavor than the Cone Smoker, Rogue Smoke Ale, or any other Rauchbier IÂ’ve tried. I got a definite grapey taste from the smoke. I donÂ’t know if I would call it a good taste, but it certainly did the job of concealing the alcohol behind it.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2007 Has a smokey smell kind of like smoked bacon or beef jerkey. The aroma was intimidating, it took me 5 minutes before I even took a sip after smelling it. It is a great aroma, but not an aroma I want in a beer. Dark brown in color. Has a smoke taste. Would be great for marinating ribs or other such foods. I donÂ’t feel this is a good drinking beer. It has to be paired with something to be good.

Re-rate: poured brown with a dirty white head. Aroma was smoked beef and burning wood in the winter. Flavor was smokey, sweet meats, and big malts. Kind of reminds of little smokies.

Dark honey color. Long lasting head, small bubbles. Smoky smell, a little malt and a hint of sweetness too. Sweet and smoky taste,  a weak malt. All smoke, start to finish. Would be good at the grill, or with a big piece of meat.

Deep dark brown color with a light tan head that lasts well.
Smoke and malt in the aroma. The flavor is sweet malt with smoke. Smoke again in the finish. Any more smoke and this would be annoying, but as it is, it is perfect. Well done brew.

Bottled.  A very smoky aroma, reminiscent of smoked dried ham.  The colour is very very dark brown and there is a reasonably long lasting head.  The taste again is smoky but also strongish alcohol.  The type of beer you either love or hate, and although it is harsh and for drinking slowly; it is a beautifully brewed skillful beer
Deep brown in color, very little head with some lacing, smoked beef jerky in the nose, lots of smoked notes everywhere in the beer, very smooth & drinkable, very rich malty profile, great smoked beer

trappist glass: smells like smoked bacon! appearance: clear black body with dark ruby highlight; thin and airy white head that leaves itself soapy. flavor, aroma: bacon, wood! thatÂ’s... neat. palate: oily, smooth. overall: wow, i need to pair this with something because it does not belong by itself. where's the cheese? where's the dish? yow! i need to re-rate. this is an interesting smoked brew. SMOKE!!!

Deep Brown, smallish head. The smoke assails your nostrils like a Kansas City BBQ! Rich sweet malty flavor, very little hop presence. The smoke permeates throughout. The best smoke beer I have tasted. I am headed to the homebrew store to buy some smoked malt, so I can attempt this style!

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2010 Pours a deep unfiltered brown with absolutely no-head. Very little CO2. Aromas of a great BBQ. Fat sweet malt with tons of smokiness. This beer would be awesome for marinating. Very sweet with no hints of hops but a ton oÂ’ smoke. Not really offensive though, but it does take some getting used to.  A sipper, perfect with some bratwurst or blood sausage.

Re-rate (10/20/10) Pours a deep ruset brown with one of the most stable tan heads I have ever seen. Just beautiful. So many varied smokey aromas... burnt caramel, gouda, bacon with a great deal of fresh from the oven bread. The flavors are semi-sweet. Truly one of the finest balances in any German beer labeled "bock". In no way is this cloying at all. Balanced perfectly by a moderate bitterness but no hop aroma. This completely relies on the character of the malts. There is no fermentation character at all. No esters, phenols, sulphur, nothing. Just beautiful malt. The palate is chewy, maybe the very definition of chewy. Mouth-filling with an amazingly creamy carbonation. This is rustic and beautiful. One of the greatest lagers on earth.
Clear ruvy red with a nice white head and lacing. Smoke and sweet malt in the nose. Nice smokiness with a good malt background. Great creamy texture. Mild oily finish.
UPDATED: FEB 7, 2005 Bottle. Full on salami, really smoky, with some light roasted coffee notes, so much flavour and body, without being overly complex, just really well balanced, yum.

thanks to ClarkVV for this one - dark red-brown colour with a fine foam and a nice lacing, deep aroma of smoked bacon, oily and heavy body, some bitterness in a long smokey and slightly dry finish followed by a warming alcohol touch - heavy and a bit one-dimensional but dangerously pleasant !

Huge smoke aroma from first pour. Thin, off-white head trails away. Lingering aroma of woodsmoke.  Deep, walnut brown.  Taste is great marriage of sweet malt and smoke. Tastes of smoked schwiene haxes with sherry-like notes.  Remarkably drinkable, despite assertive flavor.  In itÂ’s own class.

Hugely smoky, chewy malt aroma. You can smell it across the room. Dark ruby brown with decent white head that recedes to ring. Burning wood and leaves, strong malt base - sweet and smoky. Medium-full body and very smooth mouthfeel. Fantastic. Enjoyed with MartinT and Rastacouere. Bottle.

Ruby brown. Generous off-white head receding to a big ring. Aroma is heavily smoky, youÂ’ve got to like this aspect. ThereÂ’s just tons of ham, bacon, pork. ItÂ’s intensely meaty and feels like a meal in itself, very expressive and one that you can smell from far. In this ragard, this can do wonders as a welcome home beer or a barbecue apetizer. It remains rather sweet too with its maple suggestions, peppery and salty, thereÂ’s even leather and woody flavours in there. This is pretty complex with tons of character. The oldest sharp smoked cheddar youÂ’ll come across. Body is medium-thick, fulfilling with a bit above average carbonation. Mild bitterness in the finish balances from the rather sweet malts. Fantastic. Probably the smokiest beer on the planet and it will never get on your nerves. Actually, I wished some brewery would make something smokier and as pleasant than this, but this is an old manÂ’s daydream. Nevertheless, this remains the father of smoked beers and an experience to enjoy as often as possible. A truly unique product of great appeal.
Slightly better then the Marzen... A little less bacon taste then it.  Better nice thick frothy head, smokey aroma which is awesome.  Another good smoked beer.

Bottle (no date): Pours with a nice amber/egg-white head that is moderately diminishing.  Very smokey aroma that I expected, notes of burnt wood, sausage, earth, matchstick, and barely discernable notes of malt.  The taste of this beer is more well-rounded then the Marzen they brew.  Initially bitter and smokey, it very quickly changes to slightly sweet malty wood tones (oak, maple?, ash?), and spicey flavors.  Aftertaste is a pleasant smokey bbq-like flavor that lasts just long enough to make you want another sip.  Very well balanced for a smoke beer.  Rerate: Wow.  As this stuff warms up to room temp. it is taking on an almost port-like quality to the taste.  Interesting, I will have to get more of this and try it with cigars (too much smoke? weÂ’ll see).  This beer is a hell of a change up from the normal, although I wouldnÂ’t drink it everyday.

Deep red amber color with a lasting fine bubble ring.  Great aroma reminiscent of your clothes after sitting around a hardwood bon fire all night.  Nice wood smokiness, without the greasy bacon that you can get from a lot of other smoke beers.  Some brown sugar sweetness.  Seems a little thin for the robust flavor.  Easy to drink.  Very nice smoke beer.

Mmmm, smells like breakfast.  A little thin, somewhat sweet, doesn't seem very strong. Combines the joyous flavors of beer and meat in one package, jerky in a bottle. This would go well with some salmon, at a BBQ, or while camping. Quite the experience.

UPDATED: APR 20, 2004 Rich sparkling mahoghny, thin white head.  Like a woodburning stove thats cooking fresh salty bacon.  Flamed wood, beefy, earthy, with a touch of malted sweetness on the backside.  Hops even try to balance at the end.  Medium bodied, sweet smokey finish.  An awesome smoked beer if its your thing.  It apparently is mine!

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2007 Decent head of big bubbles.  Interesting  aroma of beef jerky from out of the smoker.  Kind of a salty terrakie (sp) smell.  Definate smoky aroma.  Color is a dark reddish/brown.  Flavor is interesting.  Slightly sweet with more smoke, spices and slightly woody.  Good balanced and depth in the flavor.  Finish is smoky again with good malt smoothness and a touch of hops.  A very good and very interesting beer that would go well with food.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2005 My first smoked beer and I found it extremely interesting. Aroma and aftertaste both reminded me of smoked salmon. Poured with a dark ruby color. This is unique. Not my favorite style, but a great change of pace. I had this again and it is massive with smoke, but not overwhelming. Apple chips and some wood. A beautifully made beer.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2006 Deep, mahogany body and soft, ripply off-white head. Aroma reminds me of applewood smoked bacon. A big, meaty Rauchbier with a little bit of ashtray thrown in. Bold, lush, and good! Nice, big body. I prefer the flat out smoke assault of the Marzen better, but this is awesome as well. Definitely best close to room temperature.

Draught at the London Drinker beer festival.  I will long remember the first time I had a rauchbier - long before beer geek days and in Germany. Although I knew that "rauch" was going to have something to do with smoke ("nicht raucher"), I was quite unprepared for the intense bacon flavour. How could a beer be intended to taste of meat? And, even if that as intended, could it be palatable. Well I did enjoy it once the shock had passed. I guess rauchbier is something you either love or hate. I fall into the former camp. This was a rare opportunity to sample a strong rauchbier on draught (using a strange siphon/bicycle pump type contraption on top of the barrel) in the UK and very impressive it was too.
UPDATED: MAR 21, 2004 Aroma of smoked meat, sweat and slight ammonia.  Medium thickness in mouthfeel, pretty carbonated.  Huge head with frothy lacing.  Seems more watery than the marzen
Poured dark amber with a thick beige head. Ham/salami sandwich aroma. Very smokey flavor. It is a decent brew but I'm no real big rauchbier fan.

Hickory bacon, dying fire aroma with a touch of some kind of sweetness.  My first smoke beer and very enjoyable I must say. The flavor matches the nose alot with a bit more sweetness.  Big palate great finish. I need to expore this style a bit more and rerate.

Really dug this beer.  Kind of looks a bit like a cola w/o all the bubble.  The nose was right on with a hickory smoked aroma.  This may sound a bit weird but the taste reminds me a bit of bacon.  I guess that's the smoked flavor.  A little hoppiness in the finish just to make it interesting.  Very good.

Great bottle! Pours with a chocolate/cola colored body and a very small white head that dissipates too quickly. Aroma is of salty smoked fish. Very smokey. Flavor is smokey, slightly malty, and strong all around with some alcohol in the finish. This is definitely not a style for the faint of palate. I can't say that I love this beer--it's definitely one of those acquired tastes--but overall I can taste some real potential here. Not an everyday beer but it would go great with barbecue and maybe cigars.

UPDATED: JUL 23, 2006 2004 bottle consumed July 2004.  Wow. (didnt even realize there was a minimum you had to write). So allow me to elaborate on wow.  Aroma is powerful, thick, pervasive, but not all smoke.  There is some rich malty goodness, almost a winey smell and some sweet nutty aroma.  Beautiful deep deep dark cherry red, burnt white head, but quite clear.  Flavor is smoke, tobacco, rich malted barley, bocky, winey sweetness.  Towards the finish I even got some hops out of it.  ItÂ’s just so incredible that you can pick out the bock flavors (just like you can pick out the marzen qualities in the marzen version).  Superb and even better with some rich, sharp cheese.  Stone porter be damned, this aint subtle, but the flavor is unmatched.2004 or 2005 bottles not sure.  Having had this a good deal more, I can honestly say IÂ’m pulled more towards the more balanced marzen.  Granted these beers arent really about balance in the strict sense of the word, but a well-aged marzen really seems to have a bit better beer characteristic.  Still this is fantastic stuff.
Now I really liked this stuff. Tastes like a yummy liquid smoke. It didn't go over so well with the other two people I was drinking with. I am going to age a bottle of this and use it in maranades.
Poured a very dark brown, lighter brown highlights, retentive tan head. Huge hickory smoke aroma and flavor, some sweetness. Medium-full body. An excellent winter beer.

Aroma is so big I would not have been suprised to see smoke escape from the top of the bottle and burning embers inside. This is a clean and solid bock completely blanketed by smoke. Slightly bitter finish, hints of salt. So much smoke yet still balanced.

Bottled.
It smells and tastes like a huge load of bacon.
Interesting and quiet fine, though only in smaller amounts.
More rounded than the MÃ¤rzen.

Whew!  This is one bold f-ing beer.  Huge Aroma!  Nothing subtle or complex about the aroma, it's like beer bacon.  Seriously, it reminds me of a smokehouse I used to visit in upstate NY.  The smoke lingers on the tongue and coats the mouth but is not at all unwelcomed.  Really a treat.  There is a certain dry sweetness that pervades the thick palate, reminds of cured pork fat and dark/bitter chocolate.  An excellent occasional beer and one that I can bust out a big ol' stein for (unfortunately I don't really know what it looks like thanks to the stein, but I'll assume is looks great beneath that massive frothy tan head).
Dark golden, somewhat hazy. Aroma from smoked fish, really smoky. Flavor brings the same smoke and some sweetness. Not my kind of beer.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2007  Bottled. 
Simply marvellous! Birch wood. Smoke. Malts. Full. Birch. Wood. Smoke. Full. Lingering. Wonderful! More-ish than the MÃ¤rzen!

Clearish dark reddish brown color with a small beige foamy head that fades out quickly leaving some good sticky sheets and strings of lace. Aroma is quite unique with a smokey twinge rendering some hints of bacon, bar-b-que sweetness, and wet ashes. Not much else really comes through but the smokened senses which isn't all that bad but would have liked to seen some more complexity within the aroma with some malts or something. Taste is sweet and tangy with a smokey character that adds subdued salty meats, touches of bar-b-que or mustard sauces, charcoal, and jerky. Overall its not really coming across as anything else but smoke for character, which is fine, but I'd like to see an already good beer then add touches of smoke then take a subpar beer and add lots of smoke to cover up the fact that its really not all that good to begin with. And thats what I'm perceiving with this. Feel is lighty creamy with tangyness and quite smooth and close to medium bodied but has some slight watery notions late in the finish. An OK beer to have an occasion but more or less I think I'll use it to marinate and cook up some porkchops or steak with. I think it'll work very well in the that department.

I was extremely hesistant to drink this after its rich Smokey aroma. However it had a sweet smokey flavor that was pleasing.  The aroma doesn't quite match its flavor, however it was Wonderfully pleasing.

Deep opaque brown color with a beige head. Extremely smokey cheese aroma. Feel is a little thin. Very strong smoked cheese flavor, with a bit of malty sweetness. This one takes a few sips to get used to, but once you do, it's pretty good.

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2005 (Bottled) Very dark amber color with a large, tight, off-white, lacy head. Quite neutral, but very strong, smoked ham aroma. Strong, slightly sweet-malty, very smoky and salty flavor with strong, bitter hopping. Ashy, bitter licorice finish. Medium to full-bodied, moderately bitter, smoky, warming and very slicky palate. ABV is very well hidden (canÂ’t even compete with the huge smokiness). Reasonably full-bodied, silky smooth,very strongly smoked and hopped brew. Straightforward, but very pleasant in small doses! Also a nice replacement for food. In a class of its own.

Pours a dark brown color with islandic lacing. Aroma is very nicely smoked, very refreshing like a harvest smoke house. Flavor doesn't have many complexities, just straight forward fruit and smoke. This one isn't as good as the marzen but is still a very good smoked beer. I'm really developing a taste for these. Thanks Indra!

Pours with almost no head, but starts bubbling a tan one up as it starts warming. Super strong smoke aroma hides most everything else. Very "meaty", beef jerky smells.  Makes me want to grill something. Flavor is malty with a nice hop bitterness.  Yummy stuff!
UPDATED: DEC 10, 2003 If you like to eat smoked meats then you will like this. Strong smoke flavor, but well balanced. Nice dark bock color, with a good and long lasting head.

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2004 color of a thin stout (deep brown with some reddish hues). no head, only a ring of a few bubbles...aroma...beef jerky and some campfire...while these are aromas i'd normally love in everyday life, they just overwhelm this beer. i cant imagine how anyone can detect anything else in this beer other than the smoke. aroma is 100% smoke...in the flavor i can barely detect the faintest hint of something floral...no one loves smoked food more than I, but come on! can't tell even the tiniest bit of difference between this and the marzen.

Re-rate: color of a thin stout? what the hell was i thinking. color is dark brown with ruby notes and a lasting tan and frothy head. not nearly the amount of smoke that i remember being in this. very metallic in the nose. ..mild smoke. flavor is lightly smoked, mildly earthy, with some bready qualities. really is much better than i originally thought.

A nice looking beer, with a good deep brown color and a nice off white/light tan head.  The aroma is really quite nice.  Good smokiness to it and quite delicious!  Really an incredible flavor!  A nice smoke, but also a good bitter finish.  Really an amazing beer!

This beer had a dark red/brown color and the head was moderate with some tag along lacing. The aroma reminded me of what it might smell like if my roof was on fire while I was cooking breakfast and drinking a Huber bock. Sweet and smoky, bacon and molasses, salty. The finish was bittersweet and of course..smoky. I wonder how this would work with beer can chicken?

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2014 First off, the aroma is incredible; very much like smoked salmon. I had to just enjoy the smell for a little while before pouring it into the glass. The beer has a thin white head and a dark reddish/brown color(but for a beer like this, appearance is the last thing on my mind). The flavor is very smokey, but well-balanced by a sweet, rich maltiness and just a hint of hops. Very well done. ItÂ’s 6.5% but I didnÂ’t even notice the alcohol presence amidst all the dense flavors loaded into this beer. A great beer.
Very smooth and well balanced. The smoke is strong, but not overwhelming. Nice dark bock color and lasting head. The malt is sweet, but well balanced by the smoke. Very gooey.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: UPDATED: JAN 14, 2004 Delicous sweet malt, and smoked bacon aroma. Ruby brown body with a very small head. Great taste of sweet smoked malts. Lingering sweet and almost salty taste. Very drinkable and delicous.
Muddy brown colour.  Smoked bacon aroma and flavour with a watery, empty finish.
Just out standing.  Has everything a good bock has.  But what puts this over the top is the great smoke flavor.

Great color, medium head that lingers a bit. Smokey smell and taste. I love this beer for two at most, then it becomes a little overbearing. Interesting though, I had a Don Diego Playboy with this beer and it was fab.

(via Mabdoney) I have only had a few from this style and this one is just as good as the rest.  Looked just like coca cola.  Strong beef jerky/smoke aroma.....a great steak beer....I got a lot of alcohol in the taste for it being only 6.5.

Bottle.  Unique...tastes and smells like a New York Strip steak.  No joke!  I ate...I mean, drank this with a prime rib, and I didn't like the combination very well.  Lingering finish and a thin mouthfeel, considering how hearty the taste was.  I like the style but this one did not impress me.

Most powerful of the Schlenkerla line, and does not disappoint. Almost had to sit down afterwards. Could not pick out a specific aftertaste as with the other 2, but still a very impressive brew nonetheless.

Dark brown to black in color,small tan head that has some lasting power.Very nice smokey aroma,mild malt,smells like a good hard wood smoked bacon or bacon bits.Very smokey flavor with a slight malt to it and you can actually detect the hop bitterness in it.The after taste is mild malt,bitter with a smoked fish attitude.Very nice brew I kind of still prefer the marzen but this is pretty decent and worth having.

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2003 Smoked bacon aroma, very similar to their maerzen. Dark brown pour, decent head. Sweet smoked pork like palate, meatiness mellowing out in the finish to sweet caramel and light hop bitterness.

Bacon.  Smoked bacon.  a whole frickin' smokehouse in every damn bottle.  Wow.  at first i was like "holy crap, the pure smokiness of it."  Volgon suggested that i eat some fine cheese with it.  i did and it hugely enhanced the flavor of not only the cheese, but of the beer.  i winced at first, but i came to like it lots.

This rauchbier pours a clear, deep, red mahagoney color with a small, diminishing tan head. It has a big aroma of smoke, burnt bacon, pork, and malts. It has a medium to full body with light carbonation and a smooth palate. The flavors are big and smokey with lots of burnt woodiness, bacon flavors, and a good, fairly sweet maltiness in the background. The finish is long and filled with smoke flavors, but still has that lingering sweetness in the background from the malts. An excellent smoked beer, very delicious and appetizing. A must try.

UPDATED: OCT 28, 2007 Smokey, bacon/meat and malty aroma. Dark brown coloured, remaining head. Not much difference with the Marzen; smokey and meat/bacon taste, malty, more bitter in the end. Decent brew.
Rerate @ PINT bokbierfestival 2007.  Fantastic brew. Original rating 3.3

Intensely smokey and meaty. Ruby, with a small short lived toffee head. Smoke, sausage, and bacon flavours, with some peat, tobacco, dried fruit, brazil nuts. Complex, bitter. Almost as unique as the Marzen!

This is the third Aecht Schlenkerla I've tried and probably the mildest and most balanced of the trio. Same smoky presence as its brothers but perhaps a little less powerful. Nice brown color with thin but dense tan head. Tastes on the sweet side but a terrific balance overall.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: I wake up hung over yet bursting with energy for the powder day ahead to find my cabin filled with smoke from the beech and oak fire the night before since I left the flue shut.   The dark red walls are coated with thick mahagony smoke, only the white carpet remains its original color.   As I ride up Wildcat ready to pound the Hoe and its 36 new Inches i'm overpowered with the smell of smoke.   The ride down is continuous over the head face shots from Punch Bowl to Pot Smokers finishing on Blackjack.   As i skate back to the line i bust out a Toblerone bar i find in my jacket half open.  The strong flavor chocolate and caramel is topped with a thick smokyness.   Once in line one of the drunk monoskiers gives me a swig of his Optimator he bought at Joanies.   The bocky sweetness is refreshing but I can't escape the smoke.  It's time to go to Germ and bash High Boy for a while, a good smokey day.

How in the world do they fit a oak burning brick smoke house into a 16oz bottle? 
This is a very good smoked beer and I highly recommend giving it a try. As the beer warms, the rich smoky aroma becomes even more pungent. It reminds me of the smell of my clothing after sitting around a campfire all day.  This is not a beer for the light hearted but you need to give it a try.

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2012 Dark brown color, short head. Aroma of smoked bacon, salami, tar. Lingering salami palate. This one is definitely stronger than the Marzen-version. Taste is more smoked, not as easy drinkable as the Marzen.

UPDATED: APR 22, 2008 When i first tried this one in Bamberg i must say i really disliked the strong smoked flavour and aroma. However, like a few others beer-styles (for me e.g. lambics and flemish sour ales) itÂ’s all just a matter of getting used to the extreme. Last night i tried this one again and MAN did i like it! The strong smoked aroma is just one of the best iÂ’ve ever experienced, the flavour is marvellously cpmplex and the mouthfeel is outstanding: very full and thick. This is fantastic stuff, once youÂ’ve gotten used to the extreme smokiness.
Tons of smoke. The bacon of beer. I felt this example of the style was a bit over the top.
One of the smokeyest beers I've ever had!  There is enough malt there to make it interesting.  The wood also comes through somewhat.  Great brew!

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2005 Hang gliding over flamboyantly rich smoked gouda lakes, earthy grilled fumes reach your dripping saliva...I could just sail over this ubiquitous fragrance for hours...The voracious appetite which is created fuels the dive and welcomes the sweet dryness of a sticky, muddy roast...Light vinous mirth ensues, as balanced and quaffable flambÃ©d characters reign...A centripetal force of bountiful rejoicing...

Huge smokey aroma (duh!) The color was a pretty dark ruby color with a large tan head. The flavor was very smokey...bacon came to mind...definitely smoked ham of some kind. The aftertaste was more malty...sweet. This gave a pleasant finish to the beer.

This was an excellent smoked beer with a velvety smooth taste and wonderful appeal.  The smokey flavor was evident but not over abundant.  Fluffy beigh head with small frothy bubbles covers this dark brownish bock beer.  Rich and creamy flavor with a malty undertone.  Not overly sweet.  Excellent palate with a great finish.  I really loved this beer.  Thanks to CaptainCougar!

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2005 Bottle. Dark mahogany. Small foamy tan head. Dark malts, smoked meat, burnt wood, smoldering earth, and some sweet notes(like burnt barbecue sauce-due to the sugars). Taste is sweet malts, roasty notes, dark smoke, burning wood, smoked sausage, and light spices. Body is thicker and smoother than the Maerzen. Medium carbonation. Lingering smokiness. Finish is big smokiness, creamy, sweet malts, light spice, and smoked meats. hint of smoked gouda as well. Nice!

IÂ´d rather eat a smoked salmon or a really smoked sausage or salami. This is more like sitting in house on fire, drinking. a pity for such a beautiful appearence. I wonder why this beer style hasnÂ´t been spread allover the world?

The appearance is like a dark Vienna with nice clarity and tremendous head.  The aroma hides a bit of the smoke that is encountered in the mouth.  The smoke is especially strong in the first half of the bottle: as it goes, the smoke merely provides highlights to a darned good bock.  I think their Maerzen is a bit better, as the malt comes out of the smoke a bit more easily.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2003 This is as smokey as anything I'd ever want. Im not a real fan of this type, but did find it very easy to drink. Half way thru I started to enjoy it, then really couldnt drink anymore.
Very mellow, but alot like drinking a campfire.

My first real intimation with a smoke-beer.  I love it.  The first thing I compared the smell to was beef jerky, but now it owns a smell of its own in my brain's library.  Great sweet body, nice finish. wow. The only funny thing is that I swear I am picking up some esters in the aroma here that I would expect from an ale. Not that I mind, but I was just surprised. Great beer.

Amazingly clear resonant ruby color with a very pale white head.  Smells of light hops and a meaty smokiness.  Flavor is initially much of the same.  After a few sips the smokiness fades a bit and is replaced to a certain extent by a rich sweet maltiness.  Smoke stays rather strong throughout, and is just a bit too strong the entire time.  This is an extremely challenging beer and it may take me another sample or two to completely make up my mind about this one.

YUCK!!!!!! i prefer my beer mid rare!! yechhhh!! i hate this stuff. call an uncultured pretentious twerp if you wish but i cant stand this junk!! it tastes like someone ground up a cow and threw it into a vat of hops!! EEWWWWWW!!! i'm glad i tried it tho. Smoked beer? what a novel idea but it fails to captivate me.if you like smoke beer this is your bag cause i coughed up a lung just drinking it!! BLECHH!!!
Dies ist GroÃŸe ScheiÃŸe!!!

Dark brown color. Medium white foamy head. Aroma is smoked gouda. It sort of like drinking a liquid glass of smoked gouda wrapped around a rasher of bacon. The initial smokiness is somewhat overwhelming, but after the first few sips it settles down into a smoky malty beer. The smokiness is well balanced by the maltyness. Nice beer, if you donâ€™t like smoke, donâ€™t bother with this beer, but if you do try this one. World class. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is smoky and slightly bitter.

Dark ruby, with a thick rocky tan head, medium diminishing and leaving decent lace.  Aroma is that of a smoke house - smokey sweet bbq sauce.  Flavor follows the aroma, with a sweet smokiness that coats the tongue.  Carbonation is hardly noticeable, but the smoke taste lasts long after you are done with the last sip.
My first smoked beer, I think I will have to look for more in this style.

Beautiful initial presentation, ruddy brown/ruby color with an oily tan head.  Smoke house with touches of ham and sweet malts in the nose.  Initialy a bit thin bodied but thickens as it warms.  Smokey and vinious as it warms with sweet, biscuty, creamy malts, and subtle hop notes.  Smoke begins to gather as it gains more of a wine like charactor in the nose and flavor as it continues to warms.  Very smooth with silky smooth malts and slight toffee notes.
Dark color with, ah, yes, smoked sausage. Great smoked beer.  Dark colored, with more malt, and preferable to the marzen.
Mellower than, say, Rogue Smoked, and smother too. Viscous on the tounge. It has a nice maltiness, but the smoke flaove dominates. Smoked beers are great for freaking out non-beergeeks
Dark purple/red in colour.  Smokiness is less potent than the Rauchbier Marzen.  Malty and smokey and pretty strong in alcohol.  I prefer the Marzen to urbock.
Ham, smoked ham in a blanket of beer. Meaty almost. Long lasting aftertaste. Great!
