Great aroma! Smoky molasses malts, barbecue, smoked sausage, oily. Ruby brown clear beer with small off-white head. Considering the aroma, the smoky taste was quite subdued - nice malty sweetness, like a bock. Light sweet finish and tinge of smokiness that I thought was less pronouced than in the maerzen. Mild-medium carb and light oily body. Very nice rauchbier, but not as smoky as the maerzen. Went great with smoked sausages and ham for dinner.

UPDATED: AUG 9, 2008 Bottle... This beer rocks... The aroma is heavily malty, but thatâ€™s not really the issue here. Do you like the aroma of mesquite BBQ? If not, stay away from this beer. If so, buy a case. Reminds me of early July in the backyard or Memphis BBQ ribs from the â€™Voo! Beale Steet, here I come! 
A truly beautiful beer.  Crystal clear crimson hue. Large, frothy, off-white, mostly lasting head that is mostly lasting. Decent lacing.
The flavor is not extremely complex. A matter of taste, really.
Heavy malt. Heavy hickory/mesquite smoke up front. The hops balance out this smoke-laden nectar.  However, you can run, but you cannot hide from the sweetness of the barley malt.  The hops canâ€™t control it, they can only hope to contain it. Forget about it!  The sweet malt wins out in the end.
Medium-bodied with soft carbonation. Oily mouthfeel. Long, sweet, smoky finish. I ate smoked Salmon with mine! How about you?  Great Rauchbier!

Smells like a smoked ham. Clear brown color. I didnÂ’t find a huge difference between this and the Maerzen Rauchbier, though I didnÂ’t try them side by side. Metallic feel to it. Very challenging. Would be great with a cheese plate. A friend jokingly said: "starts with a smoked ham flavor and ends with a bacon finish."

Deep brown with a slight tan head.  Aroma is rich smokiness.  Flavor has the smokiness everyone talks about, but thereÂ’s also some serious malt (caramel & chocolate) present to create balance.  Ok, balance might not be the right word, but it serves as a nice complement.  One note of caution:  this is not a beer to be savored -- it tasted best before it warmed significantly.

This beer is packed with smoky flavor and good hoppy bitterness.  There is some tasty sweet chocolate.  Of the Aecht Schlenkerla Rauchbiers, this is the best.  I think theyÂ’re all novelties, in a derogatory sense.  I got sick of this beer halfway through the glass.  Smokiness is neat...for a few minutes.  This is definitely worth trying, but I donÂ’t think it belongs anywhere near the 97.5th percentile in which itÂ’s rated.  IÂ’ve rated this lower than the other two Aecht Schlenkerla Rauchbiers, but this reflects the fact that IÂ’ve overrrated beers I found mediocre.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2004 nice smoke aroma.
Dark oak looks, not much carbonation, stable brownish head.
inceribly well balanced malt/smoke/bitterness
lingering smoketaste in the top of the mouth.
Body is on the thinner side. Yum.

Vertical tasting 2003 
vs. 2004
Aroma: The younger bottle shows a more fruity malt and bittering hops, the old one exposes more acidic notes.
Appareance: 2003 is definetly cloudier 
than the young version, also the head stability is better in the young one - I am wondering whether  this is due to the additional lagering or a different way of production. 
Flavor: The young one has more fruit and bittering hops. The smoke has changed a bit as the 04 version has more burned flavors whereas the old one is a bit more soft and wooden.
Palate: To be honest I can not find much difference in mouthfeel and body.
Overall: Both brews are brilliant and I have a hard time saying which one is best - probably the young one is a bit more pleasant to drink as it balances the smoke  better with fruit and bitterhop taste.

Big smokey aroma, olives?  Nice tight off white head.  Raison hue.  Great mouthfeel, medium bodied, hoppy bitter finish, totally encumbered by smokiness.  An excellent brew, highly recommended, and definately a classic, BRAVO!
Smokey fireplace chocolate aroma.Mellow smokey chocolate malt oak flavour.Slight bitter finish.
UPDATED: MAR 28, 2003 All I can say is it's like a grilled meal in a bottle.  Sweet, dark, rich meaty body with wonderful balance.  Definitely the best smoke beer on the market.

UPDATED: APR 24, 2004 Wow.  This beer is the reason this site is so great. I never would have bought this a couple of years ago.  Instead, I've had a few smoked beers before and knew what I was getting into.  This beer has little to no head.  Aroma is of smoked pork.  Hmmm...pork...  The qualities that I find fault with in a bock work great with the intense smoke in this beer.  Half-way through the bottle,  I gave this beer a great score, then I had some smoked cheddar with this.  Words can't describe how beautiful it was.  I won't be able to rate anymore beers today, as my tastebuds are shot.  But shot in a really freaking good way.

The slightly sweet signature profile of a typical bock beer strives to rise above the smoke and charcoal flavor. There is kind of a struggle here that is most unusual. This is a great tasting beer once you get used to it. Big bodied. Filling. Long complex finish.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2004 Damn, these are interesting.  Smells like a glass full of beef jerky, smoky as hell and spicy.  Tastes a bit like chewing on mesquite, full and smoky, with again a bit of spiciness to it.  Really beginning to like rauchbiers.

Smoky but not. Heavy but light. Delicious but, well, still pretty damn good. For me, however, the taste is a bit lost through the smoke. Great mouthfeel, a bit thin, but seems just right. Nicely bitter throughout. A touch of mapley (?) sweetness, maybe?
user_location: ÅÃ³dÅ¼, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Fantastic, classic beer.  Just like something youÂ’d crave at breakfast time... tastes like smoked sausage; the Marzen has a similar smoked flavor but is slightly less strong and probably would have more appeal to a beginner.  Definitely drink this one at room temperature, donÂ’t even think of drinking it cold or youÂ’ll regret it.

This Beer is like few others.  Mostly smoky and very smooth and different in flavor.  Do not try it if you do not like smoked things.  This beer is almost like drinking liquid smoke, but in a pleasant way.
I havent tried many smoked beers before, and i gotta say i really like this one. Smells and tastes like fresh smoked jerky. Would go great with some barbequed brats.

A deep garnet on the pour, the head is large, long lasting, frothy and biege, tonnes of lace. Nose is Â’Smoky to the MAX!Â’ (I Like It!), some sweetness, hints of malt. Front is sweet, the top is light, the finish is lightly acidic, somewhat dry, decent hop presence. Ranks #219 on my current 1000 master beer list. Thanks HerbJones

I guess if you enjoy drinking your Black Forest ham this will be the beer for you. Definately milder than the marzen but it really dont matter.I guess as it warms it loses a little of the high octane liquid smoke but damn,IÂ’d like at least a resemblance of a beer.Wheres the malt,hops anything but smoke.This high average rating just baffles me. It warms up a little more and finally itÂ’s starting to taste like beer rather than smoked gouda.
This is a distinctive and remarkable brew, full-bodied, with a strong, smoky aroma and flavor. I really enjoyed it.
Smokey aroma, malty full bodied, taste like smoked ham, great for the style.
Strong aroma of smoked ham. Sweet taste with smoked malt. Some wood. Extreme taste you have to acquire. Nevertheless a classic.

Bottle.  I never found a smoked beer I liked until I this beer.  A deep red mahogany color with a beige head.  The aroma is fantastic with malty smoke (roasted pig) flavor.  It is so much more than smoke with hints of chocolate and wood chips.  The flavor is rich and roasted with molasses and smoke.

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2003 poured like a glass of coca-cola classic, the head was diminished to mere leopard print lace, aroma was smokey but tart, sampled this directly after sampling the Rogue smoke ale, and such a sinario just exemplifies the quality of this beer, magnificent, medium to high carbination, smokiness was very enjoyable, meaty, woody, fresh, smoked-gouda finish, excellente... however I think I like the Marzen a tad better though I probably couldn't tell the two apart when it came down to it
This beer has the beautiful aroma of the best deli youÂ’ve ever been in. ItÂ’s the perfect accompanyment to sausages & smoked meat. Very unique. Either youÂ’ll really like it, or youÂ’ll pour it down

just the name is quite a mouthful, itÂ’s almost a lecture.  how about Â’shlennyÂ’? itÂ’s maple color and thin tan head make little impression compared to the effussive release  of aroma upon decanting--like opening the smokehouse door. meat in a bottle. as a vegetarian, iÂ’m not sure iÂ’m allowed to drink this:  aecht hamhock bock. an aquired taste certainly, itÂ’s deep carboniferous quality of a train tressle fire or the boots of a chimney sweep  seemed like a marinade, but in fact, over the course of a cool pint i was liking it more and more. beneath the soot is a firm bock base of maltiness and a full hop bitterness. very satisfying. save this one to finish the evening, few can follow it--must be the pinnacle example of the style.

Take my comments from the Marzen version and add a few points for a milder taste ( I actually tasted beer ), a point for palatability, and you have another beer that is too much smoke, not enough beer. Bratwurst love to soak in this overnight before BBQs!!!!
Smells and tastes like Sunday breakfast! Smoked bacon comes through in a big way in the aroma and taste with a richer malt profile than the Maerzen.

Delicious. Smells like salami and fresh baked bread. Pours a dark reddish brown w. insignificant head. Tastes of salt, smoke, leather, malt and faintly of licorice. Finished with a surprisingly bitter smoky bite. IÂ’m sure this one ainÂ’t gonna suit everybody, but what a great beer.

IÂ’m kind of surprised by all the high ratings - this oneÂ’s tough to handle...

very smokey - lightly carbonated... yes - tastes like smoked pork - which isnÂ’t usually something I look for in a beer.

interesting - but not a regular repeat.

for the record - I donÂ’t like brautwerst either....

My least favorite of the three beers.  A strong smoke flavor like the rest, but not as smooth for me.  The alcohol comes through well, maybe a little overpowering over all for me with this style.  IÂ’d like to revisit this one.
Wow, this is like smoked meat. IÂ’m surprised how much I like it. Simply amazing.

While pouring this brew I was consumed with the aroma of smoked sausages. The palate is medium bodied, the middle is full, and it finishes with a campfire smoke taste. This was my first smoked beer and it was very interesting. I could see myself drinking these in a pub in Germany.
Enjoyed on an early spring day. I think I would enjoy it even more on a cold winter night. Not too smokey, just right.

I just finished my Bavarian dinner of cabbage, wurst, apples and potatoes -- I wanted some kind of complement to but no obstruction of my tasting of this sought after beer. The cold aroma is like a doused beach bonfire. The warm aroma smacks of nonkosher smoked swine ass but less so than the maerzen. I was expecting a greater whallop in both the malt and the smoke/ hop balance but as IÂ’d imagined the malt quietly fills in the spaces left by the billowing smoke. The texture is phenomenal -- easy, soft, even wet in a good way. This is not a whalloping beer nor do I find it in any way challenging, although it is a smoked beer and novices might proceed with caution.

Wow.  ItÂ’s been a few months since IÂ’ve had rauchbier and this sample marks the fourth in two days.  And the best.  Nice malt and hops balance with just the right amount of smokiness.  Pleasant bitterness left on the tongue.  Very nice rauchbier.  Now only if I could get my hands on some Rauchenfels Steinbrau for comparison of a stone beer vs. rauchbier....
Its ok, but a bit too smokey, I donÂ’t think i could drink more than one bottle in a sitting.

One of, if not the best smoked beers IÂ’ve had.  The strong smoke aroma can almost drive you away if you are not ready for it.  The sweet malt coupled with the mild smoked flavors blend well witha smooth rich mouth fell.  The aroma disipates during the course of imbibing and leads to some nice malt aromas.

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2010 Bottle. Head is initially average sized, frothy, light brown, mostly lasting. Body is dark brown. Aroma is moderately malty (toasted dark bread, caramel), with notes of savory smoke (wood and meat), leather, and cumin. Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, moderately bitter. Medium to full body, velvety/watery texture, lively/soft carbonation, lightly alcoholic.  Probably my fave of the three main beers...richer and less smoke-driven than the maerzen, although IÂ’m not always in the mood for that.  I really need to try making a blend of the maerzen and bock...my usual mood is for something in between the two in terms of body, richness/sweetness, and alcohol.

It taste like a BBQ potato chip!!! I canÂ’t believe how much I love this stuff. I loved it from the first smokey aroma to the last smokey sip. This is deffinitly the one of the strangest beers I have ever had and one of my Favorites!!!
A truly special brew!  Worthy of slow contemplation.  Somehow, an entire smokehouse was crammed into the bottle.

Paid too much (actually it was worth it) and got a bottle of this stuff... WOW! ItÂ’s like drinking beer in front of a fireplace, only without the ashes in your face. Considering the fact that I add liquid smoke to almost everything I cook (Except for scrambled eggs and most stir fry) this stuff really appealed to me! This is the first beer I have bought based solely on the recommendation of Ratebeer.com and I am impressed... the panel scores a hit with this one... Something wrong with the way it smells though, like liquid smoke the smell seemed artificial, but the beer itself tasted like smokehouse scrapings, and not like a cedar closet, or other attempts at Â’woodsyÂ’ beers. I like a smokey flavor more in scotch or bourbon, but for beer, this was great, will recommend for those with the green to blow on a bottle.
Very smoky beer. Good flavor, but the head was weak. Tastes somewhat like smoked sausage and is very thick on the tongue. Good for its style.

UPDATED: NOV 11, 2014 Multiple pours from the oak barrel at Schlenkerla over the years, and dozens of fresh bottles.  While I tend to prefer the peppy vibrancy and nuanced complexity of the marzen to the bruising intensity of this, itÂ’s still a top-tier rauchbier.  It takes copious amounts of melanoidins to elevate rauchbier into something magical, and while this exhibits a hint of them, it leans toward the sweeter and fruitier side of the spectrum.  But what it lacks in beefy malt-driven complexity makes up for it nicely with its idiosyncratic pen ink, shoe polish and molasses-steeped plum dimensions.  Perhaps not overly complex and not the cleanest, but certainly a beer with plenty of soul to complement the immense depth. Even at itÂ’s immodest strength, my half-liter glass always finds itself in need of a refill within minutes.  Great beer.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: just wretched. the taste reminded me of the time in cubscouts when i dropped a hotdog in the fire then ate it - A greasy-charred taste that did not go away for a day and a half.  Now, i am willing to experiment and try every beer that i can get my hands on, this is the only one of about 350 that I really donÂ’t want to try again.   Sorry, this one is not for me.
I love this stuff more than anything when I am having BBQ or smoked salmon.  The urbock is not as good as the marzen IMO but it is still quite decent.

UPDATED: OCT 6, 2004 I love Rauchbier so my review is a bit colored.  Schlenkerla Urbock is an outstanding example of the style.  There is no point in me telling you that the beer is smoky, as you should already know this, or have read the other reviews.  But it is also well balanced, the smoke is prominent but not overwhelming. I could actually use more smoke!  You can tell that this would be a good beer without the smoke.  It's not as if they just dumped in some Liquid Smoke.  I don't drink Rauchbier as a curiosity, I drink it for the whole picture, which is a good beer brewed in a different style.
Big beer! Lots of malt, smoke and alcohol. Lingering sausage like smokey flavour. This beer is not exactly allabout balance, itÂ’s about new taste experiances.

Nice lighter brown color, with a slight head.  Aroma is, of course, smoky, with a touch of malt sweetness.  Flavor profile follows the aroma very closely, as well, with a touch of sweetness mingling with the smoked darker malt flavors.  Finish is very long, and as someone else pointed out, rather Â’wetÂ’.  Very smooth all the way through, and the smokiness kind of fades in the aftertaste just before a bit of hoppiness and some nice malt flavors shine through.  I am again suprised at how much I like rauchbier, although I am sure to keep my exposure to it at a minimum (familiarity possibly breeding negative things; I have a similar attitude about Pink Floyd).

Like drinking smoked bacon, but in a good way. Nice copper to brown color, with a hickory smoked, camp fire aroma and taste. Complemented perfectly by a nicely marinated filet mignon, grilled to perfection in my backyard.

Tastes like liquid smoke.  I canÂ’t say this is a bad beer because that would not be fair.  I just have never been able to take the flavor of liquid smoke & that is what this tasted like.  It churned my stomach!

I just got this recently and had a taste to see what all the hubbub was about.  And I can say that all the hubbub was right on!  A nice new style of beer that I could continue to savor.  Very special category of unique, classic beer.  It was love at first sip.
I know that small brewery, itÂ´s from Bamberg, IÂ´ve been there. I was surprised that youcan get this beer in the US.
Malt is just packed with smoke. Tastes like a campfire, which I like. DidnÂ’t seem to be amazingly complex flavor-wise in my opinion but was well balanced..and definitely was a campfire in a glass.

UPDATED: JUN 27, 2004 Bottled. Deep ruby red, creamy lasting thick off white head and good condition.  Luscious sweet malty nose with big, big wood smoke aromas, some background buttery creaminess and maybe even a trace of hop, but I wouldn't swear to it. Full bodied with massive but beautiful bitter woodsmoke and sweet melanoidin malt in the mouth and a touch of roast barley becoming apparent. Long woodsmoke in the finish with roast barley and sweet fruity malt. Stunning, and even better from a wooden cask. Maybe this year I will get back to try it again....
An artisinal specialty but hits the spot when itÂ’s desired.

Commonly known around here as the Â’bacon beerÂ’, this is a nice beer. Though I donÂ’t think I could drink more than one at a sitting. Smooth smokey flavor with great malts and a perciptable hop finish. Worth trying!
I didnÂ’t think this could be better than the maerzen, but it is. Similar baconesque character, but a much dryer finish.

A dark amber-brown with  a short lived fizzy head.
very malty with a strong  smoky taste.
may not be to everyones liking but definately a great beer.
worth a try if you come across it.

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2006 Nice dark amber with so-so head, some lacing. Awesome smokey aroma. This beer is incredible to me..it has a sweet malty backbone, smoky notes are interwoven through out the entire taste, incredible  creamy mouthfeel and huge body, even some quiet hints of chocolate,slightly hoppy finish even without the smoke i think this would be a first rate bock...with everything thats going on, this beer is amazingly drinkable...a gift from the beer gods.......
grab it not knowing what the hell to expect,turned out pretty ok, but dont think ill drink it agian.
O.K.  A bier to end all biers. In Germany, that is. This beer is so full of character and ambience that I am left speechless. I am glad I have case of it :) I just hope it sits well for a few years!
Wonderful smokiness.  Makes me want to go out & eat smoked salmon!

OHMYGOD.  The aroma is smoked cheddar and hickory-smoked bacon; the flavor a mix of sweet (maple, chocolate) and smoky, slightly bitter malt and wheat.  With this complexity and sweetness, youÂ’d think it would be a Â’special occasionÂ’ beer suitable only with certain foods or in front of a roaring fire -- youÂ’d be wrong.  My current favorite beer (and brewery!), justifiably occupying a spot in our collective Â’top 10.Â’  The finish is perfect, with just a hint of lingering smokiness -- this must be what smokers of fine cigars experience!
A truy awesome beer.  If I ever make it back to Germany I WILL go to Bamburg to drink it.  Make me want to eat smoked cheese.  Find a girl who like this and youÂ’re set for life.

This smoky beauty devastated me on the first sip. Even pouring it was a real treat - gorgeous color, just the right amount of head. As others have noted, itÂ’s a real food-accompanying sort of beer - it just cries out for robust meats and fish. This Urbock deserves to be a legend.

Like so many of the finer things in life, the first bottle of this stuff is awful.  The smoke is overwhelming and unpleasant, and the result is a concoction worthy of the oleÂ’ sink sacrifice. But give it just one more shot, and you will discover a beer of astonishing complexity, with varying layers of smoke at different stages of the tasting process. The underlying bock is of the highest quality.  Indescribably delicious with pork chops or smoked ham.  The best beer out of Germany, and a top five brew for me.

This is still something IÂ’ll need
to get used to, if possible.  Too much
liquid smoke flavor.
Hugely assertive. I might like this more than the marzen.
